TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering clause 255 of the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 as amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —This was debated in relation to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. I think it was indicated on the last occasion that the objectives of the tribunal are the same in this legislation as they are in the primary act. It was not satisfactorily explained to me why it is necessary to restate the objectives in this act rather than just say, `Appeal is available to the tribunal', and allow the objectives to stand as they presently exist.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the one concern that could arise from the way that this is being done is that there could be a difficulty in the future if the Social Security Appeals Tribunal objectives are changed and the objectives separately stated in this piece of legislation remain as the originals were. The minister might indicate to me the reasons for the way this was done, whether this could be a problem, and how it could be dealt with if the objectives of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal are altered in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Neal's question, I am advised that that was the advice given by the Attorney‐General's Department, that it should go in the bill. I am now advised that if the Social Security Act is to be amended for another reason, this will have to be amended as well. If the Social Security Act is amended, and this particular provision is not in the bill in front of us, then it will have to be included at a later date. I hope I have made myself clear on that.

—I think you have, Minister. Obviously, if you wanted to make sure they are maintained as identical objectives, you would not have to make consequential amendments. My question is this: why was it done in this way so that that sort of change would be required, and do we have an undertaking from the government that, if the objectives of the tribunal are changed in the future, the objectives contained in this act will also be changed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that we were advised that it was better to do it this way in the first instance, to include it in the act, rather than be dependent on any subsequent change should that be necessary if the Social Security Act is to change.
—You don't know why?
—I can't answer you. That was the advice that was received from the Attorney‐General's Department.

—I must confess that, in the absence of an explanation and an undertaking from the government that they will consequentially amend the objectives in this bill, it is very hard for me. If I could be given that undertaking, I could quite happily not proceed with this amendment, but, bearing in mind that you, firstly, seem to be unable to explain why, and, secondly, that you are unable to give that undertaking, I feel pressed to continue with it.
—Are we still on clause 255—the Social Security Appeals Tribunal objectives? I apologise for my late arrival.
—Please feel free to make a contribution.
—No, I am just asking if that is what we are dealing with.
—Yes, it is what we are dealing with. The question is that clause 255 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 231, page 169 (line 5), omit the penalty, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 120 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 232, page 169 (line 24), omit the penalty, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 120 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 236, page 172 (line 10), omit the penalty, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 120 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 237, page 172 (line 21), omit the penalty, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 120 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 238, page 173 (line 4), omit the penalty, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 120 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 238, page 173 (line 14), omit the penalty, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Penalty: 120 penalty units.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister in the chamber will recall that there was a bit of confusion about this. We supported a number of Labor amendments which were to do with penalties. They were penalties which converted prison sentences to 30 penalty points.

These amendments extend that whole principle into another series of more serious offences. I think Labor was probably not going to support these. Nevertheless, I think it is worth putting on the record the reasons we have proposed them. Firstly, consistency. We believe that prison sentences are not appropriate in any of these issues. Even though these are more serious offences—we recognise that—and to do with the disclosure of information, we believe that the 120 penalty points or penalty units are a sufficient deterrent and a sufficient penalty. They represent very substantial fines rather than prison sentences. If it were possible to get Labor to support them, then of course I would encourage them to do that.

I believe that, even though these are of a different nature from the amendments which were carried previously, nevertheless, the same principle applies that prison sentences should not be applied to this legislation; it is appropriate to have a quite serious deterrent in terms of 120 penalty units. I think this is what they are called. I am sorry, I have not got the whole thing in front of me. Because of consistency and because we believe that prison sentences are quite inappropriate in terms of this legislation, we do not agree with the argument that the prison sentences are consistent with prison sentences for social security breaches. We believe that, in those cases also, prison sentences should not apply; that there is sufficient penalty in the 120 penalty units.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, I do not know whether it is really appropriate, not being the minister, but I would like to clarify your amendment. My understanding of your amendment is that, in relation to penalties that apply to providing or giving out confidential information, I would have thought that that was a circumstance that would generally apply to employees of the Public Service rather than to parents.
—That's correct.
—Are you aware of or could you suggest any examples where this sort of breach could apply to parents who were involved in negotiations or discussions with Centrelink?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give you an example. The problem, again, is that it is the very general nature of the legislation. It appears to us that it would not only be public servants: there could be disclosure of information inadvertently through a child‐care centre itself or even through parents who had access to such information. We do not want to have the possibility of prison sentences in those cases.

SPEECH.PARA: I did signal that I understood your reticence to support these amendments. Although we believe it is important to press them, I can say we do not think they are of the same moment as your amendments which we supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, is it your understanding of the provisions that Senator Woodley is at tempting to amend that it would be necessary for the disclosure to be intentional for these penalties to come into play or would inadvertent disclosure bring into play the prison terms?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have to be intentional if it were taken to court; if it was unintentional, obviously there would be no attempt to bring such person to court. The government is opposing the amendment because there is considerable community concern about the security of information that is provided by people in good faith to governments. There have been enough examples of confidential information being disclosed, and in some cases sold, to support such concerns. I am sure all of us are aware of that occurring in the past. We are a little surprised the Democrats would want to lessen the deterrents for such behaviour.
—The point I am making is that I simply believe that prison sentences are an inappropriate penalty; 120 penalty units are, in fact,

BREAK.PARA: a very large fine and a very serious deterrent for any person. To underline that again, if you read the various clauses of the bill you will see that, while it would infer that this would mostly be an officer of the department, it does not necessarily specify that—it could be any person. For example a person is guilty of an offence if the person obtains information and the information is protected information and the person is not authorised or required under this act or the Social Security Act 1991 and has no other lawful authority to obtain the information and the person knows or is reckless as to whether the information is protected information.

My problem is that the person most likely to obtain the information would be a person in a government department, but not necessarily so. We believe that the 120 penalty units are a sufficient deterrent.
Amendments not agreed to.

First 6 non‐standard hours family day care for a school child
Seventh and subsequent non‐standard hours family day care for a school child

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are proposed in order to ensure that school-age children that are being cared for in family day care are on the usual hours for after‐school care; that is, between, say, 7 o'clock and 9 o'clock in the morning and 3.30 and 5 or 6 o'clock at night. But for those school‐age children that are actually being cared for for longer hours—maybe on weekends or overnight for shift work—the family day carer will actually be paid the same rates as for children who are not at school yet.

BREAK.PARA: It seems to me rather unfair—and it was certainly argued very strongly to me by the family day community—that where family day care is in fact providing a service for school‐age children, which is equivalent to long day care, they should be remunerated at that same level and that it would be unfair to remunerate family day carers at a rate that is appropriate for before‐ and after‐school care when they are doing that long child care overnight, at weekends and generally for shift workers.

I understand that this would probably affect a rather small proportion of the number of children who attend family day care. I would be interested to know if the minister has any budget estimates on this matter. Despite the fact that it affects a small group of people, to not move the amendment would be very unfair to that group of family day carers it affects and also for the children that are cared for in those circumstances. I would be pleased to hear from the minister about the costing on this item.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Neal, does this refer to six hours per week or per day? It does not specify in the amendment, because that obviously will affect costing. I can give an estimate on the assumption that it is the first six hours per week. The cost is about $35 million per annum. It would also complicate administration significantly to have different funding rates according to the number of hours each individual child uses each week, given that this number will often vary from week to week. The rate of child‐care assistance proposed is less for school‐age children than for younger children, because the cost of caring for these children is less than for younger children. State governments specify staffing ratios for children of various ages, and fewer staff are required to care for the school‐aged children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments proposed in fact indicate six hours of care per day. That is because the usual period that a school‐age child is minded for before‐ and after‐school care is normally about two hours in the morning and 3½ to four hours in the afternoon. That being the case, I thought it was clear in the amendment but I might just try to clarify whether we need to revise this amendment to make that very clear. I thought that the way the amendment was framed and how it interacts with the bill made it very clear that it is per day. While we are in discussion I might try to look over that.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot see how it could be anywhere near the figure that you are proposing. I suggest that the department might want to rethink that. It really deals only with school‐age children that are cared for for shift workers outside the normal hours of 7 o'clock in the morning to about 6 o'clock at night, which would be, I would think, a very small group of people. Do you have any further advice, Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I moved these amendments on the last occasion we debated the bill in the Senate and there was some concern that the way the amendment was drafted would mean that the amount that could be taken out of a person's child‐care assistance could be no less than 14 per cent rather than 14 per cent being the maximum. This amendment reduces it so that the department can only take a maximum of 14 per cent on each occasion.

—l seek leave to withdraw the original amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be opposing the revised amendments because they do not allow recovery at a faster rate. We think that option should be available to Centrelink. Under the current arrangements, the secretary can decide the recovery procedure in each case. The Department of Social Security has developed complex procedures to cover this, including recovery at a faster rate from people with higher incomes or from people who request it. These amendments rule that out. Such requests are not uncommon where the amount to be recovered is small. The amendments would prevent this flexibili ty. It is for that reason that we will be opposing them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 3A of the bill provides for the secretary to make a higher or lower rate. I understand that that has allowed some provision for a higher rate, though a fairly limited one. My argument is that it is my intention that it should be more difficult to take a higher rate. Fourteen per cent is the rate designated for overpayments and recovery in nearly all social security legislation. That should be the appropriate rate here.

SPEECH.PARA: I have some serious problems with the minister's argument that, if a person has obtained child‐care assistance and wishes to repay more quickly, somehow this bill would be a bar to that occurring. This particular section only relates to deductions from the child‐care assistance entitlement of a parent prior to the payment made. It does not affect in any way the choice of a parent who, having received their child‐care assistance—although normally it would go to the child‐care centre—goes to the office and says, `I would like to pay off a bit extra.'

There is nothing in this bill or in the amendment that precludes that from happening. It restricts the amount actually taken out of the person's child‐care assistance payment to get back moneys overpaid to 14 per cent. It is not a very sound argument for the minister to say that it prevents that occurring. It would be unfair to put a person in a situation where child‐care assistance is potentially reduced to nil because of an overpayment that may well have been inadvertent on the part of that person, so that for some period of time they cannot afford child care at all.

It could cause fairly massive disruptions to their work. Imagine that someone is overpaid $5 for a year, and they are told that they have to pay it back at 100 per cent rate. It may mean that for that particular week they cannot afford child care at all. That is not an unrealistic situation for many people on low incomes. What do they do with their children? Do they give up work for a week or for a few weeks? I do not think it is appropriate for overpayments in child‐care assistance to be treated more harshly than other types of overpayments, such as in social security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of legislation which we are debating now, the Public Service Bill 1997 and related bills, has far‐reaching implications for the Public Service and for all Australians who depend on government services. It has far‐reaching implications, too, for the parliamentary service and for the institution of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has repeatedly assured us that what it is about is simplifying the 1922 Public Service Act. The opposition does not challenge the need for simplification. In fact, we were the first to recognise it by instituting, when in government, a process to reform the act. But we do question the way in which the government is going about simplification. Furthermore, we question whether simplification is the government's principal motivation in bringing forward this legislation because what we have in these bills under the guise of simplification is, in fact, radical change.

I ask the Senate to consider the impact and significance of these changes. For example, the Prime Minister and ministers will be able to negotiate salary and conditions for agency heads without reference, if they so choose, to the Remuneration Tribunal. Agency heads, in turn, will have the power to hire and fire and determine salary and conditions for agency employees. They will have the power to revoke and amend determinations which give effect to conditions of service which have been negotiated and agreed between the government and APS employees. SES officers, the entire management corps of the Public Service, will have negligible protection against capricious or unfair dismissal. A vast range of responsibilities will be devolved to agency heads, resulting in increased differentiation, competition and rivalry between departments, and much duplication of administrative procedures. The APS will become less of a career service and there will be a loss of institutional memory.

The Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act is being repealed and with it all of the current mechanisms for review of employment decisions affecting APS employees. In its place the government has reluctantly agreed to the continuation of the office of Merit Protection Commissioner, but it refuses to give the commissioner the necessary independence and powers to carry out the external review function. Mobility rights, such as those of APS employees who are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act, will be removed after a three‐year transitional period, thus limiting the movement of staff between the Public Service and Parliament House and the benefit to both institutions which would have flowed from that movement.

The overall effect of these and other changes introduced by these bills will be to create a more compliant Public Service which is more easily influenced by the government of the day and less willing to offer critical advice. This is not the sort of Public Service which will best serve the Australian people. It is not the sort of Public Service the opposition wants to inherit.

The opposition suspects that the government's principal motivation for this legislation is its deep‐seated antipathy towards the Public Service, its suspicion and mistrust of the Public Service and its frustration that public servants see themselves not only as servants of the government but also as servants of the public. This suspicion is confirmed by other actions which this government is taking, such as cutting 30,000 jobs from the Public Service and abdicating to the private sector its responsibility for the delivery of services to the public.

We acknowledge there are some positive aspects to these bills. We welcome the inclusion of Public Service values in legislation and a code of conduct for APS employees. But while the government claims to be ensuring the preservation of the traditional ethos and values of an apolitical and nonpartisan APS by incorporating these values in legislation, it is, in fact, ensuring their destruction through the inclusion of other provisions which are incompatible with, and positively hostile to, these same values.

For example, it is true, as the government claims, that the legislation proscribes patronage and favouritism. But it is also true that patronage and favouritism will be encouraged in an environment where agency heads are completely beholden to ministers, not only for their continuing employment but for their salary and conditions of employment as well, where departmental employees are similarly beholden to their agency heads and where the government remains determined to restrict the appeal rights of public servants. I think it is fair to say that, if the government wished to undermine the traditional values and ethos of the Australian Public Service, it could hardly have come up with a more effective blueprint to achieve it.

The bills also need to be assessed in the context of the challenges Australia is currently facing: persistent unemployment, lack of job security, and lack of confidence by industry and small business. At a time when unity of purpose and interdepartmental cooperation are needed more than ever, it is foolish in the extreme to risk undermining the cohesion and professionalism of the Public Service. By weakening the ties that bind the Public Service—such as standard classifications, conditions and rates of pay, and mobility between departments—and accentuating division and competition, the government is engineering the demise of the strong, unified, apolitical Public Service that has served Australia so well for so long.

There is a high risk that departments will become personal fiefdoms headed by secretaries hired more for their loyalty to the minister or the government of the day than their professional qualifications and dedication to public service. Within departments, personal loyalties are also likely to become the most significant determinants of advancement. Put simply: this is a pro-boss anti-worker piece of legislation. Its underlying philosophy is: `all power to agency heads'. They can hire and fire at will, and name their own price. The government's proposals for agency based workplace agreements will undermine the collective bargaining capacity of public servants. This will particularly disadvantage workers in the smaller agencies and those agencies singled out for higher efficiency dividends.

A further irony of the provisions contained in this legislation is that, while the government might be simplifying the Public Service Act, in the process they are hugely complicating the Public Service itself. They are sowing the seeds of a complex and confusing mix of regulations, directions and instructions that will vary from department to department. They are creating a two-tier service of executive agencies and core departments, multiple fiefdoms headed by powerful agency heads and a resultant confusing mishmash of pay scales and workplace conditions.

The legislation, as I have indicated, will also remove the mobility provisions of the Public Service Act by making mobility rights purely discretionary after a three-year transitional period. Right of re‐entry to the Public Service is a condition of employment of many public servants in other forms of public employment. It would have been a vital factor in the decision of these public servants to take up their current positions.

Mobility is also the mechanism which has been used to encourage public servants to take up positions in ministerial offices. I believe that governments have very significantly benefited from that practice. The government is now proposing to remove this condition of employment. Instead, it will become something that can be granted or denied at the whim of an agency head. This is unacceptable. The opposition will be moving an amendment to preserve the mobility rights of public servants who currently have them.

Ultimately, what the public wants from the Public Service is the provision of policy and administrative support for the government of the day and the delivery of taxpayer funded services in the most efficient and effective way possible. The Australian Public Service has a proud record in this regard. It is a record the opposition believes should be maintained and built on. This legislation ignores this record and threatens to undermine it.

The opposition supports the concept of separate legislation for the parliamentary departments, recognising the independence of the institution of the parliament. We will be supporting the proposal that the clerks be appointed for a 10-year non-renewable term. We believe this will provide an appropriate and sufficient safeguard for their independence. We will be seeking to amend the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 consistent with our approach on the Public Service Bill 1997 .

Let me say in conclusion that the bills which are before us are not acceptable to the opposition in their current form. We be seeking to amend them to remedy the defects that we have identified. If we are unsuccessful in achieving substantial change to the bills, we will oppose them. I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to an extract from an excellent article on the government's legislation which appeared in the Age on 7 November. The article is by Judith Brett of La Trobe University and states:

The Government will lose the next election, and one of the reasons will be its "reforms" to the Public Service. What this Government has forgotten is that it is only one arm of government, and if it severely mutilates its other arm it exposes itself to increased risks of public policy and administrative bungles. The aged-care disaster is one example and there are no doubt more disasters waiting in the wings.

I can assure senators that, while the opposition certainly do not wish to prevent a coalition loss at the next election, we do wish to prevent any more such disasters being inflicted on the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service Bill 1997 , the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 , and the Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 are the legislative outcome of the government's agenda to substantially restructure the public sector of this country. I think `restructure' should read `gut'. The bills follow on from the discussion paper issued by Minister Reith entitled Towards a best practice Australian Public Service . At the outset, I must indicate my concern with the agenda being followed by this government. The question must be asked: what do you mean by best practice? In so many areas of public policy, this government, and also the Keating government for that matter, referred to the concept of international competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it, this concept has some merits. It may be considered to be a laudable aim for Australian industry or for some sectors of Australian industry, but in the context of this bill relating to the Australian Public Service, is it appropriate as a main aim? I wonder about the emphasis on increasing productivity when in fact what we should read for that is job shedding. In an area which is largely service oriented, we know what that means. But in any industry, if you are referring to this as an industry—and I would argue that it is not particularly appropriate—there are other factors. You could look at whether or not you are using your other forms of production, such as land and capital, effectively and efficiently. If you are shedding more and more jobs, I would argue that you are not necessarily using your other factors effectively and that you may be leaving people without effective access to services that they should be entitled to receive.

When you peel away the layers of government rhetoric, it is obvious that, in many cases, international competitiveness or best practice is equated with lower wages and conditions for workers and lower standards in areas such as environmental protection, occupational health and safety and food hygiene. Quite frankly, we are seeing more and more examples of very high wages paid to people at the top in order to achieve fewer jobs and lower conditions for those people who are actually doing the jobs, particularly those people who have years of experience.

I always wonder about the concept of putting people out of the Public Service and having to re‐hire them as consultants at four, five or 10 times the hourly rate. How many full time people who are actually professionally involved in that level of public service could be kept on instead of having to hire consultants?

The ACTU's submission to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into this package of bills pointed to some areas of concern in relation to both the rights of Public Service employees and also the broader issue of the impact of the proposed changes on public policy in this country.I would like to take up some of those issues as they are consistent with the sorts of concerns that I have been raising in this place over the last four years.

The first issue I want to touch on is the important question of corporate memory. Many of the changes in these bills, particularly those that will create massive turnover in SES positions, will destroy the concept of career public service and consequently threaten the maintenance of corporate memory that is invaluable in avoiding many of the unintended consequences and inconsistencies that are of real concern in the development of public policy. The reality is that many of these concepts that are developed into public policy have been around in some form or other for many years. There are parallels with previous policies that can be used to avoid confusion and inconsistency in the formation and implementation of policy changes. We have the serious risk of the Public Service reinventing the same wheels again and again.

There is also a time and efficiency issue in the context of corporate memory. In many cases, there is no need to reinvent this wheel in relation to the development of public policy. Public servants who have been involved in the development of a wide range of public policy are able to bring that experience to the table when new public policy initiatives are being developed. People who are parachuted into senior positions on the basis of experience in the private sector, and more than likely have a sympathy for the government's policy position, are unable to bring that experience into the policy development process and consequently may find themselves reinventing many wheels unnecessarily.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, you do need to have that professionalism and the ability to speak and give accurate and unbiased advice in relation to these issues. Otherwise, governments who organise a situation where they are not going to hear that critique will find themselves lurching from crisis to crisis. We already know that this government is organising it so that funding to community groups in many different sectors has a caveat, and that caveat is that they do not fund people to criticise the government. What an amazing issue in 1997—a government that does not actually want to have feedback on their own policy areas from those people who know most about what the impacts of those policies will be. Any smart government would welcome that feedback because, if they are prepared to make changes and improvements, they are likely to have good policy outcomes. This government has indicated that they are not willing to do this. Therefore it is even more critical that you have an independence and professionalism within the Public Service. That point seems to have been lost on this government.

Another issue on which I have spoken regularly is job security. In the name of promoting employment growth, this government has proposed changes such as reduced access to unfair dismissal protections for small business employees. The Greens (WA) justifiably oppose that change vigorously. It is outrageous to suggest that massive job insecurity will benefit the economy and promote growth in employment. I contend that the reduction in consumer spending that will result from the job insecurity and, also for that matter, from the creation of a growing number of part-time and casual jobs will lead to, and indeed has already led to, a substantial threat to small business in this country. You only have to walk through the major shopping centres in suburbs throughout Australia to see the number of closing down sales and shops for lease to confirm this fact. In the Public Service we will see job insecurity as a result of these bills where previously there was a level of security and a sense of a career and commitment to public policy.

These bills are about reducing the size of the public sector and facilitating the politicisation of the Public Service. They are consistent with the government's agenda to reduce the level of services provided by the public sector because of a blind faith that the private sector can do the job better. We will see the creation of large, inefficient private sector service providers at the expense of the public sector. How many times already during this Senate estimates process and the last couple have we actually seen that tenders have gone out or that tenders have not gone out at all? People have actually been employed as consultants with no tendering process—no publicly reviewable tendering process. This is happening again and again. So we have this double whammy of privatisation and lack of public information and public accountability.

We will see the creation of large, inefficient private sector service providers at the expense of the public sector. How many times already during this Senate estimates processes, and the last couple, have we actually seen that tenders have gone out or that tenders have not gone out at all? People have actually been employed as consultants with no tendering process, no publicly reviewable tendering process. This is happening again and again. So we have this double whammy of privatisation and lack of public information and public accountability. These bills are about reducing the size of the public sector and facilitating the politicisation of the Public Service. They are consistent with the government's agenda to reduce the level of services provided by the public sector because of a blind faith that the private sector can do the job better.

We will see the creation of a large inefficient private sector. We could instead have seen a positive approach to restructuring the public sector that avoided some of the inefficiencies that have been evident in some areas. I must say, however, that if the example of the outsourcing of senators' and members' travel services is anything to go by, we must have serious concerns about the questioning of outsourcing and the government's handling of it. Just to give you a question on that example: what has been saved? Do we end up with a more efficient or effective service? Just a small example. If that is what happening on a mass scale I have deep concerns.

The recently released report on information technology outsourcing by the finance and public administration committee also highlighted some concerns in this regard. We have enforced competitive neutrality in lots of areas. In relation to information technology, we have the concept of a privacy subsidy: that is, the community is required to give up its privacy to reduce the costs of compliance to industry. That is a disgusting kind of concept, and of course you end up with a lack of accountability for those people who are required to provide those services. This is not the way to go—not in 1997. If—and I have said this again and again—it is a decision of parliament to privatise more—and that is if—there should always be more accountability from the private sector to the public purse, not less. That should always be the rule of thumb.

What we are seeing, however, is the move towards industry self regulation and that includes those elements of industry which are in fact tendering for government contracts. That is not what we should be seeing. I will be looking to support amendments in this bill which withdraw the worst aspects of what we are being presented with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this cognate debate briefly to speak about the Public Service bills that are before us and the report that came down from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. There is no doubt that the Australian Public Service is different from any private enterprise instrumentality and, therefore, one cannot adopt the same for the Public Service as one would for the private sector. One cannot apply the same criteria because the nature of the Public Service is inherently different.

SPEECH.PARA: The driving force undoubtedly in the private sector is profit. Whilst profit is achieved by efficiency, the Australian Public Service, which has to be efficient, nonetheless cannot be totally dependent upon efficiency and profitability as its driving mechanism. The same efficiency cannot apply in the public sector as it applies in private enterprise. Profit cannot be the sole determinant in the way that the public sector is run. It is interesting to look at the report of the JCPA because at paragraph 2.20 this fact is clearly recognised. It states:
. . . an American academic in debating how far public employment should differ from private employment:

PARA.EMPHASIS: To many, especially those familiar with private sector personnel administration, it is difficult to understand why public sector employees should be treated any differently from private sector employees . . . the answer is simple. It is because their employers are governmental entities.

SPEECH.PARA: That really gets to the essence of these bills. There is a substantive difference between the private sector and the public sector, and these bills seek to dismantle any delineation. The report goes on:

The Committee also heard concerns that the drive to incorporate private sector management practices and philosophies into the public sector does not recognise the special qualities of people who are motivated by a commitment to public service over and above private profit.

That does stand the public sector quite distinctly and separately from the private sector. The public sector is different. The people in the public sector are different. Of course, the people have a commitment which goes over and above what might be expected in the private sector. The public sector itself is there to serve the public, and I do not believe that these bills will achieve this goal. I believe that these bills will go down the path of dismantling the concept of service to the public in the name of economic efficiency and economic expediency.

If one looks at paragraph 2.12 of the report, one sees the nature of the Public Service is different and the essence that the Public Service is a source of independent advice to the parliament. The independence of the Public Service is the very hallmark, the very essence, of what makes the Public Service what it is—that is, able to give valuable information to the parliament without any fear and without any retribution. Mr Harry Evans gave evidence before the JCPA and paragraph 2.12 states:

Mr Evans contends that the employment regime proposed in the Bill will make it difficult for public servants to fulfil this responsibility and that Members of Parliament are increasingly likely to be confronted with ministers and their (dismissible) employees `all singing the same well‐orchestrated song'.

It will be an unfortunate consequence of these pieces of legislation that we will see the valuable source of independent advice to the parliament being watered down and people being forced down the path of singing the same well‐orchestrated song, as outlined in the evidence by Mr Harry Evans.

The Australian Public Service must be independent but still must remain of government. I feel that these pieces of legislation are forcing the Public Service to be independent and not of government. They will destroy the Public Service as a career service and they get to the very issue that confronts the people in the Public Service—that is, job security. Job security remains the No. 1 issue at the forefront of people's minds, and one cannot doubt that these bills will do much to undermine the job security which has been for so long a feature of the Public Service, and thereby the strength of the Public Service itself will be weakened. If one looks at the second reading speech of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service, Dr Kemp, at page 9775 of the Hansard, one sees that he says:
We need to provide the foundation for a high performance public service while reaffirming its sense of public purpose.

I do not believe that these bills will do anything for high performance, nor will they do anything to reaffirm its sense of public purpose. So, at the end of the day, the bills will be well misplaced in their purpose.

Public servants have always given their utmost in their performance to ensure that the government is given good and timely advice. The details outlined in these bills will do everything to take away the performance that is required of our public servants to enable us to have an efficient and effective Public Service.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I refer to the government's proposed therapeutic groups premiums policy which will come into effect from 1 February next year. Minister, can you tell us how many Australians are currently being treated with therapeutic drugs which will fall into the government's proposed five groups? Is it true that there are at least 1½ million such persons who will come within those five groups? And, Minister, what will be the impact on these people, and how many of them will be exempted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I thank Senator Forshaw for the question. There is considerable debate about the therapeutic groups changes. The government does not believe that anybody will be unfairly penalised, particularly the elderly, by the therapeutic groups premiums policy. Naturally, the elderly are the main users of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and, as I have mentioned many times in this Senate, two‐thirds of the health care dollar is spent on people over the age of 65. But they are also the people who will benefit most if the scheme is more cost effective and we are able to afford important new medicines as they emerge.

ANSWER.PARA: Consumers should be asking why companies are charging more for similar drugs. We are talking about drugs which have not been shown to be clinically different when companies provide evidence to have them considered for listing on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The pharmaceutical benefits scheme is only sustainable if people take cost into account where this is appropriate. For several years there has been a cost signal between alternative brands of the same product. From 1 February 1998, this is being extended to very similar drugs.

So, in reply to Senator Forshaw, what we are saying is that there are a number of choices and we will fund a set price for the alternatives. It is a choice for the doctor and the patient to decide if they want to choose a more expensive version. Our research suggests that, when a doctor and a patient do decide that a drug above the base should be used, the average premium is likely to be under $2.

I have no detail in relation to the numbers that are likely to be affected that Senator Forshaw has asked about; I need to get further advice on that. I think that those numbers may be available from surveys only. Because this is a new scheme I doubt that they will be totally available, so it will be a presumption as to what those figures might be.

The reason that those products are more expensive is that companies want to charge more for their particular versions. The marketplace will quickly decide if an extra company charge is acceptable. Many countries use similar pricing arrangements and find that companies have to drop their prices because the real value is quickly decided by the marketplace. It is because of that as well that those figures will have to be regarded as an assumption. Who knows what will occur after the changes come into place. The manufacturers, of course, dislike this course—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're supposed to know.

—For example, Madam President, there are nine ace inhibitors—drugs that affect blood pressure—on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. They are a variation on a particular theme so that companies can compete in a lucrative part of the market.
—Which ones are these?

—Ace inhibitors. However, companies are resisting the introduction of increased competition through this measure. We have said to manufacturers, `If you can provide evidence of extra benefit, the government is willing to pay more.' Now they can't ask much more than that of the government. This can occur at any time.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time the government will protect those people who must stay on particular medication for clinical reasons through the authority prescription arrangements—that is, if a doctor for a particular reason believes that there is a necessity for a particular patient to stay on a particular drug as against an alternative, then an approach can be made to the department for that to be considered in that context. Not at any stage is it considered that anybody should be put at risk. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Today Telstra lists on the Australian Stock Exchange and over 1.8 million people are voting with their feet in choosing to be shareholders in the float. Will you tell the Senate the benefits of the sale of Telstra and, in particular, the benefits which will flow to the environment as a result of the National Heritage Trust, which was opposed by the Australian Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens?

—Yes, I am very pleased to do so. It is, in fact, a red face day for the Labor Party today and the Australian Democrats and the Greens who were so opposed to the sale of one‐third of Telstra, so disinterested in the environmental benefits that could flow from it; so totally disinterested, I might add, in the issue of repayment of debt and all the benefits that can bring to the Australian economy and to small business in particular that even today Mr Beazley is still not prepared to face up to his mistake. He said, `I'm sad that the Telstra float has gone ahead.' Sad that it has gone ahead! These are the lot that sold the Commonwealth Bank, these are the lot that sold Qantas, these are the lot we knew had intentions to sell Telstra but, because they are on the other side of the chamber, they made a great mistake and they are still not prepared to admit that mistake.

BREAK.PARA: Today's listing is particularly pleasing for a number of reasons. Firstly, we have achieved good value from the sale for the Australian taxpayer. Total proceeds are expected to be $14.3 billion for the Australian taxpayer. Good value, good money that could be put to better purposes. Secondly, many of the 1.8 million Australians who have chosen to become shareholders are small and first‐time investors. A good start for them to get into the share market and to invest for their futures. Thirdly, 81 per cent of Telstra shares will remain in Australian hands. Do you remember all the doom stories about Telstra being sold offshore? No, 81 per cent of Telstra shares will remain in Australian hands—good news for all Australians. Fourthly—this one will really irritate the Labor Party—90 per cent of eligible Telstra employees have chosen to become part owners—part owners of their company.

So much for Labor's scare campaign. Union members, in fact, in the end voted with their feet and bought shares in this company. They welcome what this government did, the opportunity that this government gave them against the wishes of the ALP.

Madam President, there was enormous demand for shares, as you know, and there has been enormous demand from the Australian people for reinvestment of some of this money in the Australian environment. In fact, when we called for applications from community groups to reinvest $1.1 billion of this money in the Australian environment we got more than 7,000 applications.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of intervention is too high. Order! Senators will not speak across the chamber during question time.

—I was reminding the Senate that more than 7,000 community groups sought funding to enhance the environment per the opportunity that this part sale of Telstra provides. So it was good news for them and good news for the environment as well.

BREAK.PARA: Furthermore, the sale is a demonstration of the confidence the Australian people have in the economy; the economy now being managed sensibly and rationally by the Howard government. It is not surprising when the Australian people look and see record low interest rates, record low inflation, booming retail sales, booming business investment and now falling unemployment that they will vote for the Australian economy, for the management of that economy by the Howard government and invest in this share float.

If I might just give you three examples re‐endorsing what I have said about the state of the economy of recent times: the NAB survey of business confidence, which came out last Thursday, showing a substantial improvement in October; the Morgan and Banks survey of hiring intentions—the best in two years—that came out last week; and a 4.8 per cent decline in the number of Australians being long‐term unemployed—good news all round. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the leader of the Government whether he could be more specific and tell us how the Natural Heritage Trust is going to help the bush?

—Certainly, and with pleasure. Three hundred and eighteen million dollars will be spent on the national vegetation initiative—the largest effort by an Australian government to fund revegetation and to support the existing native vegetation in this country. Everyone knows that part of the solution to the salinity problems and other environmental degradation is to revegetate Australia. There is now a capital fund to enable that to be done in the way that there never was before. Eighty‐five million will be put into the river care initiative, Senator Boswell, to re‐engage the challenge to restore health to Australia's streams and internal waterways—applauded, I would have thought, by all Australians who care about these issues. One hundred and fifty million will be put into the Murray‐Darling program, supported by the states that will equally fund it, so $300 million is to be invested in the bread bowl, the food bowl, of Australia—the Murray‐Darling. That is good news for all Australians. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say I am a bit disappointed at the response, bearing in mind that it was a matter canvassed at some length at estimates.
