ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not present at the estimates. I cannot be in two places at once. The policy in relation to nursing homes is not a disaster. It may be that that is the word that the opposition uses, but the principles remain intact, such as that those people who can afford to pay should be required to pay for their nursing home care. The opposition left us with a disaster in relation to nursing homes, because for 13 years they neglected this industry and the nursing homes became run‐down because there was no capital injection into it. So the only disaster that has occurred is the disaster that has resulted from the opposition's neglect of nursing homes. We are now trying to sort it out. We are saying that those who can afford to should pay for their nursing home care. To allege that there is some similarity between that policy and the therapeutic groups premium policy is incorrect. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, the Workplace Relations Act recognises the importance of allowing employers and employees to reach agreements in an atmosphere of cooperation at their individual workplaces unimpeded by third parties. Will the minister explain the impact of any change to these arrangements on jobs, growth and productivity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is abundantly clear to the Australian public that the central tenet of the Workplace Relations Act is to ensure that workers are able to negotiate directly with their employers unimpeded by the unwanted interference of the Industrial Relations Commission and the trade union movement. Indeed, I think the benefits of enterprise bargaining are now increasingly recognised worldwide. Certainly, the flexibility that flows from those sorts of arrangements is of enormous benefit to companies wishing to increase productivity, to workers seeking to get a greater return on their efforts, and to the overall competitiveness of the economy.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly, the Hawke and Keating governments recognised that enterprise bargaining was the key to a more flexible industrial relations system. So it is quite ironic that old Labor's new hero, Mr Tony Blair, stated in March this year that `the essential elements of the conservative trade union legislation of the 1980s will remain. There will be no return to secondary action, flying pickets, strikes without ballots, the closed shop and the rest.'

So what is tired old Labor in this country advocating? We saw it last week in the dead of night: a document put around by Mr McMullan makes it plain that this crowd have once again—lock, stock and barrel—handed over the single most important policy instrument in terms of productivity and competitiveness to their old mates. It is perfectly clear at the very time when the significance and influence of the trade union movement are declining everywhere except in this chamber, where of course they go from strength to strength. Indeed, I think it is well known that you have to be a member of the trade union movement to even get a guernsey in this place. That is right, isn't it, Senator Bolkus? Hands up, anyone over there who is not a member of the trade union movement. There you are. It proves the point: 100 per cent, a closed shop. You cannot get a guernsey in this place unless you belong to the trade union movement—

TALK.START.PARA: —On that side.

—On that side, yes. You couldn't get a job over here if you belonged to it. The fact is that something like 31 per cent of the work force are represented by the trade union movement overall. That is largely because of the high level of membership in the public sector. In the private sector it is about 24 per cent. What that tells you is that people are deserting the trade union movement in droves. Yet what Labor is proposing to do is to turn its back on enterprise bargaining, to go back to the bad old days of union thuggery by way of secondary boycotts, getting rid of the rights of workers to reach an agreement without a trade union being involved. They want to abolish the Employment Advocate; they want to give the IRC virtually unfettered and untrammelled power, the power to deal with any industrial matter, and to go back to industry‐wide agreements.

ANSWER.PARA: So is it any surprise that the Melbourne Age under the title `U‐turn to nowhere' says that this will do little to protect the jobs of even traditional Labor voters? The Courier‐Mail said last week that `Labor flies back to the future' and says that it is `impractical and indefensible and gives the lie to any notions of new Labor in Australia.' The Financial Review had an editorial under the title `Labor's bad old IR club'. It goes on and on. Even Senator Murray made the very valid point that the ALP just has not come to terms with the massive changes in industrial relations over the past decade. This policy is a recipe for economic disaster. It is anti‐jobs, anti‐economic growth, anti‐productivity. It is a European Union 13 per cent unemployment policy rather than a Tony Blair six per cent unemployment policy. In fact, it is a new definition of industrial democracy—`of the unions by the unions for the unions'.

BREAK.PARA: The only beneficiaries of this back to the future policy will be Labor's trade union mates. In fact, I would be very surprised if even they, in their heart of hearts, would not acknowledge that this is simply a political payback and that the workers of Australia and the economy at large will be much the worse as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can you confirm that aged care assessment teams at Sydney's Prince of Wales Hospital are finding it increasingly difficult to place concessional residents—that, is, people who do not have the money to pay entry fees of any kind—in nursing homes? Can the government assure the Australian community that all nursing homes are following the requirement to provide 27 per cent of beds for financially disadvantaged older Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I was not aware that that is the case in relation to that particular place, but I would remind Senator Denman that the reason all these problems are occurring is that nursing homes were left in such a mess when we won government last year. So little attention had been paid to nursing homes by the previous government that 40 per cent had more than four people per room and something like 60 per cent did not comply with fire relations.
—Can you give a guarantee about that?

—No, Senator Faulkner, I do not think that guarantee can be given because we would need to know the facts. I do not always accept that what I am told from the other side is factual. I am not saying that they are being loose with the facts or that they are inventing the facts, but I think in all cases we need to ascertain the truth. So before replying to any blanket question like that, I think the truth needs to be ascertained so that a truthful answer can be given to the question. I cannot give a guarantee about that because the presumption is that the matters that have been related to me are correct.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, could you undertake to ascertain for yourself whether that is the truth? Is the government now in a position to say how many people signed contracts to pay nursing home bonds? Can you guarantee that those who have signed contracts but not paid the bond will not be disadvantaged in any way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is the government's intention that nobody should be disadvantaged by the change in the arrangements that are being made in relation to nursing homes. I would be very happy to get the detail. It is interesting that Senator Denman asked: would I obtain the truth? I am grateful for her acknowledgment of that. I am happy to obtain the truth of the matter and get back to her with any answers to questions that she has asked of me in relation to detail.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, are you aware that employment in the mining industry has slumped from 103,000 in 1990 to 79,000 this year as more and more labour intensive mines are replaced by capital intensive mines? Are you aware that the three of our biggest mining companies—BHP Coal, CRA and North Broken Hill—made the list of the top 20 corporate retrenchers of the past five years with BHP Utah—your old company—retrenching 83 per cent of its employees since 1990? Are you aware of the 1994 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which found huge potential for job gains in the energy conservation and renewable energy sectors? I ask: is it not the case that your government's greenhouse policy protects the mining industry while cutting assistance to the energy conservation and renewable energy sector; that, in fact, you are protecting an industry which has indulged in massive job shedding while denying the growth opportunities of a new, emerging job‐creation industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lees for that question because she is pointing out that the biggest export industry in Australia by far is the mining industry. It accounts for 60 per cent of all commodity exports from Australia and some 33 or 34 per cent of all exports of goods and services. There is no doubt that in recent years the industry has become more competitive. Other countries are now opening up their resources which were not available before. Typical examples are countries in South America and countries closer to us in places like Indonesia and Malaysia.

ANSWER.PARA: In the process, it is absolutely vital that our industry remains competitive. We are fortunate in that we are blessed with good resources and also with the most efficient and competent mining engineers in the world—something of which we should be very proud. Not only are we exporting the raw materials that come from those particular products but also we are exporting the technology. There is a major increase in technology exports, in particular in the field of energy.

You referred to the greenhouse matter which is worth touching on. We have a reputation around the world for being one of the most energy efficient countries and we have expertise in clean coal technology. Our technology exports into areas—particularly into the Asian region—for energy efficient operations now total a figure of about $800 million, which is a very big figure.

Senator Lees also referred to the fact that these industries had changed from being labour intensive industries to capital intensive industries. It is a bit like Rip Van Winkle: that has been the case for 25 or 30 years. It is not a new thing. With increased competition, which is already here and has been here for the last couple of years, for these companies to remain competitive in order to maintain high exports, they must also become more productive. To some degree, you are seeing that sort of movement now in some of the mining operations. For instance, with the big changes that occurred in our industrial relations act, companies are now able to address productivity. If productivity is not addressed, we will lose the advantage we have had over many years compared with other countries.

You referred to BHP as `my old company'. Senator, I never did work for BHP, but I was involved very much in the major develop ments which occurred in the mining industry back in the 1970s, particularly in Queensland, but in other parts of Australia too. Those developments mainly revolved around exports into markets where the Australian companies had to gain markets from other competitors, notably in the case of the steel mills in Japan and Korea from the American producers. How that occurred was that we were lucky; we had good resources and good mines, and they worked—(Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer to the question, but the primary purpose was to look at the issue of jobs because, after all, one of the key excuses given for your greenhouse policy is to protect jobs. Minister, isn't it a fact that, while competition is obviously important, this industry is steadily losing jobs, and that you are ignoring the new jobs that are out there waiting to be created, waiting to be done, in a range of new industries?

QUESTION.PARA: The real figures are, for example, that BHP Utah has retrenched 1,648 out of 2,000 workers, North Broken Hill has retrenched 4,729 out of 7,000, and the list goes on. Are you seriously telling us that this sector is such a good generator of jobs that your entire greenhouse gas emissions policy has to be about protecting those jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —In the minute left to me let me say that one of the big advantages Australia has, if you believe in the law of comparative advantage, is the ability to supply electricity at a rate that is substantially cheaper than is available to people in other developed countries. I see, Senator Lees, that you shake your head. The cost of our electricity in Australia—and it is helped by the deregulation of the electricity market—is important because what this industry provides is not just the production of steaming coal or the production of gas, it is the downstream processing that is coming with it.

ANSWER.PARA: We are now seeing, for the first time—after a lot of people have been pushing for it for decades, I might tell you, Senator—the development of major downstream processing in this country. I can give you a few examples. You are looking at projects such as the An Feng Kingstream project in Western Australia and the development of the HBI project in Western Australia on iron ore processing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is it true that the higher education discussion paper prepared by Mr Roderick West and commissioned by the failed former education minister, Senator Vanstone, has taken 10 months to prepare and cost more than $2 million? Will the government be responding to the discussion paper? If so, when? Will you guarantee that Mr West will deliver a final report by March next year, as was originally proposed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Campbell for that question. Of course, the West discussion paper is not government policy. It is a discussion paper—just that. The government will be listening to the debate with great interest. I can say to Senator Campbell that these questions were the subject of some time in estimates, and the figure that you mentioned is correct—it is around about $2 million—but the government will be looking at this closely, and it is a matter which the government takes as very important.

ANSWER.PARA: Can I just say that some furphies are being spread around about vouchers. The minister concerned, Dr Kemp, has ruled out any voucher system for universities or HECS for TAFE, so you can take that as the government's position: those two are ruled out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true, as was stated in the editorial in the Australian on 12 November, that Mr Howard and the failed former minister's successor, Dr Kemp, are not interested in taking the West discussion paper further? Is it true that it will simply be regarded as a failed initiative of a failed minister, or can you rule this out?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —You just have to travel around the community to know that Dr Kemp is not a failed minister at all. In fact, some of the initiatives he has announced are being overwhelmingly endorsed by the community—and I point to literacy.
—He's talking about Senator Vanstone—you've got the wrong minister!

—In relation to Senator Vanstone, can I just say that Senator Vanstone carried through some great initiatives in relation to the area. I can say to you that this government does take the issues raised by the West report seriously and that the government will be listening to the debate. There is no question of them being disregarded.

—My question goes to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is he aware of the description by Archbishop Belo of actions by authorities at the University of East Timor last Friday as involving `incredible brutality'? Is it true that two people were shot, one person was dragged out of a Red Cross vehicle and driven away by police, and eight were arrested and must be assumed to be facing torture under the Indonesian authorities' aegis? What is the government's response to the call by the Prime Minister of Portugal, Mr Antonio Guterres, for international condemnation of this action by the Indonesian military authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information relating to the matters raised by Senator Brown. We have been informed by our embassy in Jakarta that a shooting incident took place on 14 November at the University of Dili. The embassy understands that a number of young people received gunshot wounds and were being treated in hospital. The embassy does not have any confirmed reports of deaths.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is obviously concerned by the violence and urges restraint in East Timor. The government has constantly called for full respect for human rights in East Timor. As Senator Brown may be aware, the government will provide $300,000 to support the activities of the ICRC in East Timor this year. Matters related to human rights issues in East Timor were raised in the recent visit by the Prime Minister with President Suharto.

This is another sad chapter of violence in relation to East Timor. We obviously would wish this sequence of violence to cease. We are doing our bit as a friend of Indonesia and as a friend of the East Timorese to encourage that in every way possible, and we hope that these occurrences that sadly are on the record from time to time in East Timor will soon come to an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister say what the Prime Minister meant yesterday when he said when being questioned about this incident, `I do not want to talk specifically about it'? Can the minister also say whether it is the government's information that people arrested under these circumstances in East Timor are almost inevitably tortured, and what is the government's reaction to that prospect?

—We would obviously be horrified at suggestions of torture. There is nothing in my brief to suggest we have information that is occurring in this instance. The comment by the Prime Minister, I presume, flows from the fact that information is still somewhat scarce in relation to this matter and from his desire to comment on the basis of established fact rather than speculation.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can you confirm that the `Dob in a don' hotline proposal is now regarded by the government as another failed initiative of the former education minister? Can you confirm reports that the hotline proposal, which Senator Vanstone maintained would provide a picture of students' experience, has been canned? Is it also true that members of the reference group, which was set up to advise how to implement the proposal, have been told by the higher education division head of DEETYA, Mr Gallagher, that Dr Kemp does not wish to proceed at all with this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unaware of the situation in relation to that reference group and Dr Kemp. I will seek some details and get back to Senator Quirke.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister also find out how much this initiative actually cost?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —I undertake to do that.

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State. Why is the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 essential and what would be the consequences across Australia if the bill were not passed by the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crane for his question. I did hear Gareth Evans, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party, on radio this morning talking about the importance of regional Australia. We are very pleased on this side that the ALP has rediscovered the importance of regional Australia, but we do say to the ALP that the most important thing for regional Australia is the passage of the amendments to the Native Title Act. There is nothing more important than fixing up the Native Title Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is essential because it does remedy the fundamental deficiencies in the Native Title Act—many of which have been recognised by the ALP and we are pleased about that. One of the great deficiencies in the Native Title Act as it currently stands is that there is no basis for legally certain, binding, voluntary agreements, which obviously are essential if we are to have practical coexistence on pastoral lease land.

The act passed by the Labor government sets up a completely unworkable process. In Western Australia—Senator Crane's state—1,910 mining and exploration leases have been subject to the full right to negotiate process and only 148 have actually got through the process. The clearance rate for mining and exploration leases subject to the right to negotiate is only 7.7 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: The act has simply not delivered for Aboriginal Australians. We now have over 660 native title claims in the process that have been registered. They cover about 45 per cent of the Australian mainland. There has been only one determination of native title on the Australian mainland. So the act simply has not delivered. If the ALP talked to Aboriginal people on the ground, they would discover that.

The Wik decision has now more than doubled the area of Australia subject to native title—it is now 79 per cent. So all the problems with the Native Title Act are much more acute than was the case. We have multiple overlapping claims all around Australia which are dividing Aboriginal communities themselves and, frankly, raising unrealistic expectations of what native title might actually deliver. If the ALP would spend some time on the ground in the Western Australian goldfields and talk to Aborigines in the Western Australian goldfields, they would see what an absolute mess there is and what internal strife is being caused by a maze of overlapping multiple claims.

Across the country, the act is impeding state and territory management of land as well as pastoral lease land and is causing significant problems for local government—something which I think the ALP is also failing to realise. In relation to local government, as Senator Crane would well know, the people of Karratha are really suffering from the blockage in the system in relation to native title claims because housing land availability is causing enormous problems there.

The mining and exploration industries are facing very real difficulties with uncertainty about the validity of their mining and exploration titles. We heard from the Democrats just then about the drop in employment in one of the most essential industries in this country, the mining industry, which clearly is related to native title problems. Since the Wik decision, pastoralists across the country have been completely unsure of what their rights are, not because of the Wik decision itself but because of the operation of the current Native Title Act and the great uncertainty which it is causing for people across the country.

The bill is very important because it does a number of essential things: it gives effect to the Wik decision, something that the ALP is not acknowledging; it reflects the common law finding that native title is extinguished on grants of exclusive possession; it provides legal certainty for agreements about native title; it maintains the statutory right to negotiate on land which has never been alienated; and, on pastoral lease land, it guarantees equal rights for lessees and for native title holders—what could be fairer than that? I say to the ALP: if you really care about regional Australia, you will pass this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I noted your comments that only 148 mining applications have gone through the process and that, out of well over 600 native title claims, only one has been determined on the mainland under the current Native Title Act or `Keating's big bungle'. How does the bill's approach to the fundamental issue of validation differ from that of the current act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —Point one of the 10-point plan is about validation. The current Native Title Act validated absolutely everything that had occurred prior to 1994 that might have been invalid due to native title. So, under the current act, validated pastoral leases completely extinguish native title, which is one of the ironies of the current situation. The only legislative extinguishment of native title on pastoral leases that may have occurred in this country is as a result of the former Labor government's Native Title Act. Graham Richardson has revealed that he, as a cabinet minister, thought that the act extinguished native title on all pastoral leases right across Australia—a bill that they all voted for.

ANSWER.PARA: Our bill provides a much more limited validation regime for acts on pastoral lease land between the commencement of the Native Title Act and the Wik decision. Native title will not necessarily be extinguished by this validation, unlike under the current act. This is further reflection of the fact that we are respecting and reflecting the Wik decision in our bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, is the family home still part of the nursing home assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has foreshadowed that he will be making an announcement in relation to changes of the policy, and he will be doing so as soon as possible. As I have said previously, there is no alteration in the generality of the policy that those who can afford to pay should be required to do so. They are very silent on the other side when we bring up this principle. We have to remember that when the Labor Party were in power the nursing home capital expenditure approvals had been slashed by 90 per cent.

—Madam President, I take a point of order. My point of order is on the basis of relevance. Even for Senator Herron, who has not been able to answer a question today, this is a simple one: is the family home still part of the nursing home assets test? Even he might be able to have a go at answering that, Madam President, and I ask you to direct him to do so.
—Senator Herron has dealt with that and is elucidating his answer, which he may do if he wishes.

—I am quite happy to repeat that. I ask the opposition whether they agree with the principle that those who can afford to pay something towards their nursing home care should do so. There is a deafening silence, Madam President. The state of the nursing homes in this country is an absolute disgrace. It is a national disgrace that only 13 per cent qualify with health standards and 11 per cent with fire regulations.

ANSWER.PARA: Our reforms are based on four principles: fairness, which they would not understand that on the other side; the capacity to contribute; a needs access—not means, Senator Gibbs; and addressing the long‐term needs of the aged. The policy is based on those principles. The policy details will be announced by the minister as soon as possible, following discussions as he has had in relation to the nursing home providers and the consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I am very confused. Is that a yes or a no? The minister went around and around. My question consisted of one sentence, and all I wanted was a yes or a no.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that not only is Senator Gibbs confused but the whole of the opposition are confused. They set up this scare campaign and established the problem, as I have said previously. We inherited that problem and have tackled it head‐on to do something about it. Senator Gibbs, the Labor Party were confused when they were in government, because they did nothing to address this problem.

—Madam President, I have a point of order. Senator Herron is unable to answer a simple question: is the family home still part of the nursing home assets test? He has been asked a primary question and he has been asked again. You ought to direct this minister to answer what is a very simple question. He has not been able to answer any other question directed to him today, but surely he could have a go at answering this one.

—On the point of order, Madam President: that was an appalling performance because it was simply an assertion, not a submission. It did not add anything to the comments that had been made a little earlier, and which had been overruled comprehensively by you, when you made it clear to Senator Faulkner that Senator Herron had answered, and was in the process of answering, the question. You ought to treat it as simply a time‐wasting exercise rather than any submission on the merit.
—The minister is entitled to deal with the question and answer it as he sees fit. Senator Herron is, I believe, doing that.

—I was making it clear, Madam President, that the minister will be making an announcement in regard to nursing homes as soon as possible and that the detail will be clarified. It is no wonder that the listening public do not have very great regard for politicians when we get this sort of behaviour by the Labor Party in this chamber. I would hope that they would have an interest in raising the standards so that the people who are listening to this can be assured that their representatives are taking things in a—(Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, an hour ago Telstra shares were trading on the market at 60c higher than the government sold them for. That means that the stock market has valued Telstra at $2.6 billion more than the government sold it for. In other words, the government has undervalued Telstra by 18 per cent. Minister, are you aware that a month ago the Democrats called for the government to set the share price at $4?
—You idiot.
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I am sorry to interrupt, but I did hear Senator Campbell call Senator Allison an idiot. I think that is unparliamentary.
—I did not hear that comment. Senator Campbell, if you used that comment, I would ask you to withdraw it.
—I am sorry you did not hear it, Madam President, but I withdraw.

—Minister, are you aware that a month ago the Democrats called for the government to set the share price at $4? Our assessment of $4 was backed by stockbrokers James Capel and business analyst Robert Gottliebsen. Minister, what do you say to the 90 per cent of Australians who do not own Telstra shares, when they see that a $2.6 billion windfall has been transferred from public ownership to the private benefit of Telstra shareholders? Will you be investigating why the finance department and its business advisers ignored the evidence and got the price so wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Allison has mentioned the exceedingly successful float of Telstra that occurred today on the Stock Exchange and that means that so many Australians were able to support this very important float. In relation to the price of the shares they were offered, the government received the best advice available and that was the price which was set for the float.

ANSWER.PARA: The Democrats have got a problem with Telstra. I point out to you why they do. In the first place, Senator, you opposed the government bringing in this key election promise that we went to the people with in the last election—that we would sell one-third of Telstra. Senator, you fought that tooth and nail through this Senate with the assistance of the Labor Party. You attempted to make the government break its promises. That is what you attempted to do. The government, I believe, was quite right in proceeding with this promise that it went to the election on.

The next point I would make is that you seem to forget that not only have private people obtained these shares but many major institutions have also obtained shares under the allocation. In this way, all those Australians who have an interest in those particular institutions—super funds and others—will benefit. This is a great benefit to the nation. Senator, we make no apology for this very important initiative which has been so widely welcomed by all Australians and, of course, keeps a promise that the government made to the people in the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask you again, Minister: do you accept that a $2.6 billion loss to Australian taxpayers is not irresponsible on the part of the government? Minister, I remind you of the massive undervaluation of Telstra following as it does on the multibillion dollar undervaluation of share prices for the Commonwealth Bank, CSL and Qantas. Is it not the case that privatisation is very much about enriching some at the expense of the vast majority of Australians who benefited from the lower taxes that the public ownership of Telstra allowed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —There were many statements and assumptions made in your question to me then—none of which I agree with. The fact of the matter is that this is of great benefit to all Australians. It keeps a key election promise that we made to the Australian people.

BREAK.PARA: I can understand the sourness and the bitterness of the Democrats because they attempted to force the government to break its promises to the Australian people. I am very proud to say that we kept our promise to the Australian people and this float has been widely welcomed by the public. That is why you feel so bad about it, Senator. But the truth of the matter is that, on this issue, the Democrats are absolutely out of kilter with major Australian public opinion. I hope you have learnt your lesson: do not join the Labor Party on these types of issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, do you regard the views on the 10-point plan and Aboriginal reconciliation expressed by participants in the AFI awards and by Pat Dodson in his eulogy at Nugget Coombs's state funeral as partisan political statements or as genuine concerns about the direction your government is taking race relations in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for the question. I am very concerned about the reconciliation process because I believe it is important that the reconciliation process continue. Patrick Dodson in his statement to the press said that he believed that as well, as did Sir Ronald Wilson. I believe that the reconciliation process has gained a momentum of its own now that, regardless of people who scoff about these things—
—How can you say that?

—I acknowledge the interjection of Senator Bolkus because he has been one of the scoffers. Senator Bolkus has not been around out in the community. There is widespread community involvement in the reconciliation process—2,000 people attended the reconciliation convention in Melbourne. There is enormous support for the reconciliation process. The scoffers like Senator Bolkus have not been out in the community and are not aware of what is occurring in the wider community, as I, as many members on our side and as many members of his own party are. There is a momentum occurring that I believe will reach fulfilment.

ANSWER.PARA: The difficulty is that statements such as these that are made out of context are attempting to link inextricably the native title debate to the reconciliation process. It is but part of the reconciliation process. The reconciliation process is something that I think all of us in this chamber should be supporting in the nation's interest as a whole.

In relation to the 10-point plan, of course I support the government's initiative in that regard because we were left with an unworkable situation following the passage of the Native Title Act, which Senator Minchin has already referred to. Under the Native Title Act there has been only one agreement achieved out of more than 600 claims that were put in, and more than 40 per cent of this country is now subject to native title claim. Surely it is in the interests of everybody in this chamber to recognise the significance of the reconciliation process in the long-term interest of the nation and not to try to drag everything that anybody wants to comment on into that reconciliation process when it quite rightly is not related.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of those comments, Minister, was your colleague Mr Anderson correct in dismissing the views expressed by so many of the participants in the AFI awards as being politically motivated?

Senator Crowley, you have been around long enough to know that politics intervenes into everything. If you have the opportunity of using a platform for your own political purposes, then you do so. I recognise the validity of what was done but I do not recognise that that was representative of everybody who was there. People use these processes because they are available to them to make political statements. That is politics. That is what occurs in the outside world. If

BREAK.PARA: that is what they want to do, it is their right to do so. It is a democratic country. They can do what they like in that regard. The question is: how much significance is paid to that and whom do those people represent?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday, 11 November, Senator McKiernan asked me some questions in relation to some remarks that the Commonwealth DPP had made in his annual report. I have an answer for him which I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response to Question from Senator McKiernan

SPEECH.PARA: Senator VANSTONE: On Tuesday 11 November 1997 Senator McKiernan asked me a question about a comment made by the Commonwealth DPP in his Annual Report for 1996/97. Senator McKiernan's question related to the number of cases which are affected by ineligibility of the defendant to obtain legal aid and the principle enunciated by the High Court in Dietrich . Senator McKiernan asked which cases were referred to by the DPP and the nature of the offences involved in those cases.

I undertook to make inquiries through the Attorney‐General about the matter and to provide the information at a later date. I am now able to table a document which sets out the information sought by Senator McKiernan.
Cases Affected by the Dietrich Principle

The following matters which are currently being prosecuted by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions have been stayed or are under threat of being stayed on the basis that the defendants do not have access to legal aid and otherwise fit within the criteria set down by the High Court in the Dietrich decision:

ROW.ENTRY: Charged with conspiracy to import a trafficable quantity of ecstasy. Arthur Roberts has additional charges.

Last mentioned on 30 October 1997 before the District Court of Western Australia when Legal Aid Western Australia informed the Court that it would not be funding the defence on the ground that there was only limited funding from the Commonwealth. The matter has been set down to hear a Dietrich application on 1 December 1997.
Charged with offences against section 229(4) of the Companies (WA) Code (improper use of position)

Refused legal aid by both Legal Aid Western Australia and the Commonwealth. The defendants were committed for trial in 1993 and on 1 June 1995 the prosecution was stayed under the principles in Dietrich by the District Court of Western Australia.
Charged with 65 counts of stealing and 23 counts of fraud, under the Criminal Code (WA)

This matter was investigated by both the Australian Securities Commission and the WA Police. Legal Aid was refused by Legal Aid Western Australia and by the Commonwealth. On 19 May 1997 the District Court of Western Australia confirmed the matter be stayed on the Dietrich principles. The Commonwealth DPP has now referred the matter to the WA DPP to prosecute in an attempt to resolve the impasse.
Charged with offences against the Companies (SA) Code and the Criminal Law Consolidation Act (SA)

Refused legal aid by Legal Aid Commission of South Australia. The prosecution was stayed on 29 August 1997 by the South Australian Court of Criminal Appeal on the principles in Dietrich . Commonwealth DPP has requested that Fuller and Cummings reapply for legal aid under the new Commonwealth legal aid guidelines.
Charged with various Companies Code and State Criminal Law Consolidation Act (SA) offences

Awaiting extradition from the United Kingdom. The defendant has argued in the course of his extradition proceedings that the lack of legal aid funding for Fuller and Cummings (who are co‐accused) would be applicable to him and that therefore extradition should not be ordered.
Charged with offences contrary to sections 1317FA and 232(6) Corporations Law (improper use of position)

Awaiting trial before the District Court of South Australia. Matter set down for three days commencing on 10 December 1997 for a Dietrich application following refusal of legal aid funding. It is not clear why legal aid has been refused.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to the above matters a number of Commonwealth prosecutions relating to serious offences were delayed in the first half of this year as a result of the imposition of restrictive policies by the State Legal Aid Commissions. These policies included the imposition of expenditure caps to legal aid funding of trials which prevented the funding of lengthy drug importation trials. In addition, in New South Wales a policy operated preventing the legal aid funding of re‐trials following the failure of a trial due to a hung jury. This policy delayed the prosecution of a number of defendants for offences relating to the importation of illegal drugs.

As a result of the commencement of the new Commonwealth and State and Territory Agreements in Relation to the Provision of Legal Assistance in Commonwealth matters the above difficulties in relation to the Legal Aid Commissions' policies are being addressed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October I advised the Senate that a Savage Garden CD had been purchased in New Zealand during the previous week for a price equivalent to $A18.90. This figure was identified and provided to me by a member of my staff who informed me that it was based on the purchase of the CD in a leading New Zealand store for a price which had been converted at the prevailing exchange rate to the above figure. On 30 October I was asked about the facts and circumstances of the New Zealand purchase. On the basis of the material avail able to me at that time, I reiterated my belief that the earlier figure was correct. I subsequently asked my staff to check the matter thoroughly and I was again informed that the information made available to me was accurate.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not until Wednesday last week, in the course of preparing for the estimates committee process, that I was provided with material that indicated that there were competing exchange rates that could have been applied on 20 October rather than 13 October when the CD was purchased in New Zealand. I then caused further inquiries to be made on Thursday and Friday last week. I have now satisfied myself to the extent that there is a discrepancy between the exchange rate provided to me by my staff member after his discussion with one of the leading newsagencies and the Reuters daily report on the average of the bid and ask rates. The latter is to be preferred.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I acknowledge that the minister has come in and indicated to the Senate that he mislead the parliament, but I wonder if he was not required under the government's code of ministerial responsibility to do that at an earlier stage—namely, as soon as the parliament reconvened this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have managed to get some further information for Senator Lees in response to her question regarding climate change research as it relates to El Nino. I can advise the Senate that a three‐year CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorological Research Centre study on El Nino, southern oscillation and global warming, with funding support from my department, was recently completed. The study looked at possible changes in the El Nino cycle which could occur under climate change. Results of that project indicate that El Nino events are likely to remain a feature of the climate and the global warming conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The study also found that El Nino cycles may become shorter—that is, El Nino droughts may occur more frequently. La Nina flooding may also be more frequent and the normal periods in between may become shorter. These results, however, are very preliminary. Scientists are as yet uncertain of the potential impacts of greenhouse warming on El Nino. Although there does appear to be a consensus that it is likely to have some effect on ENSO, more research is necessary, particularly on model validation and more realistic modelling of scenarios—that is, transient runs of models rather than sudden doubling of CO2 levels. The CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology are continuing to undertake El Nino southern oscillation and relevant climate modelling research as part of their ongoing climate research programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to questions without notice asked by Senators Forshaw and Neal today, relating to Therapeutic Group Premium strategy.

It was illustrative of Minister Herron's total lack of knowledge of what is happening in the portfolio he represents in this chamber on behalf of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) that he said that he could not be expected to know the answer to my reference to the estimates last week because he was not there. As you will recall, Madam Deputy President, on Friday last week when therapeutic group premiums were dealt with in the Senate estimates, Senator Herron was sitting at the table. At one point there was even a reference made in the Hansard to the fact that the minister was there and might like to comment. Unfortunately, he did not respond at that time.

What we have seen today, once again, is a total failure by this minister to address some very real and serious issues with respect to this government's policy on health. If they have a disaster on their hands in terms of their policy on nursing homes, which is now in tatters, then it appears, unfortunately for the people of Australia, that a disaster is looming with respect to this policy on therapeutic group premiums.

The minister cannot tell us how many people will be affected. That is a terrible admission for him to have to make because this is a budget measure. It is going to produce substantial savings, according to the government, in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It is going to be implemented by regulation changes which are not disallowable and the minister, Mr Wooldridge, is actually quite proud of that. He has stood up publicly and said he can do this notwithstanding what the views of the parliament might be, nor the fact that reputable bodies like the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association have estimated that around a million and a half to two million people could be affected by these changes. This minister cannot give us any information at all. One wonders how they base their calculations in the budget if they do not know.

What is more important, however, is that they should know because this policy is going to come into effect from 1 February next year. From 1 February, many patients who happen to be on drug treatments for such complaints as hypertension, cardiovascular disease, high cholesterol—the five groups that are involved in this proposal—may well find themselves in a position where the drug that they have been taking for some time is in the higher priced category and it will no longer be subsidised under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This government, notwithstanding the fact that this policy is to come into effect from 1 February next year, still has not finalised the prices to be charged for those drugs.

BREAK.PARA: Evidence was given at the estimates hearing that they are still in the processes of sorting that out. They said to us at estimates last Friday that some time in December they are going to start a publicity campaign, and they are going to contact doctors and give them the information about this new scheme to come in on 1 February. As you yourself said, Madam President, and I well recall your comments, `They are going to do this during the silly season.' A euphemism of course for the fact that many people are going to be on holidays over the Christmas‐New Year period. Indeed, many doctors could well be on holidays, and traditionally have locums in.

During this period the doctors are supposed to consult with their patients who are on these drugs and work out whether it is appropriate for them to be transferred to the cheaper drug within the group or whether they should be required to stay on the brand name that they are on. The doctor then has to write a letter to the Health Insurance Commission seeking an exemption. All of this is going to have to be done between some time in December—we still do not know what date—and 1 February. The minister cannot tell us, but certainly the experts are saying that there could well be up to two million in this country who will be affected by these changes on 1 February.

What have we got? We have a minister who cannot give us an answer. The people who are suffering these complaints, the medical profession and the manufacturers are entitled to know what is in store. This is a disastrous policy and should be stopped. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hard to believe in the Senate that we have the opposition coming in here day after day after day just terrorising individuals and groups of people. We have gone on for months now with the lie campaign being generated by the opposition about aged care. We now have the opposition coming in here and generating a fear and lie campaign about therapeutic good premiums. This is just not good enough. When is this mob going to learn?

SPEECH.PARA: But not only that, we had a situation whereby the circumstances that prevailed, that led to the policy difference for aged care, were generated by the Labor government. What has happened with therapeutic good premiums? This change is following previous Labor government initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—I ask for that to be withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Forshaw, would you please withdraw.

—I am happy to withdraw, but I ask, Madam President, will the honourable senator withdraw the statement that she made at the outset of her comments, which was that the opposition had lied about the nursing homes policy? If I am required to withdraw that comment, then so should the senator.
—It was not an individual reflection.
—Thank you very much, Madam Deputy President, and I will repeat what I said about the opposition lie campaign because that is—
—Senator Knowles, I do not think that you need to make this any worse. I will have to ask you to withdraw, please.

—There is no other way to describe what is going on here. The government's decision to introduce therapeutic group premiums simply refines the previous government's concept of price premiums beyond individual brands of drugs with identical chemical make‐up.
—They're not generic drugs, you dope. Tell the truth!

—Senator Forshaw would not have a clue what a bottle of pills looks like, other than the ones that he should be taking right this very instant, and the ones that Senator Cook should have taken the other day before he exploded, because the situation is that this policy does reflect previous government policy. The policy had long support from those opposite. Let me just quote the member for Dobell in 1990 when he said:

BREAK.PARA: Doctors should be trained to prescribe a family of drugs and not a particular brand.

Why has this little cabal over here, that have gone through this time and time again, wanted to come in here yet again today and distort the facts even further—because this is what was dredged through last week at estimates, quite rightly. It was dredged through and the answers were given. The reality is that the government cannot keep adding new drugs to the PBS unless it generates some offsetting in savings, and that is exactly what the previous government initiated. It will mean at the end of the day that consumers will continue to have access to the broadest possible range of the latest and most effective medicines.

What disturbs me is the fact that those opposite just continually come in here or go to estimates and become abusive in the extreme about the way in which they handle these issues. For the majority of people, there will be no need to change drugs as the current drug will be at the benchmark level. Why don't they talk about that? Why don't they talk about that aspect of their own policy that ensured that that was the case, because that is certainly the case with this particular policy.

Furthermore, for most people a switch to another product in the group will make no difference whatsoever to their health outcomes and need not have any financial impact on them at all. That is not the message they are giving. The message they are giving at the moment is that everyone will suffer, everyone will be up for $18, $20 or $25 a month extra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty dollars.

—We now have a higher bid—$30. Is there any advance on $30? These dills are pushing the price up the whole time when the average brand premium under the minimum pricing policy is $1.70, not $30 as Senator Neal has just said. We might add that similar price arrangements are in place in several overseas countries such as New Zealand, Canada, Germany and the Netherlands. What makes this country so different? Yet we have Senator Forshaw who simply says, `We cannot bring this in. We cannot do it over Christmas because doctors and locums are stupid and they will not be able to get the information. I object to the doctors being called stupid. They can get the information. They can pass it on to their patients and make sure that the information is conveyed.

—Madam Deputy President, on a point of order: I know Senator Knowles thinks she is a great debater, but one of the oldest debating tricks in the world is to make a statement and claim that someone else said it.
—Have you got anything to say?
—Senator Knowles, I am trying to hear a point of order. It is not helped by interjections.
—At no stage in my remarks did I at any time call doctors or locums stupid. What I actually said was that this was during a time when many people were on holidays.
—Blow a fuse. Go on.
—Senator Knowles, can I have some order please or I will blow a fuse.
—You have done that plenty of times too.
—Excuse me, Senator Knowles. We will have a bit of order here, thank you. Senator Forshaw, at this stage there is no point of order.
—I rest my case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am a little concerned about the debate degenerating into personal abuse rather than the issue. I will certainly contain myself to the extent that I am dealing with the matter in principle and not the personalities involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that for many years when I have had occasion to visit overseas I have had the opportunity of making a comparison between what the position is in Australia and what it is overseas. I was often distressed to see that, even though there were drugs available that were effective in dealing with fairly mundane, run of the mill diseases, people were often dying for lack of things such as antibiotics and quite basic pharmaceuticals.

BREAK.PARA: In making that comparison I often thought to myself how lucky we were in Australia that people could still afford to have the safest and most effective drug, despite the fact that they may not be particularly well off, they may be elderly, frail or poor. In Australia we made a decision that it was our priority to provide the safest and most effective drug. I suppose that is what worries me about this whole proposition, this new drugs tax, the therapeutic groups premium: we are now saying to people that you can no longer have the safest and most effective drug. If you want the safest and most effective drug in every case, then you are going to have to pay extra.

We had some discussion earlier about how much extra. The figure that is being proposed by the opposition is not some figure that has been plucked out of the air. The figure of $30 was put to us by people who I would have thought would well know, that is, the AMA, a group that represents the vast majority of medical practitioners in Australia. It is not some scare technique, some figure used to frighten people. The figure was put to us by people who deal with the prescribing of drugs all the time and, I believe, are very likely to be correct.

It is not only the problem that this is not a very good policy decision, an unfair policy decision, but also the problem that this government is making the situation even worse by not telling people what is about to occur. They have not told the pharmacists, the medical providers or the community at large. They have not told about a quarter of people who receive prescriptions. In many cases the way they deal with their prescription will fundamentally change as of 1 February.

I was a little astonished, as was Senator Forshaw, by Senator Herron's statement when he said that he would not know about this because he was not there. The Hansard shows that during the questioning in estimates on this issue Senator Herron was the minister who attended. During questioning on the issue, the members of the department who did provide the information—Senator Heron did not answer the questions; he was obviously concentrating on something else—said that the advisory committee that had recently started meeting would not be providing information before December. It was not clear whether it would be beginning of December or the end of December.

I have the very firm view, and I believe a lot of people in the community would have the firm view, that to make such a fundamental change to the way the pharmaceutical benefits scheme operates and not provide any information some 60 days before the scheme is to take effect is really quite extraordinary. I suppose what is even more extraordinary is that members of the government who are responsible for this scheme, this major change, do not seem to be the least concerned.

The fact is that the drugs that people will have to make use of under this new scheme are not the most effective. They are not the drugs that have the least potential side effects. It has very much been the policy under the pharmaceutical benefit scheme since 1993 that a drug can only have a higher fee attached to it if it is shown to have some greater beneficial effect—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Eggleston, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that all of us here have motorcars and we all go down to the petrol station to fill them up with petrol. One of the remarkable things about cars and petrol is that it does not matter if you fill it up with Shell, Ampol or BP, the car still runs in exactly the same way. The common ingredient in all those brands is the petrol, the gasoline. What we are talking about here with the therapeutic groups premium is exactly the same thing in principle. Therapeutic goods, or drugs, all contain a chemical. The chemical, like petrol, comes under different names because different companies market that chemical and call it something else.
—Try putting super in an unleaded car and see what happens!

—There is a difference between super and ordinary petrol, Senator Forshaw, in that it has a higher octane level. You pay a premium for higher octane just as you do if you buy a drug like an ace inhibitor, for example, or one of the other anti-depressants on this list which has a higher dosage. If you buy a higher dosage petrol, you pay more for it. If you buy a higher dosage drug, you pay more for it. The point is the same.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, you are buying a chemical and the drug companies are asking you to pay a premium for the name of the company. The argument of the drug companies is that the extra price premium covers the cost of basic research into these medications, but the truth is that very little, if any, basic research into the production of pharmaceuticals is done in Australia. Most of it is done overseas in Europe and North America. These drug companies are large multinational corporations who have vast incomes and who are just putting a price premium on their drugs in Australia in order to generate a little bit of extra income without really having any rationale for doing it. If these companies actually did research in Australia, that would be a different matter, but it does not happen that way.

As I have said, essentially all drugs contain the same chemical, and it is quite reasonable for the government to say that the price for a unit of some particular chemical should be the same regardless of the brand name. The government in fact expects that significant savings of some $560 million will be generated by this measure over four years. This will be of great benefit to the Australian health system because it will mean that more money will be available for other purposes.

Senator Knowles has made the point that similar pricing arrangements are available or are in place in several overseas countries such as New Zealand, Canada, Germany and the Netherlands. One of the important things to understand is that this new pricing policy does not mean that the entry of new drugs onto the market will be restricted. In fact, there will be no change at all and Australia will still benefit from new drugs as they are developed around the world. It does not mean any reduction in the investment by drug companies because drug companies make investments for a wide variety of reasons, and I am quite sure that the international drug companies that operate in Australia will continue to do so under this policy.

BREAK.PARA: The federal government has introduced the therapeutic group premium strategy to help put the brakes on the runaway cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In 1996-97, the pharmaceutical benefits scheme cost taxpayers about $2.5 billion, which is $1 billion more than it cost four years ago.

In conclusion, I come back to Senator Neal's remarks and assure her that the Australian public will still have access to safe, effective drugs. There will be no danger to the public, and Australia will continue to have one of the best subsidised pharmaceutical benefits schemes in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take note of the answer given about the therapeutic group premium strategy. This scheme appears to be nothing more than a money saving exercise. Again, the pensioners and low income groups will be hardest hit. Under this scheme, the government will only pay for the cheapest drugs in the group. The government's own advice on this matter is that within the groups some drugs are safer and more effective than others. Does this mean that only those who are more financially secure will have access to the safer, more effective drugs within their given group? Mr Rod Unsworth, the Chairman of the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said in a statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The measure due to come into effect in February hits the aged, the chronically ill and the poor particularly hard by stripping away part of the PBS subsidy for many medicines. This is another swipe at the elderly. The federal government has obviously been poorly advised about the consequences of this policy. It has chosen to ignore submissions by doctors and patient groups and eminent clinicians who have condemned the policy as likely to result in health and financial problems for many patients, including the elderly . . .

From that quote, I would suggest that maybe there should have been more consultation with the groups of doctors and pharmacists who are the people responsible for helping to implement this policy. Further, the President of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, Dr Peter Joseph, warned of potential medical problems and increased costs due to this measure.

BREAK.PARA: Other problems that have been identified in similar reforms in other countries include confusion about new medications and non-compliance with therapy. The findings of the international reference pricing study, for example, that was provided by the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association to the government would appear to have been ignored. The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the AMA are examples of bodies that are concerned that individual needs are being ignored, and they are also concerned by the lack of consultation.

Based on scientific evidence, some medications are superior to others. Some medications possess benefits beyond the original purpose for which they were first prescribed. Such benefits could be lost under the scheme to those individuals who cannot afford the additional costs.

There has been a study done in New Hampshire in the United States which says that restrictions on the number of drugs prescribed for patients treated for schizophrenia reduce drug volumes by 35 per cent but increase admissions to nursing homes by more than 50 per cent. The additional costs for hospitalisation, emergency mental health care and additional clinic visits are roughly nine times the saving from volume control on drugs. So it sounds to me as though this measure in the short term will save money, but perhaps in the long term will increase costs in other areas. It seems to me that that is very short‐sighted.

One of the other concerns I have is that, during the nursing home debate, we had people who were potential clients of nursing homes phone our office to see whether, if they paid to go into nursing homes, they would have the same food as people who did not pay to go into nursing homes. Again, that was setting up a distinction between the elderly themselves. I am afraid that this measure may well do the same thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the wider public's concern about their perceived deprivation of access to drugs, and I understand that the opposition is peddling a policy of fear among the elderly in particular. The elderly, of course, are the most vulnerable in our society, apart from the very young.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not the government's intention to deny access of therapeutic group drugs to the elderly—or to anyone else for that matter; it was about getting the best value for the taxpayer's dollar. Senator Denman said that money saving is the exercise. It cannot be denied that money saving is part of the exercise, but it is not the exercise. The exercise is to deliver a cost‐effective therapeutic drug group to as many people as practicable for the cheapest possible price.

It must be remembered that most of the drugs that are dispensed within the Commonwealth come, significantly, from Switzerland, the United Kingdom or North America, and very few find their origins of ownership in Australia. I think that shielding people from information about health costs—or any other costs, for that matter, that the government is associated with—is wrong, and it is not the government's intention to hide behind that shield. This is an up‐front process and a process that rightly ought to be debated—and debated it is.
In 1990, for instance, the then member for Dobell said:
Doctors should be trained to prescribe a family of drugs and not a particular brand.

This government, and I, of course, agree with that statement. If a particular drug from a family should be prescribed, it is often cheaper than a brand name drug and is equally as good in its effect as the brand name drug. It was the aim of the government to significantly target that area for money savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Generics.

If they are using a higher priced drug within one of the six therapeutic groups, they should—as I am advised—ask their doctor if they can change to what has been called the benchmark priced drug.

SPEECH.PARA: Claims that introducing the therapeutic group will result in costs to patients of up to $18 or more each month are entirely misplaced and misleading, and add to the scare tactics that the opposition, I am rather ashamed to say, has resorted to—and not just with this particular subject either. The premiums are not simply a subtraction of the price of the cheapest drug dosage from that of the most expensive in the therapeutic group; the premiums are calculated as the average cost of the drug across all dosage forms. The entry of new drugs into the market will not be restricted. Since 1996, 134 new products have been listed. Most are currently under consideration, and prices of innovative drugs listed in recent years in Australia are close to average European Union prices. There will be no deleterious effect of the government's initiative of introducing the therapeutic group premium scheme.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
