PARA.EMPHASIS: STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 SPRING SITTINGS
FARM HOUSEHOLD SUPPORT AMENDMENT (RESTART AND EXCEPTIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES) BILL 1997

The purpose of the bill is to amend the Farm Household Support Act 1992 to provide for the introduction of two farm family welfare schemes. These welfare proposals are integral to the Integrated Rural Policy Package (IRPP) which has been developed following the Budget process.

The proposed amendments provide for the introduction of a Farm Family Restart Scheme which aims to provide income support to farm families who have been denied commercial finance. The income support would be equivalent to the current Department of Social Security (DSS) NewStart allowance, subject to income and off farm asset tests, but would have no activity test requirement. The Restart Allowance would be provided for a maximum of one year. During this time the farm family would be provided with access to professional business and career advice. There would be an obligation, to continue eligibility for income support, for the recipients to take up the professional advice provided.

The second amendment would modify the existing Drought Relief Payment Scheme (DRP) by introducing an Exceptional Circumstances Relief Payment to address the needs of farmers in areas experiencing exceptionally difficult business conditions, triggered by a combination of events including climatic and economic circumstances eg. insufficient rainfall, pasture damage, frost damage, heavy rainfall etc. and will follow the provisions of the existing Drought Relief Payment.

The early establishment of the schemes will provide a welfare safety net for those farmers coming off DRP. The cessation dates for DRP are not uniform and the next cessation date for some farmers will be, with the proposed extension, 1 December 1997.
The Australian farm sector has been badly damaged by a decade of drought which has undermined the farm sector's capacity to recover and remain independent of Government income support requirements.
Effect if the Bill is not passed this sitting

If the amendments to provide a farm welfare safety net is not passed in this sitting it may be necessary to consider further extensions to the Drought Relief Payments (DRP) to assist farmers in financial difficulty. The extension of the DRP is a high cost ad hoc approach to drought relief and does not assist in recognising the welfare needs of farm families.

The amendments are part of a reform package for rural Australia which has been developed over the previous four months. The need to expedite the introduction of the farm family welfare safety net element has occurred as a result of the worsening drought across much of Australia.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 SPRING SITTINGS
MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION APPLICATION CHARGE BILL MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION RENEWAL CHARGE BILL 1997

The proposed Bills will provide a broad range of powers relating to the regulation of migration agents. These powers will reside with the Minister who may delegate them to a person or office within the Migration Institute of Australia (MIA). Delegation to the MIA is a transitional step towards voluntary self regulation.
The Bills will also impose charges on applicants for registration, and for renewal of registration, as migration agents. These charges are currently imposed in the form of levies.

Subsection 333(1) of the Migration Act 1958 contains a statutory sunset provision which will automatically terminate the existing scheme for regulation of the migration advice industry on 21 March 1998.
Introduction and passage in the one Sittings is sought to enable the new scheme to be in place by 21 March 1998.
Effect if Bill is not dealt with in one Sittings
Legal advice indicates that it will not be possible to revive the existing scheme for regulating the migration advice industry if the sunset clause comes into effect.

The result of this is that it may be necessary to refund substantial sums which have been paid as migration agent registration fees. In addition visa applicants would have no specialist consumer protection from unscrupulous and/or incompetent migration agents.
(Circulated with the authority of the Minister for immigration and Multicultural Affairs.)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR THE INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY BILL 1997
AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK INDUSTRY (REPEALS AND
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (BUFFALO SLAUGHTER) LEVY BILL 1997
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (CATTLE EXPORT) LEVY BILL 1997
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (SHEEP, LAMBS AND GOATS
NATIONAL RESIDUE SURVEY (SHEEP, LAMBS AND GOATS

The proposed package of Bills implements critical industry reform to provide effective industry self determination through a move from a statutory management basis to cooperative sectoral participation based on the Corporations Law. The Bills clearly delineate sectoral ownership of existing industry levies.

The meat and live-stock industry has been particularly and adversely affected by recent international market developments, by drought, and by food safety questions. It has also long been recognised that structural deficiencies in the meat processing area have disadvantaged Australian product internationally. The need for competition policy implementation and regulatory reform is also well accepted.

The Government endorsed the package of reforms following extensive consultation. These reforms are clearly based on Government's policies on Competition, Regulatory Rationalisation, and reform of Government's role in industry operations. Now that Government and industry have determined key reform initiatives, it is essential that critical legislative aspects be given the highest priority. There is a clear expectation throughout industry that the reform legislation will be determined by the end of 1997.

Both industry and the Commonwealth will benefit from expeditious implementation. There are implications for industry participants relating principally to increased more direct representation, together with anticipated reduced industry outlays and more responsive leadership.

The current Meat and Live-stock Industry Act 1995 has a sunset date of 30 June 1998. These Bills replace that Act, but the nature of the reforms requires extensive industry based development of replacement organisations and mechanisms prior to proclamation. These reforms will not detrimentally impact on individual businesses.

Delay could have adverse financial and operational impacts on industry, and there is a strong impera tive to provide timely reform changes in a single package. All sectors of industry have been given a considerable task with regard to the reforms, which are based on significantly increased self determination and management. The Bills will minimise difficulties for industry in meeting these challenges.

The real need for reform of the industry has been identified over a number of years in various reports. Now that impetus for such reform has been developed, and a clear reform path set, further delay would be particularly disruptive to industry especially in the present difficult market situation.
(Circulated with the Authority of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 SPRING SITTINGS
The purpose of this bill is to give effect to a package of measures to protect the beneficial purpose of the Defence Service Homes Act 1918.

The primary measures in this bill reform the interest rate mechanisms applying to Defence Service Home (DSH) loans. A major feature is the introduction of a guaranteed minimum subsidy of 1.5 percentage points below the average standard variable home loan rate.

Continued falling market interest rates has resulted in some DSH loan borrowers now paying a higher interest rate on their "concessional" DSH loan than they could obtain in the general market. This situation is untenable. The bill will restore the value of the DSH loan as a compensatory benefit to certain men and women who have served Australia in either wartime or peacetime.

The introduction and passage of this bill in the Spring 1997 sittings will ensure the beneficial nature of the DSH loans is restored without further delay. If the Bill to give effect to these measures cannot be dealt with during the current sittings, then the integrity of the DSH loan scheme is at risk.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills amend the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to modify part of the Commonwealth's safety net to protect State and Territory revenues following the decision of the High Court in the cases of Ngo Ngo Ha v State of New South Wales and Walter Hammond and Associates P/L v State of New South Wales. Part of this safety net required increases in customs and excise duties of $167 per kilogram on tobacco and tobacco products, with effect from 7 August 1997.

At the time these increases were implemented, the Commonwealth Government was aware of the effect that changing from a value-based franchise fees system to a weight based system would have on the tobacco industry. For example, some manufacturers produce cigarettes which weigh less than others and the duty rates calculated by weight has the potential to advantage some manufacturers over others. The Commonwealth held discussions with the industry and reached an agreement to implement arrangements which will ensure that the effect of the safety net on the manufacturers of the different tobacco products is as close as possible to effect of the business franchise fees which applied prior to the High Court decision. All of the States and Territories have requested the Commonwealth to implement these new arrangements.
The new arrangements involve the replacement of the safety net element of the weight based duty rates with the options of:
a hybrid rate, based on a combination of a weight based rate per kilogram and 50.32% of the wholesale list price of a particular product when the wholesale list price is gazetted; or
a solely weight based duty rate only where no wholesale list price has been determined.

The new method of calculating the customs and excise duty rates on these products was implemented immediately by the publication of notices in the Commonwealth Gazette in accordance with section 273EA of the Customs Act 1901 and section 160B of the Excise Act 1901. These notices were published on 16 September 1997 and took effect from 17 September 1997.
These Bills will formally incorporate these changes into the Customs Tariff Act 1995 and the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

Introduction and passage during the 1997 Spring sittings is desirable as the early passage of this package of legislation will continue to provide certainty in Commonwealth/State relations in respect of this issue.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, the Hon Warren Truss, MP)
STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1997 SPRING SITTINGS
NATIVE TITLE AMENDMENT BILL 1997

Upon election, amending the Native Title Act 1993 to make it workable was one of the government's top priorities. After a period of consultation the Native Title Amendment Bill 1996 was introduced into the Parliament in June and further amendments were released as an exposure draft in October 1996. The proposed amendments were the subject of two reports of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, released in November and December 1996.

Before the amendments were debated, the Wik decision was handed down by the High Court on 23 December 1996. The decision held that native title was capable of coexisting on pastoral leases, reversing a widely held presumption when the Act was passed in 1993. The Wik decision has led to intense public debate and uncertainty in rural areas about what activities pastoralists can currently perform on their leases. There are real difficulties with proceeding with pastoral business in some jurisdictions and consequent pressures on the government to provide certainty for government granted interests on all forms of tenure where native title coexistence is possible.

The Treasury and resources and farming/pastoral industry associations have indicated that there is a need for a response as soon as possible to the issues raised by the Wik decision. If not, uncertainty may reduce and delay investment in mining, petroleum and rural industries and, consequently, slow the rate of economic growth.
(Circulated by authority of the Prime Minister, the Hon John Howard, MP)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Retirement Savings Accounts Regulations (Amendment) Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (Amendment)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Sherry and pursuant to standing order 78(2) I give notice that, when business is called on this afternoon, I intend to withdraw business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in the name of Senator Sherry relating to the disallowance of certain superannuation regulations. I seek leave to have a short statement about the notice of intention to withdraw incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Labor will be withdrawing the disallowance motion moved by Senator Sherry on 25 September 1997 after successful good-faith negotiations with the government to change the regulations for accessing superannuation before preservation age in certain circumstances.

I understand that later today, the Assistant Treasurer will circulate a press release announcing that the government will introduce the proposed new regulations into the Senate at the earliest available opportunity. The new regulations will amend the existing regulations and will apply from 1 July 1997.

We believe that the changes agreed to by Labor and the government will bring fairness to the early release of superannuation arrangements while still allowing the government to achieve its policy objectives.
Under the agreement with the government, the proposed new regulations will allow the early release of superannuation in the following circumstances:
. where persons with accounts of less than $200 change employers

. Australian citizens, permanent residents and expatiates who had planned to leave Australia but were caught out by the short time period between the government's announced changes and the date of the new rules, will have a transitional period ending on 30 June 1998 with which to apply for their superannuation funds and to have left Australia; and

. for those people suffering from severe financial hardship, Labor has negotiated with the government to reduce the `objective' test of receipt of a Commonwealth income support payment from 12 months for under 55's to 6 months continuously:

‐ That means people who are under 55, have been in receipt of an income support payment for 6 months or more and are in severe financial difficulty will be able to apply to their Superannuation fund trustees for the release of small amounts of their superannuation savings. Subject to the rules of their superannuation fund, the trustees will be able to release monies if they are satisfied that the applicant is suffering from severe financial hardship.

In addition, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will have a discretion to grant the early release of superannuation in individual cases which are consistent with the specific compassionate grounds provisions.

Under the government's original regulations, low and middle income earners suffering from severe financial hardship have had to wait a minimum of 12 months before they could access small amounts of their superannuation fund.

Now, thanks to Labor, families suffering from severe financial hardship will be able to access small amounts of their superannuation savings within a reasonable time frame, subject to the rules of their superannuation fund.
In addition, the transitional period up to 30 June 1998 applying to people leaving Australia will allow those planning to permanently leave Australia to adjust their plans accordingly.

Labor's agreement with the government was broadly in line with what Labor Senators recommended in the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation report into the early release of superannuation regulations.

Labor would have preferred a 3 month period before being able to apply for the release of funds and for the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to administer the severe financial hardship test rather than fund trustees.

However, we believe that the new regulations will achieve a better balance between preserving superannuation savings for retirement and allowing fair access to small amounts of superannuation savings in times of severe financial hardship.

This is the first time since the government won office that we have actually reached a negotiated agreement on superannuation issues. Negotiated outcomes are certainly a better way of dealing with our differences.

But the minute we seek to do something as far as managing times is concerned, we ring all senators, including Senator Carr as the Manager of Opposition Business—and the leader, where required.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts, we ring Senator Brown's office, your office, Senator Harradine's office, Senator Colston's—when he was here—and the Democrats' offices. I was aware that my office, as soon as these decisions had been made—and they are only government decisions; we come here to seek agreement to do them—we advise your office. I know that your office was rung within about 30 seconds of the decision being made, because we rang you first to give you that information. The reason we rang you first is that most of the other senators were probably more closely aware, because the discussions between chairmen of the estimates committees and deputy chairmen took place as those estimates were unrolling.

As you correctly assumed, Senator Brown and Senator Margetts, we had put the Friday in as a scheduled spill‐over day so that committees were scheduled to sit on the Wednesday and Thursday last week and to have a scheduled spill‐over day on the Friday. We thought we had scheduled enough time with those three days to achieve estimates—and with most of the committees we got there. There is only one committee that needs a serious amount of time, and then two other committees need more time. But we had always agreed informally—and I stress informally—that if there was going to be more time required then we would substitute a sitting day, that, is Thursday, for the extra time for estimates.

The government, for the reasons that Senator Brown has articulated, was always reluctant to lose that Thursday because we needed as many hours as possible this week to ensure that our legislative program, pre the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 , is dealt with this week so that we can make a clean start on native title and have two entire weeks dedicated to debate starting on 24 November. The opposition have suggested a way around trying to make up some of the time we will lose on Thursday and that suggestion is contained in the motion we have passed; that is, that tomorrow and Wednesday, instead of having government documents, the Senate will sit, doing government business, through until 8 p.m. each evening. We will pick up two and a bit hours doing that and will only lose about half an hour of government business because of the decision to do estimates on Thursday.

I indicate formally that the government seeks to commence the native title legislation debate as soon as possible. If we get through this week's program today, we will start native title tomorrow. If we get through it tomorrow, we will start native title on Wednesday. We will start the native title debate as soon as the legislation on the agenda for this week is finalised. They are all bills which we must have before Christmas, as was explained at the leaders and whips meetings last week. It is our intention to have them dealt with this week. It will require the cooperation of all senators when it comes to dealing with the legislation through the committee stage. I seek the cooperation of all senators to get this week's program done this week so that we can start native title when we come back next Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have done tremendously well already today with the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 , Senator Neal. Since I am taking up time which could be eating into the time for the native title bill, I will sit down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present the report of the committee entitled Security at the Adelaide office of the National Crime Authority in 1994 and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to put on the record the concerns that the Australian Democrats have about this particular incident, which is reported on by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority in its report entitled Security at the Adelaide office of the National Crime Authority in 1994 . One of the most serious attacks on a law enforcement agency in this nation's history occurred in our home state of South Australia, Madam Acting Deputy President, on 2 March 1994. The bombing killed Geoffrey Bowen and maimed Peter Wallis. May I extend the sympathies of the Senate and my party to Peter Wallis and both of their families.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the fact that this happened more than three years ago, there has been no successful prosecution of this crime and many questions remain unanswered. This is not good enough from the perspective of our law enforcement agencies. It is the role of the parliament and our responsibility to make sure we get to the bottom of this particular incident. In a significant piece of journalism by Jamie Walker in the Australian on 11 October this year, it was noted:
Contrary to the impression senior police and NCA figures sought to convey, the security infrastructure at the Adelaide office was grossly inadequate.

The article also reported that specific purpose built electronic monitors to vet incoming mail were not installed, despite repeated recommendations, because of the cost. The hand held scanners—they are of the type used in airport security and are designed to detect guns rather than bombs—apparently were the only scanning devices used in the South Australian office. If this is the case, it is contemptible.
The report before us sets out a very serious admission by the National Crime Authority, and a matter that must be taken seriously by the parliament. This report states:
21. The Committee is reporting to the Parliament its concern about the failure of the NCA to provide it with a fully reliable explanation of the state of security prior to the bombing.
22. It is also a matter of concern that the revised advice was only prompted by revelations in the media, which suggests that there are recording or reporting problems in the NCA's Adelaide office.

I understand that security has since been beefed up on NCA recommendations. I understand all mail is now X-rayed and other measures are in place to protect these agencies from harm. If this is not the case, something must be done to bring these protective measures up to standard.

I note that the Democrats have now raised these concerns on a number of occasions. We believe that those people who are in positions of authority and who are charged with the responsibility of protecting others are entitled to the maximum level of physical security available. The lives of those in public service are valuable—like all other lives—and we must learn the lessons of this particular tragedy to make sure that nothing like it ever happens again.

Perhaps equally concerning is the spectre of what other information provided to the committee has perhaps been omitted or coloured. This experience is unacceptable, and the committee is well placed to get some overdue answers. I would hope the committee will reassess the information which has been provided to it to make sure it has all the available material to make its assessments according to its terms of reference and the duties of the committee.

The other matter this report raises concerns the coroner's inquest. After three years, the South Australian coroner's office has not convened an inquest into this tragedy, because the police investigation has not been finalised. I understand this is standard practice in my home state of South Australia. However, given the lack of prosecution after this time—and it is over three years ago—we should be seeking answers as to why the coroner's inquest has not started. This investigation is central to resolving this tragedy and learning the lessons so that this never happens again.

I look forward to a constructive resolution to the committee's investigation into the details of the NCA's potential misleading of the committee, as well as a determination of the other material provided to the committee upon which assessments have perhaps been wrongly made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make some remarks about the tabling of the Auditor‐General's report on the third tranche of the Commonwealth Bank sale.
—Is leave granted?
—We have not been approached about this and we are running a bit behind on the schedule. I would like to know how long Senator Allison wishes to speak on this particular matter.
—My estimation is about five minutes.
—No more than five minutes.

—Audit report No. 13 of 1997‐98 is a very disappointing report by the Auditor-General. The Commonwealth received its final instalment receipt on Friday, the final $6 of its $10.45 sale price set in July 1996, yet as at Friday the Commonwealth Bank shares were trading at $17.20 per share. If as at Friday when the Commonwealth received its final instalment on the bank shares the new shareholders had paid market value, the Commonwealth today would be $2.8 billion better off. To put it more simply: the Commonwealth Bank was sold for $2.8 billion less than it was worth, which means that 17 million taxpayers in Australia are worse off and 354,000 shareholders will be better off to the tune of $2.8 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: The sale of the Commonwealth Bank was a case of bad timing, and this audit report concedes that point. A few months before the float, Commonwealth Bank shares were trading at 16 per cent higher than they were when the float occurred; six months later they were trading about 40 per cent higher; and now they are over 60 per cent higher. But when the float occurred it was a time of market uncertainty and, instead of pulling the float, the government proceeded and all of us have been left worse off by several billion dollars.

According to the Auditor‐General, the government achieved its twin objectives, which are described as, firstly, having achieved an optimum financial return from the sale, with appropriately balanced regard for the interests of the Commonwealth, CBA and present and future CBA shareholders; and, secondly, encouraging an orderly after‐market share for CBA shares. The object of the orderly after market was to keep investor appetite high for future floats. It is a pity that the Auditor‐General did not comment on the appropriateness of those objectives, I would have said, because the Democrats disagree with them vehemently.

In our view, the sale of a public asset should have one objective and one objective only; that is, to ensure that the taxpayer gets full value for the loss of public ownership in the asset. Interests of future shareholders or floats should be disregarded. If we are talking public assets, then the public interest should be paramount. It was clear that this was not the case in the Commonwealth Bank float.

The audit report shows that, notwithstanding the poor market conditions in July 1996, the share price could have been pushed up from $10.45 to $11 and still have been fully subscribed. This would have resulted in an extra $244 million to taxpayers. But the government did not do that and, as a result, $244 million was given away, in effect, and this has since ballooned out to $2.8 billion. The Commonwealth Bank sale was a fiscal disaster for which the financial advisers received almost $70 million—$70 million for selling an asset for $2.8 billion less than it was worth.

The result of the Commonwealth Bank sale was to transfer $2.8 billion in windfall gains from public assets to private purses. It followed the undervaluation of the CSL float and the Qantas sale, and today it has been followed by a $2.6 billion undervaluation of the Telstra share price. It shows that privatisation is very much about benefiting the few at the expense of the majority of Australian taxpayers.

BREAK.XREF: PUBLIC EMPLOYMENT (CONSEQUENTIAL AND TRANSITIONAL) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Previously in this debate I raised the issue of the statement made by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) in the other House. The minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to provide the foundation for a high performance public service while reaffirming its sense of public purpose.

I question what is high performance. I really wonder whether it is economic efficiency or the provision of service that the minister was referring to. For if it is economic efficiency rather than the provision of service, we have a situation where public servants will be placed in a high performance based environment which will have little or no regard for the public needs and, of course, will then place at jeopardy the job security of the public servants as they strive for high performance rather than address, primarily, the needs of the public. I believe this is one of the hidden areas of these public service bills; that is, rather than service to the public being the maxim, we will see high performance and, of course, the public will be the only ones to suffer under those circumstances.

I have a few other issues that I will raise, and they came out in the hearings that took place before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The first one is the issue of the independence of the Public Service. I believe this has to be retained at all costs, such that there is not an erosion of the quality of advice that the government receives. For if we see a situation—as I believe will evolve as result of this bill—that the quality of advice is eroded because the public servants feel at threat in their jobs, then we will see a reduction in the independence of the Public Service, and we will see a diminution of a service that has long served this nation. These bills, unfortunately, do not guarantee this independence. I think this needs to be addressed as we proceed through the stages of these bills.

Another issue that concerns me is the loss of the continuity of corporate knowledge by striving for the flexible employment arrangements as envisaged by the bills. The word `flexible' has many connotations. Invariably, my experience of the word `flexible' has been one more threatening rather than consoling—`flexible' implying lack of security, lack of tenure and lack of any commitment on the part of the employer.

If that happens, we will end up with a loss of the continuity of the corporate knowledge—a vast corporate knowledge—which rests with the public servants who are currently employed. If flexibility becomes the main thrust and driving force behind the Public Service, then we will see people being chopped and changed at the whim of those in power and we will see as a result the loss of the corporate knowledge of the organisation. That can work only to the disadvantage of the public who are served by the Public Service.

The Public Service as an organisation is a seemingly endless repository of knowledge. One cannot expect, with changing personalities within the Public Service and under a flexible arrangement, to have this repository of knowledge retained. We will eventually see the wheel being reinvented every time a situation arises. This is no good for the public and this is no good for the overall efficiency of government and the Public Service.

The JCPA report recognises the need to maintain a degree of stability and the continuity of corporate knowledge. I trust that, in spite of the claims of the government, this can be reinforced and cemented in place to take away the uncertainty that exists with the legislation as I believe it currently exists.
Another issue I want to briefly refer to is the transparency of employment actions. If one looks at page 113 of the JCPA report, one finds recommendation 14, which states:
The Public Service Regulations dealing with review of Australian Public Service employment actions must be redrafted, in a way which is, at least, simple, clear and concise.

I believe that recommendation does not go far enough because it is not just a matter of being simple, clear and concise; it must also be fair and independent, for not to do so will sacrifice transparency. This government says it is about transparency. Here is its opportunity to see that transparency prevails. What we have at stake in this situation is really the credibility of the Public Service. So it is not just a matter of redrafting the employment actions to be simple, clear and concise; they must also be redrafted to be at least fair and independent.

Another issue that I want to speak about briefly is remuneration for agency heads. Whilst the JCPA and, I believe, the government have agreed that the remuneration for agency heads should still be published in the annual financial statements of Commonwealth agencies as envisaged in the recommendation of the JCPA, I believe that the remuneration also needs to be left with the Remuneration Tribunal because there we have a clear and transparent operation, an operation that is subject to public scrutiny and public purview—the very essence of what these bills should be about. So in my view the government really do need to have the remuneration of agency heads not placed elsewhere other than with the Remuneration Tribunal.

The bills the government is pursuing will see, in my estimation, a loss of tenure and job security and a lowering of morale. In my summation, the bills in effect attempt to make the Australian Public Service a compliant and subservient organisation rather than a vibrant and responsible organisation. I understand that the government says that it does not want it to be politicised, but all I can see coming out of these bills is a politicised Public Service, which I do not think will serve any government of whatever persuasion any good in the future.

Whilst there is some agreement that the previous act was in need of review, I do not believe that this review will do anything other than strive for efficiency and lose sight of the fact that the Public Service really should be service orientated and serve the public in a proper and meaningful way. I believe these bills as summed up in part of the report will shun the qualities of people who choose the Public Service as a career. This is the thing that stands the Public Service aside from any other type of business or organisation throughout this nation.

In many senses, these bills do nothing to enhance the Public Service but merely seek to detract from a very credible organisation that has served Australians, the Australian government and the Australian people well over a long time. Whilst the government claims good intent, I believe that most of the good intentions will be misplaced when this legislation finally passes through this chamber unless it is appropriately amended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate to start my remarks today on the Public Service Bill 1997 , the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1997 by acknowledging the fact that the Australian Public Service is a great institution and one that has served Australia very well since the beginnings of federal government in this country. The men and women of the Australian Public Service should be proud to be playing a crucial and integral role in our system of democratic government, a role which they perform admirably, even in the most trying of times. A fact that is often overlooked is that the Australian Public Service is not some cumbersome dinosaur that some on the other side of the chamber would try to have us believe; it is a dynamic and efficient organisation which has served successive governments very well. It is an organisation that has shown a willingness to change and evolve as the country it serves has changed and evolved.

SPEECH.PARA: It has more than fulfilled its essential functions of providing fearless and frank advice to government, delivering services to the wider Australian community and ensuring efficient government administration. These functions have been, and are still, so very important to the development of this nation. They go to the heart of what assists a nation to be a community, to be a civilisation; they go to the heart of accountable and responsible government. The reason Australia enjoys such a professional Public Service is because of the high calibre of those men and women who make a commitment to that service. It is a commitment that I feel is undervalued by the community and completely disregarded by the Liberal government.

It is a complex and important package of bills that the Senate has before it. In fact, the importance may not be fully realised at the moment by the Australian community. These bills have far‐reaching implications obviously and immediately for members of the Australian Public Service but they also have implications for all Australians, particularly those in our community who depend on the services that the government provides.

I believe that these bills and the ideology behind them highlight the dramatic difference between the Australian Labor Party and the coalition.Labor firmly believes that strong and active government leadership with a strong public sector operating in partnership with a thriving private sector best ensures the delivery of both security and opportunity for Australians. Labor believes that government is critical in the achievement of social justice. We see government as a guardian of the common good, not only in achieving social justice but also in securing many public benefits which are unlikely to be delivered by a free market. It is this commitment to good government and an understanding of the important role that government has to play in our society which distinguishes Labor from our opponents.

Like many of my constituents, I approach this package of public and parliamentary service bills with great scepticism. It is with very good reason that we approach these bills this way. The people of Canberra and Australia have been betrayed by this government time after time after time since the coalition was elected last year. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave his word to the people of Canberra. He even put his promises in writing in full‐page ads in the local paper, stating that he would not cut more than 2,500 Public Service positions in his first term as Prime Minister, stating that he would not change the Public Service superannuation scheme and making a whole range of what are now obviously not core promises.

What have we seen happen? We have seen Mr Howard and his slash and burn team sack over 30,000 public servants in under 18 months, over 10,000 of which are here in our local community. We have seen him change the superannuation arrangements for public servants that will see the benefits they receive dramatically reduced. We have seen him show complete contempt for the national capital by not residing in the Prime Minister's official residence, the Lodge. Now this mean spirited and divisive government is lining the Australian Public Service up for its final blow, a plan that will cause instability and derision.

I would think that this government has given all Australians very good reason for being suspicious of the changes that they propose, especially with respect to the Public Service. The government's main argument for the proposed changes contained in these bills is one of simplification. Yet it is most ironic that, while these bills may simplify the Public Service Act, they will complicate the Public Service in the process. These bills are setting up a very complex and confusing mix of regulations, directions and instructions that will vary from department to department. The legislation will create a two‐tier service of executive agencies and core departments. It will create multiple fiefdoms headed by powerful agency heads. This bill, at its core, is against the interests of the employees of the Australian Public Service in its underlying philosophy of all power to agency heads. Agency heads will be given the power to hire and fire at will. Agency heads will be naming their price, a price that will see them become political servants rather than servants of the Australian people.

Perhaps the most frightening thing about this legislation, and the thing which indicated the government's real intentions, was the original proposal to delete the 75-year-old requirement for the Public Service to provide frank, honest, comprehensive and accurate advice to the government of the day. This government espouses all these statements on old values and principles, yet there was a period where they were prepared to place under threat the tradition of Commonwealth public servant giving frank, honest and accurate advice without fear or favour. This, the most important of principles, goes to the very fabric of the Australian democratic system, a principle more important today than ever before.

This matter aside, the overall effect of these and other changes introduced in these bills, despite all the government's assurances and declared intentions, is to create the potential for a Public Service which will be more easily influenced by the government of the day and less willing to offer critical advice. While this government may think that is a positive, it is only a short‐term positive for them, because it is the Australian community and our democratic system which will suffer if the Australian Public Service is simply reduced to a party political extension of the executive government.

It is also crucial that the Australian Public Service maintains reasonable working conditions so that it continues to attract competent people. I understand that reasonable employment conditions is a concept that is lost on this government. But by diminishing the conditions in the APS you simply diminish the calibre of people wanting to serve their community through the Australian Public Service. It would be most terrible to see an institution such as the Australian Public Service—an institution that has produced such great careers—simply reduced to a mediocre or average government administration.

We have seen in recent times the skill and the talent by which the Australian Public Service has positioned itself in a global context on best practice in a whole range of administrative areas. The late Nugget Coombs and the other great architects of Australia's post‐war reconstruction under the Chifley Labor government are a wonderful testament to the benefits of governments valuing a well resourced and independent public sector—values that this coalition government obvious ly does not share with the rest of the community.

The government has also been most enthusiastic in its use of the word `flexibility' when talking about the changes required to the Public Service. However, we see that the proposed employment provisions under these bills would restrict mobility between the Australian Public Service and the staff of members and senators, government authorities and business enterprises. What absolute hypocrisy by this government to talk about the essential need for flexibility and at the same time remove a provision in the current act that gives total flexibility in the management of the human resources of the Public Service.

There is also the situation with respect to how these bills propose to change the way the Merit Protection and Review Agency operates. Of utmost importance is ensuring the continuation of an independent Merit Protection Commissioner, but further to that is ensuring that the commissioner's statutory functions are included in the primary legislation, and that the commissioner has the power to properly carry out the duties and responsibilities that are required of the MPRA—something the government has failed to provide for.

It also changes the way in which the MPRA will report. It will no longer directly report to the parliament but to the Public Service Commission. Perhaps the government should listen to its own members on this point. Mr Georgiou, a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which considered the bill in detail, stated in his speech on the bill in the other place:

The other side of the coin to flexibility is accountability. For this to be met, the independent review body will have to be very robust in reporting to the parliament on cases where secretaries choose not to implement its recommendations. This is of great significance and I do expect that the parliament will be monitoring such reports very closely to see that what is intended does actually occur.

Mr Georgiou has got it right. It is a pity that the government, of which he is a member, is unable to get it right. Without these powers the Merit Protection Agency simply becomes window dressing; something that appears to be one of the government's goals.

On the point of the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 , the opposition supports the concept of separate legislation for the parliamentary departments. We recognise the importance of maintaining the independence of the institution of the parliament. However, we have seen from this government attempts to gut the structure of the parliamentary departments. The arguments I have applied with respect to the Public Service Bill equally apply to the Parliamentary Service Bill. The accolades I have given to those in the wider Public Service also most definitely apply to those who have made a commitment to serve the Australian people through serving their parliament and their parliamentarians.

The coalition government has made clear by its actions towards the Public Service since being elected, that it is motivated by hate and has a small‐minded, mean‐fisted approach to government. It is the Australian people who suffer most as a result of this approach. The dismissal of public servants is not just about the loss of jobs. It is an attack on the role of government in the delivery of services to all Australians and the willingness to invest in the provision of services—a willingness that has been shown to be lacking by the coalition.

Ultimately, what the Australian people want from the Public Service is the delivery of taxpayer-funded services in the most efficient and effective way possible. The Australian Public Service has a distinguished record in this regard. Australia does have a Public Service of which we can be proud—one which receives criticism that it does not deserve and one which does not always get the defence it does deserve, especially with regard to this government. I greatly value the contribution of the individual Australians who choose to work for their government as public servants, and collectively for their contribution to our nation and our democracy.

It is hard to imagine what Australia is going to be like if this government is allowed to pursue its agenda. Can you imagine a country where the means by which services are provided to those in need is governed by the ability of the private sector to make a dollar out of the provision of such services? The concept of user pays applied to services that are currently provided by government is one that is abhorrent. I reject it on the basis that it is not about equity; it is not about fairness; it is not about giving all Australians a fair go. It is about a principle that excludes the concept of fairness. It is about a principle that blindly puts the interests of the private sector above the needs of all Australians.

The problem with this package of bills is that it does not take into account the great record of our Public Service and how it increases equity in Australian society. Hence, it does not look to maintain or build upon that powerful framework upon which it was built. These bills, if not successfully amended by the opposition, will result in the undermining of much of that which has made the Australian Public Service so successful and so effective.

I accept that we need an amended, more contemporary Public Service Act. However, I do not accept that these bills provide a viable option for an Australian Public Service that will be able to serve the nation as the Australian public expect and as the Australian public will continue to demand and expect into the new millennium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service legislation seeks to implement the government's Public Service reforms—reforms which are pitched clearly and unequivocally at undermining the integrity and independence of the Australian Public Service, reforms which attempt to turn the Australian Public Service into the creature of the government of the day rather than the servant of the government, the parliament and the Australian public. I want to be very clear about this from the outset: the Democrats are not opposed to Public Service and public sector reform. In fact, we see it as being necessary if Australia is to meet the challenges ahead with an efficient, effective and viable public sector in place.

SPEECH.PARA: When the government released its discussion paper on Public Service reform, the Democrats said that we welcomed reform aimed at improving service delivery and reducing bureaucratic obstacles standing in the way of the APS delivering more responsive and flexible services and programs. We indicated that we welcome reform designed to improve work practices within the APS.

I personally attended Public Service focus groups run by the then minister for the Public Service, Peter Reith, and I got the sense from those sessions that many dedicated Public Service employees were looking for change. They were looking for changes designed to make the Public Service both a better work environment and to give it an improved capacity to deliver quality services.

But the end result of that process—this Public Service Bill currently before us today—has very little to do with improving quality of service. It has very little to do with freeing up the APS to deliver more responsive services and programs. It has very little to do with making a genuine attempt to build a modern Public Service and everything to do with what are mainly industrial relations reforms aimed at putting the APS well and truly under the thumb of the government.

If this bill passes the parliament intact, the Democrats believe it will result in a shift towards a less accountable Public Service, one over which the parliament will be unable to exercise adequate scrutiny and one in which Public Service employees will have difficulty obtaining fair access to redress for wrongful actions and decisions. It is a bill which reflects the government's failure to acknowledge that any changes or improvements in work practices should also take into account the role of the APS in serving both the public and the wider public interest.

The APS serves the government of the day. Of course it is, in practice, doing the government's bidding. Nobody pretends otherwise. But there has always been a sense of a wider public duty running alongside that role. This bill represents the Howard government's attempts to entrench in law their very limited and narrow vision of what constitutes an effective Public Service.

It is no secret that the Howard government does not trust the Public Service, especially the Canberra based Public Service. Some level of mistrust is understandable when a government comes to power after a long time in opposition. But I believe the coalition government has done both itself and the country a great disservice by elevating that mistrust to the level of paranoia, to the point where it has either not sought or has rejected good advice from departmental staff.

That mistrust or paranoia is partly responsible for some poor decision making and poor policy implementation from the government since its election. Instead of looking at improving its own performance in this regard, the government has opted for legislation which attempts to impose a radical reform agenda on the Australian Public Service—an agenda which will change the nature of the Public Service and turn it into, in the words of Sir Lenox Hewitt, `a series of appointments at pleasure'.
In our minority report to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, the Democrats set out our objectives to this bill very clearly. We summed up our position in these terms:

The Democrats are concerned the Bill in its present form signals a shift away from a Westminster style public service able to give independent, frank and fearless advice to both government and parliament, towards a new `private sector' model of public service which `belongs' to the government of the day.

I acknowledge that the government has taken on board many of the concerns of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and that what we have before us today is a vastly improved bill from the one introduced into the House of Representatives. But it remains a seriously flawed piece of legislation and one which the Democrats cannot support without substantial amendment.

The Democrats' outstanding concerns remain as set out in our minority report. We remain concerned about the process of appointing agency heads. We believe it is unacceptable for the Prime Minister and ministers to be able to hire and fire departmental heads, as well as fix their remuneration and conditions in a manner which is not subject to independent review or public scrutiny. We remain concerned about the inadequate protection afforded to Public Service whistleblowers. Senator Murray will speak on this particular subject and will move amendments designed to significantly increase that level of protection. We remain concerned that the bill is silent on the question of maintaining standards, accountability and quality in the APS services which are contracted out.

We are unable to support legislation which effectively removes the right of Public Service employees to appeal to an independent body. This seems to us to be a very fundamental point of accountability, particularly when the bill imposes very few other controls over primary decision makers within the APS. We are unhappy about the exclusion of SES employees from the operation of the Workplace Relations Act. We are concerned about the capacity of these changes to result in major discrepancies across the APS in workplace conditions, terms and remuneration—a shift which is likely to lead to some agencies being able to offer higher salaries than others, irrespective of the nature, value or priority of the work being undertaken by the agency. We believe such an approach is unlikely to lead to better quality service.
In her evidence to the JCPA, Ms Helen Coventry of the University of Canberra made some important points about the value of some common or basic standards across the APS. She said:

To some extent any change produces productivity losses, but the losses can be minimised . . . if there are more common features on which to build amongst the units that are being combined. In the past the mechanism which facilitated this type of change in the public sector was the common terms and conditions of employment. We did see different cultures, but at least that was a strong base on which to effect such change.

In addition, members of the APS identified with membership of the APS. There has always been a stronger sense of belonging to the Public Service than belonging to a particular agency . . . This identification can be attributed to a belief in the role of government and wanting to serve government.

This is a very crucial point which we think the bill essentially ignores. There are other aspects of the bill with which the Democrats have concerns. We intend to support those opposition amendments which address most of these concerns, but we will also be moving our own amendments which go further than the opposition's amendments in six key areas.

BREAK.PARA: Firstly, we will ensure APS values also apply to services which are contracted out and that contracted services are delivered in an effective and transparent fashion. Secondly, we will retain the Governor-General's power, on the recommendation of the Prime Minister, to appoint and terminate agency heads. Thirdly, we will retain the power of the Remuneration Tribunal to determine the remuneration of agency heads, the Public Service Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner. Fourthly, we will move amendments preventing agency heads from entering into individual workplace agreements with APS employees. Fifthly, we will significantly enhance the protection given to APS whistleblowers. Finally, in relation to the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 , we will remove the 10-year tenure limit on the clerks of the Senate and the House of Representatives and ensure a much more accountable process for the appointment of the clerks.

Those are the six features which distinguish our amendments from those of the opposition. They are matters which we believe must be included within this legislation for it to be acceptable to us. Without the inclusion of these protections, these bills remain little more than an unacceptable attack on the independence and integrity of the APS; they remain little more than an attack on the rights of APS employees. They do little to improve public service quality or efficiency and they will ultimately do very little to deliver a world‐class modern public service.

In a recent article in the Canberra Bulletin of Public Administration, Peter Hennessy, who is a Professor of History at the University of London, observed that a cornerstone of a successful public service was the giving of `fearless advice resting on top‐class analysis'. He expressed the view that, in the current climate of globalisation, `the prizes go to the flexible and the intelligent. And governments can be neither of those things if the outcome of policy making is the precooked, the palatable and the convenient'. In the Democrats' view, the Howard government has allowed its preconceptions and prejudices about the public sector to stand in the way of delivering world‐class public service reform.

The Public Service Bill 1997 will ensure the government receives from the APS the advice that it wants to hear, not the advice that it needs to hear. That is an outcome which will inevitably lead to a precooked, palatable and convenient result which will do little to serve Australia's interests.

Finally, it has been extremely difficult to make an informed assessment about the impact of this legislation because of the absence of detail available to the parliament. The bills themselves are light on detail with much of the practical workings of the legislation coming in the form of regulations and directions from the Public Service Commissioner. Getting hold of the final versions of these directions and regulations has proved close to impossible.

We now have a copy of the regulations and directions, marked `draft only', and these were delivered to us last week. I understand these are the full and final set of regulations and directions which will accompany the bills. I also understand that the minister intends to table these documents today as part of the debate. Even if the minister does that, I do not believe it is acceptable for the Senate to proceed to debate these bills in the committee stage today. We have had less than one week to look at the regulations and directions, many of which are concerned with crucial parts of the principal legislation. I do not believe that that is sufficient time for the Senate to debate these bills in an informed and responsible manner. Accordingly, I move:
Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"further consideration of the Bills be postponed until 10 sitting days after final versions of the draft regulations and directions of the Public Service Commissioner are tabled in the Senate".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing my remarks to these public service bills, in particular the Public Service Bill 1997 , I think it is appropriate to go back to where this whole process really started—that is, a discussion paper issued in November 1996 by the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Peter Reith. It is interesting to note some of the comments that were made in that paper. One well worth restating is that of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in terms of maintaining the traditions of the Public Service. This is a quote attributed to the Prime Minister on 9 May 1996:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian public is very fortunate that over the years it's had a federal public service that has been distinguished by two characteristics. The first of those characteristics is an extremely high degree of integrity and honesty . . . The other characteristic, of course, is a very high degree of professionalism, and a willingness over the years . . . to give comprehensive and, on most occasions, pretty zealous technical advice.
That is so true, and the Prime Minister endorsed a statement of the key ethical values of the APS, and it is worth noting some of those points. The discussion paper states:
The values, which the National Commission of Audit described as `a best practice method of setting the ethical standards for the public service', are:
. the highest standards of probity, integrity and conduct;
. a strong commitment to the community;
. responsiveness to governments;
. a strong commitment to accountability;
. a close focus on results;
. continuous improvement through teams and individuals; and
. merit as the basis for achieving excellence in staffing.

Also in this discussion paper Towards a best practice Australian public service by the Prime Minister it is worth noting some of the comments in the preface by the minister himself. The minister says:

The Government is looking at more effective ways of serving the Australian public. It is no longer appropriate for the APS to have a monopoly. It must prove that it can deliver government services as well as the private or non‐profit sectors. This will require a new emphasis on contestability of services, outsourcing those functions which the private or non‐profit sector can undertake better and ensuring APS commitment to the process of performance benchmarking and continuous improvement.
The APS must meet the challenges of market competition and ensure that its quality standards match those of the private sector. To do this it will need support.
And that is very interesting. He continues:

BREAK.PARA: The Government is determined to address barriers which lie in the way of the APS becoming a truly best practice organisation—
He forgot to mention the government—
one that is able to deliver quality service to government and the Australian people and, at the same time, provide a professional and rewarding environment in which to work.
The minister then went on to some dot points, which state:
To achieve this the employment framework governing the APS needs to be modernised. This must encompass:
. the legislation regulating the Service, most notably (but not exclusively) the Public Service Act 1922 ;
. the industrial framework and enterprise bargaining arrangements which establish APS terms and conditions of employment;
. the management framework which influences the culture and practice of individual APS workplaces; and
. the need for more effective leadership based on clear vision and communication of future directions.
Finally, in that preface statement, the minister says:
I look forward to receiving your ideas and views to assist the Government in finalising its approach to these important issues.
Together we can reshape and reinvigorate the APS—and through that process ensure that the Australian public is provided with access to better government.

There are some very notable points there that the minister and, indeed, the Prime Minister have made—none of which appear to be supported by any of the legislation the government has introduced. It would seem that, contrary to what was set out in this discussion paper and contrary to the paper's objectives, the government is proposing to introduce a system of favouritism—a system where the Prime Minister and ministers can employ departmental heads, negotiate their salaries directly and keep those salaries confidential from the parliament; and the departmental heads, in turn, can negotiate the salaries of officers, et cetera. The Prime Minister has said that that is how you go about providing:
. . . a very high degree of professionalism, and a willingness over the years . . . to give comprehen sive and, on most occasions, pretty zealous technical advice.

But I am not sure that will be the outcome. The Finance and Public Administration Committee conducted a round table discussion in February of this year where some very interesting comments were made. Of particular note were comments made by the Public Service Commissioner, Dr Shergold, and the editor of the Canberra Times , Mr Waterford. I would just like to quote some of the points made by Dr Shergold and Mr Waterford, and I will start with some comments made by Mr Waterford. In addressing the concerns the ACT has with regard to this government's approach to the Public Service—and I think they are genuine concerns—Mr Waterford said:

I have to tell you that I come here as a considerable sceptic yet to be convinced that what is on offer from our new best practice Public Service is better than what we have now. I think I would almost prefer the old Public Service Act, and all of its very clear imperfections, to the brave new world in which some of the discussion paper is taking us. I say that, very well aware of the imperfections of the old act, though irritated by the misleading nature of some of the criticism of it, and thinking that there are many useful reforms of it which could be made.

That is so true because, in the discussion paper and as part of the overall process, various points have been made with regard to the problems associated with the existing act. If you look at the discussion paper and at how things have proceeded, you see that some confusion has crept into this process about the competitive tendering, contracting out and outsourcing of government services versus the employment of public servants. It would appear to me that that is the case and, as I said, that comes through in the discussion paper. There is nothing wrong with this process of reform of the Public Service Act and the competitive tendering and contracting out of government services. Indeed, we started it. We have never opposed amendments to the Public Service Act to bring it into the 21st century.

As we have seen over the years, various acts or agreements relating to employment have changed to fit the need of the time, and there is nothing wrong with getting the Public Service to be more efficient and more effective. But what is proposed in this legislation is far from that. Many other speakers have highlighted the problems of having an approach whereby, as I said, the Prime Minister, ministers, et cetera can negotiate with people employment outcomes that will never be up for public scrutiny. That can create agency or departmental fiefdoms where people will be beholden to the government, and that is something I thought the government wanted to totally avoid. I thought the government was seeking to have a Public Service that would deliver independent advice, that would deliver unbiased advice—something the government has always accused the current Public Service of not doing. So, if the government is about seeking changes, it ought to have done it in a genuine way.

As I said, some areas of the existing act certainly needed looking at, and one that got thrown up quite often was how many types of leave there are. Many aspects of the existing act could have been amended to rectify all those problems—leave, payments—but, at the end of the day, it is critical that we have a Public Service that has the capacity to provide a career path and that will allow public servants to take an interest in the process. It is critical that public servants have a commitment to the Public Service. They provide a very valuable service not only to the government but also, more importantly, to the public of Australia. If we do not have those things, I think that we will be taking a major step backwards rather than any step forward.

The Public Service bills, as has been said on a number of occasions, not only seek to create a very different and, I think, incorrect approach to the employment of public servants but also seek to get rid of a number of other things. In particular, they seek to remove the mobility rights of employees. Many governments have benefited over the years from public servants who have transferred from the service and have been directly employed by government working either for ministers or the Prime Minister. If that ability is taken away, public servants' career path development is also taken away. Also, the opportunities for public servants to increase and expand their knowledge of the way in which government operates in various departments would be removed. At the end of the day, such an action would very much preclude and, I think, put to an end such benefits for public servants and, therefore, the service that they can provide to the parliament and to the people of Australia.

Why are we so suspicious of this current legislation? Why should public servants be suspicious of it? That is fairly well highlighted by the fact that the government has got rid of 30,000 public servants in 20 months. Although the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) may have said that only 2,500 jobs would be lost, we have seen 30,000 go. Most of them have gone from Canberra and the Canberra region. The Canberra region has suffered and is suffering as a result of that.

As I said, although it seeks to do otherwise, this legislation lends itself to patronage and favouritism. This is a position that I suppose the government has always had, but it will increase if this legislation is enacted. We moved some 61 amendments in the House of Representatives, all of which were defeated, but that will not be the end of the day for this legislation. We must seek to amend it. As I said at the outset, there is nothing wrong with changing legislation to bring it into the 21st century, to make it more acceptable and to make the Public Service more efficient, more effective—we should do that. But that is not what the cognate bills seek to do; quite the contrary, in fact.

I encourage people not to support this bill. As I said, if we cannot get it amended we will see a Public Service that, firstly, will not be responsible to the parliament and, secondly, will not serve the government or the public of this country very well at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Public Service Bill 1997 , I will largely devote my remarks to accountability matters with reference to the bill, but before I do so I want to make some brief remarks on the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 and on the most important issue, from the Australian Democrats' point of view, in that parliamentary service bill, that is, the restriction which is intended on the ability of the clerks of both houses to have complete independence.

SPEECH.PARA: The institution of parliament is perverted to some extent by the dominance of the executive in the lower house. The separation of powers requires the parliament to be representative of the people as a whole. In that sense, it requires it to be distant from and distinct from the executive in as many ways as possible, particularly in areas to do with accountability and with ensuring that the executive of the day cannot interfere with the process of democracy and proper representative institutions.

In that respect, the presence of independent clerks who can fearlessly provide advice to individual senators or members and to parties other than the party of the executive of the day should be protected to the fullest degree possible. I think that the Presiding Officers were remiss in recommending a limited tenure for the clerks; I disagree with that intention. I am glad that the Labor Party has managed to persuade the government and the Presiding Officers to consider a tenure term rather than a five‐year term, but I will regard the day on which we grant limited tenure and, therefore, limited independence to the clerks as a bad day for this parliament. I think the numbers will ensure that that is the outcome, but I want to express my great concern and that of the Australian Democrats over that erosion of independence for both the Senate and the House of Representatives as a whole.

I turn now to the Public Service Bill 1997 . The Australian public sector in the 1990s is a vital but rapidly diminishing part of government. In May 1997 the public sector accounted for under 18 per cent of the Australian work force, which is still a very substantial figure. By comparison, in June 1985 it accounted for just under 26 per cent of all employed persons in Australia. So it has had a reduction of at least one quarter. It is estimated that after the public float of Telstra the number of those employed in the public sector will drop to approximately 15 per cent. So it has been rapidly diminishing. But it is still one of the largest employers in Australia and, as such, the public sector must provide the best possible environment for its employees.

Economic rationalists would perhaps sit up at the motion of the best possible environment for employees—because they also look at things from the point of view of employers—but it is my view that it is in the interests of both the employer and the employee to guarantee the best possible environment for employees. Overwhelmingly, research suggests that employees who are happy with the conditions of employment will be far more efficient, far more loyal, and far more productive than those who are not.

You will recall the guru of downsizing who, once he had wreaked his havoc in the United States and spread it to other countries through the world, then recanted and said he was terribly sorry, because the job insecurity and the damage that had been done to employees' belief in their employers had in fact resulted in lower productivity, less efficiency and less loyalty. So you have to provide a system which keeps both employees and employers happy.

It is in the interests of the employer—in this case, the government—that the public sector provides such an environment so that the government will benefit from a productive and efficient public sector which has loyal and happy employees. The question the government has to answer is whether these bills will in fact produce that result.

The Public Service Bill 1997 is intended to replace the current legislative framework for the establishment and management of the Australian Public Service. I have had little disagreement from any party with the concept of bringing the Public Service up to modern standards, but it is essential that the new framework does not undermine the purpose, tradition and very high standard of the Public Service, which is to serve the public. It is also important that it in no way damages the essential assets of the Public Service, which are the skills, loyalty and dedication of the employee.

I am one of those members of parliament who have lived in a number of countries, and I can tell you that the Australian Public Service is of a standard and ability which many other countries would really like to have. It is not a standard which should be dropped in any way but, if it can be raised, let us see if this bill can do that.

In the last 20 years the role of the public sector has been subject to vast changes. I only wish to stress that the changing demands on public servants and the changing nature of their jobs have meant that corresponding changes have had to be made to the terms and conditions afforded government employees. Job security in the Public Service is no longer guaranteed, which has been welcomed by some.

We are all familiar with the mythology of inefficient, parasitic Public Service employees who have no genuine interest in serving the public and who spend a large amount of their career living off the work of others and cannot be sacked because they never step out of line. I have used the term `mythology' because I do not believe that that represents the majority of public servants in any sense. My own experience of the public sector in Australia is quite the contrary, and they have a well deserved reputation as being very able.

Nevertheless, these bills do herald the further removal of job security in the Public Service, and that will continue to have significant negative effects. But let it not be forgotten that it was not the coalition who introduced job insecurity to the public sector; it was the Labor Party. And it is the Labor Party who must stand condemned for so much which has hurt the tradition and nature of the way in which we deal with our public sector employees.

One of the features of this bill that has been commented on at length is the potential loss of independent advice from senior public servants to government ministers without fear or favour. It is said that there is already a sign of deteriorating standards of advice to the government as a result of wholesale retrenchments and downsizing, because the best people have often gone first. However, that has happened.

There is also the view, often offered by those with relatively little experience of the private sector, that private sector standards of hiring, firing and managing are in fact better than those in the public sector. Many private sector organisations, including some very large ones, are in fact run on autocratic principles—they are not democratic organisations.

People stand to lose their jobs, not just in terms of not fulfilling the productive or efficient requirements of the organisation but also if they do not fit in. And fitting in in the private sector means making sure you do not put your boss offside by giving advice or opinions which might not be relished or liked. The public sector, on the other hand, has a tradition of doing that very thing.
