And quite rightly so, because governments come and go, ministers and parliamentary secretaries and those sorts of people are of varying capabilities and varying abilities, and the independent advice which can be offered by a member of the public sector who does not have to fear losing their job because of providing that independent advice is in marked contrast to the tradition and nature of the private sector employee.

I remind all those who say how wonderful the private sector is that, if you look back over 20 years at the Fortune 500, you will find that two‐thirds to three‐quarters of those companies listed 20 years ago are no longer featured. One of the reasons they are no longer featured is that the nature of employment and management practices in those organisations has often not encouraged independent advice. It is not automatically so that private sector practices are necessarily preferable or better in a public sector environment with very different demands upon the people. We must be cautious of automatically trotting out that kind of prejudice.

In future, advice which is not consistent with the policy of the government of the day will only be given by courageous public servants who do not fear that their job promotion or future opportunities may be on the line because of that advice. That is not a welcome development because it is preferable for large numbers of public servants to feel that way. The removal of this and many other protections in the public sector's administrative law gives more urgency for the inclusion of new protections for public servants. It is to that area that I now want to address my remarks because I wish to introduce amendments to the Public Service Bill 1997 which will focus on comprehensive protection for Australian Public Service employees who make public interest disclosures, people otherwise known, often pejoratively, as `whistleblowers'.

What my whistleblowing amendments will seek to achieve has been recognised as essential for the future of a democratic system of government. It has been recognised as essential in numerous Australian royal commissions, inquiries, committees and reports. It seeks to provide a legislative framework which encourages public interest disclosures about wrongdoing, corruption, fraud, gross waste or mismanagement and which affords protection legally and, in some circumstances, physically to those who make such disclosures in the public interest.

An effective program to combat corruption and gross maladministration in the public sector needs two arms: one to carry the sword with which to pursue and eradicate the wrongdoing disclosed by whistleblowers, which is the role of the government's anti‐corruption forces such as the police, the Auditor‐General, the Ombudsman and anti‐corruption agencies; and the second arm is the shield with which to protect whistleblowers from the swords of those whose wrongdoings were disclosed by the whistleblowers. That is the role of whistleblower protection bodies.

The legislative amendments which I have had drafted for the Democrats recognise the dual needs of a whistleblower. They establish an independent agency—the public interest disclosure agency—which is given the responsibility of investigating reports and allegations of wrongdoing and establish an independent body—the whistleblowers protection agency—charged principally with the responsibility for protecting whistleblowers from reprisals. This is a conscious effort to change from the model in which responsibility for whistleblower investigation and protection is grafted on to existing agencies.

It also provides a more flexible model for disclosing information as it affords protection to whistleblowers who make public interest disclosures to the public interest disclosure agency, the whistleblowers protection agency, an agency head or the Merit Protection Commissioner. In certain circumstances, disclosures may also be made to a member of parliament or a journalist. This picks up on the New South Wales Protected Disclosures Act 1994 which provides similar protection.

This protection to whistleblowers would be extended whether or not the allegations were disproved, but not if they were deliberately false or misleading. Therefore, a person making disclosures in good faith would be protected by these amendments, while a person making false and misleading claims would be criminally liable.

The government's Public Service Bill 1997 provides very limited scope for disclosure and protection of whistleblowers. Their protection is limited to allegations of breaches of the code of conduct contained in the bill. This is clearly inadequate as it may circumscribe the opportunity for what whistleblower legislation commonly describes as `public interest disclosures'. Frankly, we would have preferred for the government to have brought forward their own whistleblowers bill, but they have not done so. Therefore, it is incumbent upon the Democrats to introduce this major accountability amendment to the only vehicle we can; that is, the Public Service Bill 1997 .

The Democrat amendments broaden the scope of whistleblower disclosures to include violations of law, gross mismanagement, gross waste of public funds, abuse of authority, substantial and specific danger to public liability or safety, or a failure to act lawfully. This is necessary if we are to have an honest, efficient, open and accountable public sector in Australia. The amendments also protect whistleblowers from legal action should they breach any secrecy laws in making public interest disclosures that fall into these categories.

Remedies for whistleblowers who are threatened or who have been subject to financial disadvantage through loss of job, demotion or lack of promotion are included in the amendments. Remedies include reinstatement, ex gratia payments and, where appropriate, damages. The remedies would need to be enforced by the Industrial Relations Commission or the Supreme Court, and the commissioner of the public interest disclosure agency would have the power to apply to the court for orders or injunctions.

The public interest disclosure agency would also have the power to recommend disciplinary action against government employees responsible for the harassment of or discrimination against whistleblowers. To date, for those of you who think this is academic, 12 whistleblower protection bills have been drafted in Australia and New Zealand and five have become law. Two impressive bills were tabled in the Senate in 1991 and 1993, but have got nowhere. Since then, no comprehensive legislation establishing independent agencies for the reporting of public interest disclosures and for the protection of whistleblowers has been passed by the Commonwealth. This is a sad indictment on the government as in 1994 the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing tabled one of the most important official analyses of whistleblowing in Australia. The government is yet to respond to that report three years later.

In 1993 and 1994, whistleblower laws were passed in South Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and the ACT. A limited form of whistleblower protection is now in place in Western Australia under the act establishing the Anti‐Corruption Commission, although in Western Australia, yet again, Premier Richard Court has largely ignored the commission on government's recommendations in this regard. Whistleblowers in the remaining states, territories and the Commonwealth must rely on the common law for any form of protection.

Whistleblowing legislation is essential at the Commonwealth level for a number of reasons. Firstly, protection for public servants who make public interest disclosures encourages openness and transparency in government and is crucial if the government is to be truly accountable to the public. Secondly, whistleblowing is a legitimate form of action within a democracy. There have been, are, and will continue to be occasions when whistleblowing is the only available avenue for the concerned ethical citizen to expose wrongdoing in the public sector.

Thirdly, with the passing of state legislation which protects public service employees, quite clearly the gap in the legislative program with respect to Australian public sector employees would establish unsatisfactory inconsistencies or discrepancies and would mean that the public servants at the Commonwealth level were not afforded the same level of protection and encouragement as their state counterparts.

Next, the corruption scandals of the 1980s demonstrated the need for a system which provided for the reception of information about wrongdoing and the protection of those who bring disclosures forward. The Commonwealth is not immune from this and must act to protect its employees or risk public resources in an environment where public sector employees will not report corrupt activities, fraud or gross mismanagement which is costing taxpayers money because they are not afforded any protection in statute. We must afford whistleblowers protection. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to what Senator Murray had to say, as I always do. Perhaps more discussion can occur in the committee stage about his whistleblower provisions. There is another side to that. He condemns government for not bringing whistleblower provisions forward. The other side of it is that it has the capacity to develop the culture of the informer, which was the sort of thing that Sir Winston Churchill had much to say about in the 1930s. It also highlights the statement that was made in Pearse and Pearse by the Lord Chancellor of the time, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely—may be pursued too keenly—may cost too much.
Any development of a whistleblower statute needs to be done very carefully.

I have some hesitation in saying that it should be done in the context of the Public Service Bill 1997 , which really deals with other matters. This bill deals with the way we can best get the sorts of services we need from the public servants that look after the proper government of this country, which is a different function from that of people in the private sector. Corporations Law, for example, says that a company's duty is to look to the welfare of its shareholders by ensuring that the profit of the company is as great as it legitimately can be.

On the other hand, the purpose of a public service is to give proper advice—and it has been said here today, and it will be said again and again—without fear or favour, and to give advice that is proper for the proper governing of the country. We do not want the situation, as was said to King Richard by John of Gaunt as long ago as that, according to Shakespeare, where `a thousand flatterers sit within thy crown'. What he was saying is what we are saying now, and what speakers before me have said today: if you do not want 1,000 flatterers giving advice, then you have to do something to ensure that they will not be flatterers.

The proper comparison for public servants is not to those in the private sector but to those people whom we want to make decisions without fear or favour—namely, the judges. Whether it is pursuant to the act of settlement, the precedent set by the American constitution, the Code Napoleon or our own constitution, we try to ensure two things for judges: tenure and a proper level of income—not a rich level of income, but a proper level of income.

In this particular legislation that we are considering, we do not know what level of income is going to be given to public servants because that is going to be set by people other than those in parliament. It is going to be set pursuant to regulations. Certainly, there is no pretence of giving tenure to any public servant because the provisions within the two bills that we are considering at the moment—the Public Service Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 —is to ensure that anything but security of tenure is granted.

Our constitutional history says that the way to get good sound advice is to give tenure and a reasonable income, but those propositions are being overturned in these bills. This is radical legislation. The longer I am in this place, and the more often I see bills like this coming before me, the more I realise how conservative I have become. The sort of radical legislation that is brought before these places and which tosses aside the great principles upon which our constitutional history has developed comes as a shock and a disappointment to me, I must confess.

For example, in the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 , we have a provision that the clerk will have a 10-year period and no more. That is a coming back from the idea of tenure; the clerk is given security for 10 years but that is all. I would be very disappointed if the reason for that particular provision was that there was a dislike of a particular clerk at a particular time. If that was the motivation behind this provision, that would be a most disturbing issue. I have not heard of a good reason why it should be a 10‐year period, except to say that we need a turnover of ideas every now and then.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what we are here for.

—Senator Murray says that we are here to ensure—I am not sure what he says we are here to ensure—but what I am saying is that, as governments come and go, you need a steady, reliable set of advice that is going to be given without fear or favour.

SPEECH.PARA: What is going to be developed through the bills before us today is the spoils system, but only more so. I think it was Thomas Jefferson who started off this system when he was President but it was brought to its zenith—if that is the right word to use—or nadir, if you look at it another way, by President Jackson in 1829 when he came in and said, `Right, from now on, the top of the public service will be appointed by the incoming administration.' That has led to the spoils system in America.

But this legislation goes even further because this is a spoils system directed not only at the top echelon of the Public Service but also at every public servant who is to be employed. Let us look at how that comes about. Clause 10 of the Public Service Bill sets out high and proper values for the Commonwealth administration to pursue but then provides for a mechanism calculated to see the realisation of those values marred. Clause 51 of the Public Service Bill 1997 gives the Prime Minister power to appoint a departmental secretary and clause 52 enables him or her to terminate that appointment `at any time'—that is the expression used. Clauses 20 and 22 give an agency head, which includes a departmental secretary, the right to engage public servants, and clause 29 enables him or her to dismiss them at any time.

So it is entrenched in legislation that the Prime Minister can appoint and dismiss at any time the person who will appoint and dismiss those public servants that come within his or her department. That is clearly a recipe for a spoils system. It is a fundamental change in the philosophy that has served us well until now. The fact that the Public Service makes such a contribution is set out by the minister previously responsible for this particular legislation, Mr Peter Reith, in a discussion paper entitled Towards a best practice Australian Public Service. This paper was published in November 1996 and forms the basis for the bills that we are now considering. He wrote in the preface:

The APS makes a vital contribution to Australia through the advice and services which it delivers. The Government recognises and values the high ethical standards, professionalism, independence and quality of the technical policy advice it provides.
Having said that, he then goes ahead and sponsors a bill which is going to mar the realisation of those qualities. He goes on to explain himself:
Equally it demands that the APS be a modern and efficient employer which exhibits best practice, is committed to continuous improvement and exemplifies contemporary management techniques.
Why does it demand that? What evidence is there that the introduction of those sorts of mechanisms will lead to a better Public Service?

We have a statement from the minister in this discussion paper, Towards a best practice Australian Public Service, saying that we have a very good Public Service and Senator Murray says that, in his experience around the world, this is an outstanding Public Service. The government says, `Yes, we have that, but we are now going to change,' because for some reason it demands that the sorts of employment strategies that now operate within the private sector are better. Mind you, Senator Mackay and I would say that the sorts of employment laws that operate in the private sector now are just as destructive in that sector as they will be if introduced into the Public Service. Senator Mackay and I wonder when people are going to be praised for the work they do, given some sort of tenure within the job they carry out and also given fair remuneration.

One of the reasons that the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 and the Public Service Bill 1997 are brought forward is that it is said they are going to cut away the legislation that presently surrounds the employment of public servants and people who are employed within the Senate and the House of Representatives and akin departments. Having said that it is going to put aside all that legislation, it then sets out, in various proposed sections, provisions for regulations. There are going to be regulations providing for conduct under proposed subsection 13(13) of the Public Service Bill and the Parliamentary Service Bill.

You are going to be able to set through regulations the sort of conduct that is to be expected. You are going to set out sanctions for APS employees and for people employed in the parliamentary service. You are going to set out provisions as to how they are going to be sanctioned in regulations. You are going to put out regulations as to how people are going to be suspended from duty. You are going to put out regulations as to what the retirement age is going to be. You are going to set out regulations for commissioners' functions. You are going to set out regulations as to how salaries are going to be treated when there is a garnishee order out. You are going to set out in regulations how the clerk is going to be suspended—and on and on it goes.

This legislation is taking away all those things from primary legislation, which must be passed by this parliament, and putting them into subordinate legislation for some reason or other. This gives a much greater advantage to the government to put forward what it wants, because parliament then has to be on the lookout and has to know when these regulations are going to come along. In any event, the regulations operate until they are disallowed—if they are.

So it is not so much that legislation is being stripped away from the employment of public servants; it is that that legislation is being put into a form which gives the government of the day much more control over what that legislation is going to be. It makes it a little more difficult, perhaps a great deal more difficult, for parliament to fulfil its proper role in overseeing that sort of subordinate legislation.

We have a real problem here. We have the Parliamentary Service Bill which makes all of those people in the Department of the Senate, who have served us so well over the years, much more vulnerable to being fired. I just wonder why the people who serve us in this chamber, who look after us in the corridors, who look after our economics and who look after our speeches by putting them in Hansard for 1,000 years should suddenly be put in a position where their security of employment is attacked.

What is it about these people that we now think it is proper and right to make them subject to hiring and firing almost at the whim of particular individuals? True enough, there are some procedures to go through but, nevertheless, the statement that people can be fired at any time on the say‐so of particular individuals is set down in this legislation. That seems to me to be not well calculated to give us that honesty of service that we need; it is calculated more to ensure that a thousand flatterers will sit within the Crown—that being the government. It just makes you wonder about the attitude that people entertain in looking at how their fellow citizens go about their tasks.

I will have a bit more to say when we come to the committee stages of this legislation, but the way to sum it up is this: this is legislation which expresses great aspirations. It sets out the qualities that we want in our public servants, in the clerks and in all of those people who help us in the Senate and the House of Representatives and elsewhere. It is quite inspiring in the sorts of aspirations it sets out. But, having set them out, it then introduces a system that is quite cruelly calculated to ensure that those qualities are not forthcoming. It creates a service that is so dependent upon the will of one or two individuals that it will ensure that what we get is not the independent, courageous—it would be courageous if it were given—well‐assessed, measured advice we need. What we will get is the sort of advice that people think will best go down with those who are able to determine their future. If they do give advice that is correct in those circumstances, it is going to be courage above and beyond the call of duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney is always a hard act to follow and I regret to inform the chamber that my contribution will not have the same literary and historical flavour as his, and will probably be much more dry in its content. I rise to speak on the Public Service bills before the Senate. These bills have undergone scrutiny by two committees. The most comprehensive, of course, was the report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. I commend the committee on its work and the report that it produced, but we on this side of the chamber believe that it goes only part of the way to meeting the concerns that many people have with these bills.

SPEECH.PARA: For the record, as my colleague Senator Faulkner has already indicated, Labor is supportive of the need to reform and simplify the present act. We believe that such an aspiration is simply axiomatic. We recognised this need and we instituted a process to reform the act when we were in government. However, from our perspective, the scope of such reform needs to be spelled out honestly and clearly to the parliament and the Australian public.

The Public Service Bill 1997 is yet another example in our perspective of the government essentially falling over itself to push its industrial relations agenda, which is contained in the Workplace Relations Act. We believe this has highlighted the mistrust this government has of the Public Service. I suspect, if one were to go through public comments in Hansard made by now government ministers, one would find that mistrust of the Public Service certainly there. Also I suspect that these bills are a fast-tracking vehicle for further downsizing of the Public Service, which has deleterious effects on not only regional economies but also services provided to the public—so it is not simply an economic consequence but also a social consequence.

The government has shown that it is quite adept at window dressing its real intentions—and again I refer to the Workplace Relations Act. But I believe it is important that the government now stop what is clearly a deceptive activity and spell out very clearly its agenda to the Australian community, because I can assure the chamber that the agenda is very clear to us.

An example of the government's doublespeak is before us now. The government has stated that these bills in part are to simplify the Public Service. We regard that as a laudable aspiration. Whilst that may be the case, it should be noted that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts does not accept that all the changes would result in simplification. Recommendation 14 of the report states:
The Public Services Regulations dealing with review of Australian Public Service employment actions must be redrafted, in a way which is, at least, simple, clear and concise.

I do not regard that as being a particularly onerous ask. For the record, we believe that the redrafted regulations need to do a lot more than that. It does not sound as if the stated objective of simplification was given that much priority by the government in drafting this legislation. I submit to the chamber that the government's proposed changes, with or without amendments, have in fact very little to do with simplification or retaining an apolitical Public Service.

From my perspective, I can say to the chamber and the Australian public that the primary motivation of this government through these bills is, as Senator Cooney has referred to, widespread and radical change—not unlike what we regarded as the furphy of the alleged technical changes to the Workplace Relations Act, which gave even greater power to the Employment Advocate, powers which we believe will further result in workers being disadvantaged. I notice a Democrat amendment has been circulated about that, and I will come to that later.

The result of this simplification is a confusing range of regulations that will encourage inconsistency and inequities between agencies and between Public Service employees. From the very beginning of this term this government has been attacking the Public Service. Let us look at the empirical evidence for that. We have seen 30,000 jobs cut from the Public Service, and from May 1996 to May 1997 the number of Australians in public sector employment decreased by 92,800 according to ABS statistics. These are the straight job losses; they do not take into account the multiplier effect, which has been cited in a number of reports as at least two. In regional economies the multiplier effect is higher than that. For every single public sector job you take out of a regional economy, some of the estimates that I have read say the consequence can be up to three or four. In my home of state of Tasmania, which has the highest unemployment rate in the country, cutbacks in the public sector have had a devastating effect in terms of service delivery and the economy.

A further testament to what we regard as the wholesale butchery of the Public Service is the subsuming of the Department of Administrative Services into the Department of Finance and Administration, and the sackings of departmental secretaries, which we have heard about over the last 18 months. The Department of Administrative Services case was fairly interesting. I heard earlier some reference to whistleblowers. I wonder what the motivation is behind the subsuming of the Department of Administrative Services with regard to the so-called `travelgate' episode—if you cannot get the whistleblower, you abolish the department. Simply, this type of initiative cannot be tolerated. These bills will go quite a way towards endorsing the use of whistleblowers as scapegoats. This is something that we obviously do not agree with.

The deep mistrust that this government has of the Public Service is manifestly obvious. This government wants to make employees in the Public Service live in fear of losing their jobs. It wants a Public Service which is beholden to the government. It wants a Public Service, as Senator Cooney said, of 1,000—I cannot remember what he said now, but it was good—

TALK.START.PARA: —Flatterers.

—Yes, flatterers. From my non-literary perspective, it would be a Public Service full of yes‐people, which is the same thing. If this is not the aspiration of the government, then why attack the conditions of employment with regard to tenure of public servants? Why do that? Why give agency heads the virtually unfettered right to hire and fire? Why seek, as I understand the initial draft of the bill, to exempt dismissals from the unfair dismissal provisions if it were not to make public servants more insecure and less likely to blow the whistle, as it were, or less likely to provide courageous advice without fear or favour?

SPEECH.PARA: Why else would the government originally want to do away with the Merit Protection Commissioner and require only the Public Service to be—and this is from the original explanatory memorandum—`responsive to the government in providing timely advice'? That is a very interesting quote. I am not quite sure what `timely advice' is. I think it is a variation on `Don't call us; we'll call you'.

The government, prior to the JCPA's recommendation, was not interested in honest and frank advice—a longstanding principle in the Public Service; and one which has been there for decades and is evident in the best of public sectors elsewhere. This government, clearly as is evidenced by these bills, cannot come to terms with a Public Service that not only serves a government but also serves the public, as Senator Faulkner said in his original remarks. The Labor Party believes that the effect of these bills, if not amended, will create a pliable Public Service, one which may be easily moulded by the government and full of `a thousand flatterers'. By the time the government has finished downsizing the Public Service, it will probably only be 1,000 anyway.

The government, whilst claiming to entrench the traditional values of the Australian Public Service as an apolitical and non‐partisan Public Service, is in fact attempting to do the reverse with this legislation. A number of witnesses before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts commented that, if the bill were implemented in its current form, it would undermine the values traditionally thought to be important in the APS.

The JCPA report listed a number of the concerns of witnesses before the committee. I would like to briefly mention them. It was argued that the original bill would change the APS from a public service to a government service—a very important distinction; destroy the APS as a career service; erode the quality of advice provided to government; increase the risk that the APS would be politicised; destroy the cohesion of the APS; result in a loss of Public Service values; ignore the qualities of people who choose public service as a career—that is very important; and significantly weaken the parliament—also extremely important in terms of transparency and accountability.
Principal among those expressing these types of concerns was Sir Lenox Hewitt, the former Secretary of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, who has served a number of governments. He stated:
I think it will go right to the heart of good government. It—
I interpolate `the bill'—
will detract, because what has been an outstanding Public Service will not maintain the quality that it had under the conditions of service that were introduced at Federation.

I congratulate the government and I am glad to hear that the government has listened to the concerns expressed by the JCPA and has adopted in whole or in part the recommendations made by that committee. I am also glad to hear that this government accepts that there are certain fundamental services which a citizen should receive, not that there are many services left with regard to the Public Service, and the list of these services is getting shorter with each parliamentary sitting as we see the subsuming of departments, the cutting of services and so on.

We on this side of the chamber believe that maintaining a career Public Service is vital to the well-being of any government and the Australian community. We certainly concur with the arguments of Sir Lenox Hewitt who suggested in his evidence before the JCPA that this legislation in its original form would have destroyed the APS as a career service.

It was with interest that I noted the comments of Minister Kemp in dealing with the need for secretaries to provide frank and honest advice to government. As already mentioned, the government's original proposal was only for timely advice. We have a bit of a shift there—we have moved from timely advice to frank, honest, comprehensive, accurate and timely advice. It is nice to see that the change in emphasis has been made. But my concern has to do with the minister's comment in his second reading speech on the bills. Minister Kemp said:
I must say that I have found no evidence that secretaries are less frank and fearless in their advice today . . .

What I want to say about this is that it is impossible for the minister to make that type of personal judgment because he has no direct experience of the quality of advice he would receive under the proposed bill. Up till now, all the advice that he has received from secretaries has been under existing provisions and the existing legislation. So I think that that really is an endorsement of the APS as it currently stands rather than evidence going to the fact that the APS needs a radical overhaul.

The principle of frank, honest and accurate advice from public servants has played an important part in the traditions of the Public Service and has sent out a very clear message to Australia that candour and quality of advice that they receive from the Public Service is paramount. It is also a sad reflection of this government that they had to be more than a little reminded of the importance of this principle by the JCPA report and the witnesses who gave evidence before that committee.

Another concern which was also mentioned by Senator Faulkner originally is the lack of assurances given by the minister with regard to the issues of mobility of public servants between the APS and government bodies. The minister accepted the JCPA's recommendation that a transitional period of up to three years be allowed for those public servants with current mobility rights to decide whether they wish to return to the APS or remain in their current employment. Whether the transitional period is 12 months or three years or whatever, the government's intention of allowing agency heads the discretion to determine their own arrangement as best suits their needs has the potential to limit or restrict the mobility of staff between the Public Service and governmental bodies. This mobility provision has provided many advantages, not the least being the recruitment of expertise and talent.

The ability for staff to move between the Public Service and Parliament House, to use one example, has been of great benefit to both institutions. I do not think that anybody here would disagree with that. The security afforded to public servants by the recognition of the mobility rights provisions has been invaluable in being able to attract public servants from other areas of government. It has resulted in the type of crosspollination which adds to the Public Service and adds to the quality of advice that the Public Service provides the government and the executive. Under the bill, the ability of the parliament to attract public servants it wants is seriously curtailed to say the least, particularly when it is considered within the scope of power that agency heads may be given under this bill.

Another concern I would like to talk about briefly is the issue of merit based selection. It is absolutely essential that merit remains a fundamental principle in the selection process. It is essential that procedures that ensure that merit is a fundamental basis of selection be enshrined and maintained in the Public Service Act. This side of the chamber welcomes the government's decision to support an independent Merit Protection Commissioner to review employment decisions as clearly a commonsense decision. A bouquet to the government for that. However, I have a number of reservations regarding this issue. Those reservations have to do with the need to ensure that the independence of the commissioner is not eroded and that the commissioner be required to report directly to parliament.

BREAK.PARA: There has been a lot of concern about the creation of fiefdoms in the Public Service, and given the government's proposal whereby the Prime Minister and ministers will be able to set agency head terms and conditions, and agency heads will have the power to hire and fire and set terms and conditions and so on for agency employees, I believe that this concern is well and truly justified. This proposal by the government, and I quote again from the JCPA report, `constitutes significant departure from current practice.' They said it. It is significantly different from current practice.

Not only is it a significant departure, but it is highly likely to promote an ethos of advancement because you are a mate, or it is highly likely to create a cultural cronyism, or it is highly likely to create a culture of `Yes' people, as we referred to before, instead of merit. This is why the Merit Protection Commissioner's role must be strengthened. The government has said that it wants to maintain the traditional ethos and values of an apolitical and non‐partisan public service. but these changes are, I believe, completely contradictory to the stated aim.

This proposal would create an environment where people are hired for their loyalty rather than commitment to public service. This proposal, I believe, would see the demise of an apolitical public service. I believe the reason behind this proposal is once again to push inter alia the government's workplace relations agenda which will see the undermining of collective agreements. We will see the push by this government to introduce Australian workplace agreements on a take it or leave it basis. I note that the Democrats have circulated an amendment which indicates that agency heads should not enter into AWAs with employees. I say to the Democrats: it is a bit late, because in fact AWAs are well and truly entrenched in the public sector, not only at the SES level but also at levels throughout the public sector.

I would like to point out to the chamber what is happening with regard to the creation of the new PEPE, in terms of the creation of an employment services market, to show exactly what this means; we have a situation whereby workers wishing to transfer to the PEPE will be required to sign an AWA or they will not be employed. I appreciate that the government may say, `Ah yes, but the PEPE is now an incorporated body,' but basically AWAs are already there in the Public Service. The degree of duress involved is very difficult to prove because of the lack of transparency with regard to the AWA process. Agreements will create a situation whereby employees will be potentially doing the same work but on different pay scales. We will see employees potentially working side by side with different pay scales and conditions; that is, if the AWA situation is entered into.

But even so, the provisions of this bill in terms of the current Workplace Relations Act will provide for agency heads to say to somebody in, say, my home state, `You work in the tax office in Hobart; your pay level is X, and to somebody else who works in the tax office in Sydney you are going to get paid more—' or less, or whatever. So it allows other variables, like cost of living and so on, to be taken into account irrespective of the nature of the work undertaken. That is something that I do not think any fair‐minded Australian wants to see.

We will be moving amendments, amongst others, which seek to impose reasonable limits on the power of the agency heads, and in particular to prevent them from taking action which would diminish the provisions of an award or a certified agreement. We support a strong, unified and apolitical public service. We believe that to achieve this aim, and the aim of the simplification, the amendments that Labor will be putting forward must be passed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me thank senators from the Democrats and the opposition for their contribution today. A number of points have arisen, and I will deal with each in turn although somewhat briefly, because I think a lot of these issues can be canvassed during the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I say that in relation to the motion moved by the Democrats, and that is that there be a period of time whereby this bill is not debated so that regulations and the guidelines or commissioner's directions can be settled, is not acceptable to the government. The government is of the view that it would not be possible to prepare final versions of those until the bill had been passed.

As has been mentioned earlier, draft regulations were made available to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and also to senators from the opposition and minor parties. As well as that, there has been a good deal of scrutiny in relation to this bill. We have had a lengthy consultation process. We looked at some 300 submissions. There was consultation with over 1,500 people, many of whom were public servants at all levels.

Senator Allison from the Democrats has mentioned that there were focus groups which looked at this bill. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts handed down a thoroughly professional and comprehensive report. The Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee also took evidence and handed down a report. The minister has mentioned in the other place that the government has taken on board many of the recommendations made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and those amendments have now been incorporated in the bill.

As far as the whistleblowers provisions are concerned—and I note Senator Murray's comments in relation to that; I know that that is something that he has been involved with during his time here—the government is of view that this is not the vehicle for such legislation. In fact on page 64 the joint committee recognised `that the Public Service Bill 1997 is not the ideal framework within which to provide an extensive whistleblower protection scheme.' It is a view shared by the government. This aspect has been referred to the Attorney‐General, who is now looking at it I am advised, and I think that is an appropriate course of action.

As far as tenure of employment is concerned—a number of senators mentioned this—it is the government's view that this bill does not undermine employment arrangements for public servants. The main avenue for setting pay and conditions for public servants will continue to be via agreements under the Workplace Relations Act. It is considered that these agreements are underpinned by the protection afforded by that act and the no disadvantage test ensures that, taken as a whole, employees will not be worse off under those agreements. The government has looked at the proposed amendments put forward by the opposition and the Democrats and does not support or agree with those amendments. Therefore, in the committee stage we will not be agreeing to those proposed amendments.

The government acknowledges the very important job that the Australian Public Service carries out. I for one, as a minister and as a backbencher in opposition, have been very impressed by the standard of officers I have dealt with. I believe that those comments were reinforced by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) in the other place. What we are looking at here is a long overdue reform. The common thread in the submissions by a number of senators has been that we do need to reform this 1922 act, which has been amended over 100 times.

It was the last government that commissioned the McLeod report and was on its way to reforming this legislation. The starting point is that there is virtual unanimity in the need for reformation. I refer to comments made by other senators in relation to that. At the end of the day, the government will be proceeding with this bill as one which will reform the Australian Public Service, which will benefit both the Australian public service and the people of Australia. The government is unable to agree to the amendments which have been foreshadowed by both the Democrats and the opposition.

That the amendment (Senator Allison's ) be agreed to.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TAB.TAB: (ba) to define the powers and responsibilities of Agency Heads, the Public Service Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner; and

SPEECH.PARA: I indicate to the committee in a general sense that, as all senators would be aware, there is an enormous amount of legislative business before the Senate chamber over the next couple of days and, of course, before we break for Christmas, given the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is to be dealt with by the Senate before the conclusion of our sittings this year. Because of that, it will not be my intention to call unnecessary divisions during this committee stage debate.

BREAK.PARA: I will be listening with interest to the contributions of minor party and Independent senators on their approach to amendments that are before the chair. Except on matters of significant principle, the opposition will be making judgments accordingly, and I do hope that the same level of goodwill is demonstrated by others. I think that will assist the process to move along so we do not have to have a very significant number of divisions, the outcome of which might be clear to the committee.

I hope the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) accepts that contribution in the spirit that it is given. Obviously, I will be limiting my remarks as much as I can, given the very significant number of amendments before the chair, again, in order to allow this debate to progress as quickly as is possible in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you move some of the amendments together?

—I have the running sheet before me, Minister, and, if that is possible to achieve, obviously the opposition is happy to be cooperative in that regard. But this is a complex committee stage debate. I know that other senators are keen to make a significant contribution at times during the debate. Wherever that is practicable, as far as the opposition is concerned, we will obviously, again, be willing to facilitate debate. I am keen to work cooperatively with Senator Allison, who I think is primarily handling this for the Australian Democrats, Senator Harradine and others who will be making a contribution.

BREAK.PARA: Having made that very brief opening gambit in relation to the committee stage debate, let me turn now to the amendment. In the interests of balance and completeness, this amendment adds to the objects of the Public Service Bill 1997 . It seems to me that it would be odd here to refer to the rights and obligations of APS employees which, as senators can see, are embraced within subclause (c), as proposed, without mention of the role and responsibilities of agency heads and the commissions. As far as the opposition is con cerned, we are proposing related amendments at clauses 57 and 66. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would it not be better to leave this amendment until after we see what the committee does with the subsequent amendments to be moved by Senator Faulkner?

—Prior to the dinner break, I indicated to the committee that this amendment might best be left until the committee dealt with the other amendments to see whether it was still needed, but I have not got a firm view on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it assists Senator Harradine and the committee, I am happy to deal with this amendment at a later stage. If Senator Harradine would prefer it if the amendment were postponed, I am happy for that to happen.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

designated group means any of the following classes of persons:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

SPEECH.PARA: I thought the intention of all parties was to streamline the bill and to have a less unwieldy piece of legislation. I am just wondering whether there is a need to clutter up the legislation with things that will be dealt with in other material that is before us. TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 7, page 5 (after line 22), after the definition of locally engaged employee , insert:

merit , in relation to the engagement and promotion of employees, means assessment of the relative suitability of candidates for employment or promotion using a competitive selection process, where the assessment is:

TAB.TAB: (a) based on the relationship between a candidate's work‐related qualities and the work‐related qualities identified by the Agency as required for the job; and
(b) the sole consideration in a decision to engage or promote an employee.

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Clause 10, page 8 (lines 1 to 12), omit subclause (2).
(21) Clause 22, page 12 (after line 17), after subclause (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) The Commissioner, in consultation with Agency Heads, is to operate a merit‐based selection process for entry‐level recruitment of APS employees.

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Page 13 (after line 5), after clause 22, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 22A Engagement and promotion based on merit

TAB.TAB: The engagement or promotion of an APS employee for any period in excess of 3 months must be on the basis of merit.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to opposition amendment No. 3, which I think is one of the most important amendments that we are to deal with in this committee stage debate, the government has agreed—following some extensive deliberation on this particular issue during the JCPA inquiry and also a very clear recommendation from the JCPA—to include a definition of `merit' in the legislation in clause 10 values. We believe it is more appropriate here in the interpretation section where it will have application throughout the act.

Our definition also requires that merit be the sole rather than the primary consideration, as in the government definition. We are concerned that `primary' denotes that other factors could be considered, in which case the merit principle would be compromised. I would be interested to hear the government's view on this particular matter. If the government agreed to drop part (d) of clause 10(2), I do not think there would be any need for the opposition to pursue this issue and we could effectively drop our (b).

Opposition amendment No. 10 effectively relates to the government's definition of merit. If opposition amendment No. 3 is successful, there will obviously be a need to delete (2), as provided for in opposition amendment No. 10.

In relation to opposition amendment No. 21, the bill proposes to devolve all appointment powers to agency heads. This will encourage what I have indicated in my second reading speech: division and fragmentation of Australian Public Service agencies as well as what I think will be unnecessary duplication of recruitment procedures.

The opposition's amendment is an attempt to balance such fragmentation by maintaining a central APS‐wide recruitment process. We believe that it will also have the effect of helping to maintain the Australian Public Service as a career service. It is more efficient than each department running its own entry level recruitment. The opposition believes that this is good public policy, in other words, there is an opportunity for the government to provide employment opportunities for young people.

Opposition amendment No. 23 would preserve application of the merit principle. The government's draft directions provide for a 12‐month threshold which we believe would totally undermine the merit principle. The current threshold is three months, unless the Public Service Commission determines otherwise after consultation with the relevant staff organisation or organisations. I believe that these four amendments do have merit, and I certainly commend them to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrats will be supporting each of the opposition's amendments. In particular, we strongly endorse the inclusion of `merit' in the act. We think it should be the sole determinant of employment decisions. We urge the government to accept this amendment, not just as a primary consideration but as the principal consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government cannot agree to this amendment. It takes that position because APS values are set out in clause 10 of the bill. In particular, 10(1)(b) says:

SPEECH.PARA: the APS is a public service in which employment decisions are based on merit.

The JCPA talked about selecting the best person. Although the government agreed with the recommendation to some extent, it thought the wording itself was not as workable and prefers the path that it has taken in relation to clause 10.

Of course, you do have the Public Service Commissioner's directions, a draft copy of which has been circulated, and that deals with, among other things, merit in employment. In fact, some pages are devoted to that very point in that document. Chapter 3, Merit Employment, deals with engagement and promotion, engagement of employees, persons who accept voluntary redundancy payments and promotion of employees. So the government says that this is adequately covered in the bill—that these are covered in the values and directions which I have referred to, that it would be cumbersome to incorporate this in the bill and that not much is gained by that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, a propos of that, would you agree that clause 10 of the government's legislation is advisory—in other words, it says, `Look, it would be nice if you could approach things on this basis', whereas what the opposition and the Democrats are putting forward entrenches the idea of merit in the legislation and makes it mandatory?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not have thought that the APS values in clause 10 are advisory. They are set out in the act and they are binding. The directions which I mentioned are subject to the scrutiny of parliament, they are disallowable, and they have effect as well. So I am saying that both in the bill and in the directions you have a force of sanction; it is not as if they are just there as advice only for the government to choose whether it ignores or not.

—If you adopted what the opposition amendments suggest, those amendments would enable someone to take an action in court to enforce them. The APS values are not enforceable in court; they are just values that are stated, and there is no provision anywhere that enforces them. The APS code of conduct in clause 13 might be able to enforced under clause 15 as a breach of those conducts, but there is no machinery by which you can enforce clause 10.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very good point that you make, Senator Cooney, and I will take it up with the department. I am advised that the improvement you have here is that the current legislation does not have anything of this sort, so you do have an avenue for public servants to lodge a grievance—if that is what you are getting at. If you are talking about what avenue a public servant has for redress against a decision which he or she thinks has been unfairly taken, then it could be done by way of a grievance. But at present there is nothing like that available in any event. Whether or not it could be taken in a court by way of some sort of injunction is questionable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been told not to take too long, but I think that this goes to the very centre of the difference between this and the other side of the chamber. As I understand it, this side of the chamber says, `Irrespective of what has happened up until now, induction into the Public Service and promotion within it ought to be on merit and that ought to be a centrepiece of the legislation and should be enforceable by people who are denied either induction or promotion on merit.'

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments moved by the opposition and supported by the Democrats would entrench that regime into the legislation whereas, if it is left to clause 10, then merit is a hope—and I do not say this in any derogatory sense—but it would be a pious hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the minister and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate might have a look at whether we could split the vote on amendments 3, 10, 21 and 23, leaving out No. 21 and voting on it separately. The reason I say that is that I am inclined to agree to amendment No. 3. I think this question of merit is very important. I can see the logic of the argument that has been advanced by the mover on the question of merit. Of course, amendment No. 10, as I understand it—unless you can correct me—is consequential; it is to omit subclause (2) of clause 10. No. 23 deals with engagement and promotion based on merit.

SPEECH.PARA: But amendment No. 21 is a different kettle of fish. It really is to concentrate all of it into the hands of the commissioner. I do not think that will be necessary if you have the definition of merit and the requirement as to merit actually in the legislation. I know that the minister has said that it is in the directions. I have had a look at page 8 of the commission's directions. Yes, it is there, but I think the key point there, as mentioned in the opposition's amendment, is the key qualifier; that is, that the sole consideration and deci sion to engage or promote an employee is merit.

Under those circumstances, I am inclined to agree with amendments Nos 3, 10 and 23 put forward by Senator Faulkner but to oppose amendment No. 21. Clearly, Recruitment Services Australia would need to have regard to the merit principle, as included in the legislation, if Senator Faulkner's other three amendments are accepted. Unless I hear anything that is otherwise convincing, I would endorse and support those three and oppose 21.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put the amendments as requested. The question is that amendments Nos 3, 10 and 23 be agreed to.
—The question now is that amendment No. 21 be agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I explained at the beginning of the committee stage of the debate, even though this is an important amendment, I believe we can progress this committee stage without calling for divisions. I appreciate Senator Harradine's thorough explanation of his approach on this. In the interests of seeing the committee stage of debate move along, in this circumstance the opposition will not be calling a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 8, page 6 (line 11), omit "This", substitute "Subject to subsection 20(1A), this".
(4) Clause 20, page 12 (after line 7), after subclause (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) An Agency Head must not enter into an Australian Workplace Agreement, within the meaning of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 , with an APS employee.
(1B) The regulations may prescribe exemptions from the requirement set out in subsection (1A), in relation to particular categories of APS employees.

TAB.TAB: Note: For example, a particular category of APS employees could include "SES employees of the X Agency".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments specifically prevent agency heads from entering into individual workplace agreements with APS employees. We are moving these amendments for two reasons. Firstly, the secretive nature of AWAs precludes full accountability for the expenditure of taxpayers' funds. It would enable deals to be made between agency heads and APS employees and these deals would not be open to the public for scrutiny. Secondly, it would enable different terms and conditions to be set for the same job, something which the Democrats do not consider appropriate or desirable within the public service context.

I note that the Queensland government has also rejected the idea that individual agreements can be signed within its public service for precisely these reasons. Peter Reith's initial discussion paper also suggested that such a move was not appropriate. As we recognise that there may be occasions when an AWA is appropriate, the amendments allow for regulations to exempt particular categories of employees from this provision.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrat amendments 1 and 4 are consistent with our opposition to AWAs in the context of the debate on the government's Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 . It would also be consistent with our understanding of the government's position that AWAs would not be used widely in the public service where certified agreements would be the preferred instrument. In that context, the opposition will support these two Democrat amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments and does so because of the complexity that would be added by requiring a regulation to be made before particular categories of employees can be offered AWAs. This is an unnecessary limitation in our view and it should be a matter for agency heads to decide with their employees. Several agencies have already entered into AWAs with groups of employees, mainly senior executive people, and they have been endorsed by the Employment Advocate who is required to assess them against the no‐disadvantage test.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to accountability, there is no reason why public service agencies should not have access to all the flexibilities of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act. In that regard, as it relates to these AWAs, agencies will be continued to require to report in their annual reports on the numbers of employees whose remuneration package is more than $100,000 per annum. For those reasons—the complexity, the accountability and the fact that the public service should have the same access to these agreements as the private sector—the government would oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I imagine that it will come as no surprise to the committee to realise that, as with Senator Faulkner, I certainly will not be supporting these amendments. I do so for reasons other than those given by the senator who moved them—that is, because the Queensland government has rejected this idea. I am very pleased to hear that the Queensland government has done that! In all seriousness, we have gone over the tracks on this particular matter time and time again, both inside and outside this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot help but remind the Democrats that when their former leader was leading the Democrats they voted for AWAs. In this particular context, I believe that the committee would be—and I am glad to see that the Democrats are putting this forward—well advised to vote against AWAs in this sort of Public Service context.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to opposition amendment No. 4 on sheet 695.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 8, page 6 (after line 11), after subclause (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) Subsection (1) does not apply to section 170LZ(4) of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and to regulation 30ZE and schedule 5 of the Workplace Relations Regulations to the extent that they would preclude conditions contained in subsections 22(5), (6) and (7) and sections 23, 24, 25, 27, 28, 29, 33 and 65 of this Act being displaced by a certified agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Service Bill 1997 and the Workplace Relations Act would impact on employment arrangements in the APS. The opposition is concerned to avoid the situation where a range of matters proposed to be removed, varied or included in the Public Service legislation would be excluded from the bargaining process, due to the operation of section 170LZ(4) of the Workplace Relations Act, which has particular impact on APS employment.

The capacity for negotiations resulting in provisions in certified agreements under the Workplace Relations Act is important in a number of areas covered by the Public Service Bill 1997 : subsections 22(6), (7) and (8), engagement of APS employees, categories of employment; section 23, classification rules; section 24, remuneration and other conditions; section 25, assignment of duties; section 27, compulsory moves between agencies; section 28, suspension; section 29, termination of employment; section 33, review of actions; and section 65, machinery of government changes.

This can be illustrated by the provisions relating to the engagement of APS employees. The opposition proposes that section 22(5) be included in the Public Service Act to provide that, subject to the act and to relevant awards and certified agreements, a person be engaged as an APS employee on a permanent basis unless fixed term provisions apply.

A certified agreement might elaborate on the arrangements for engagement of fixed term employees. Section 170LZ of the Workplace Relations Act limits displacement by a certified agreement if conditions of employment specified in a Commonwealth law to prescribed conditions of employment are specified in a Commonwealth law that is prescribed by regulation.

BREAK.PARA: Regulation 30ZE under the Workplace Relations Act prescribes as Commonwealth law the Public Service ACT 1922 and the Public Service Regulations and determinations under the Public Service Act 1922. Various conditions of employment contained in the 1922 act and regulations are prescribed in schedule 5 of the regulations. Regulations 30ZE and schedule 5 need to be replaced if the Public Service Act 1922 and its regulations are repealed.

The opposition is seeking agreement from the government that regulation 30ZE and schedule 5 would be amended to permit inclusion in certified agreements of employment conditions encompassed in subsections 22(6), (7) and (8) and in sections 23, 24, 25, 27, 28, 29, 33 and 65 of the act and contained in other provisions of the bill or the Public Service Regulations which are appropriate for inclusion in certified agreements.

In the event—and the minister might care to respond on this point—that the government is willing to support the approach I have outlined, the opposition would not proceed with our proposal for a new subclause 1A to be included in clause 8 of the Public Service Bill 1997 to provide that subclause 1A does not apply to section 170LZ(4) of the Workplace Relations Act and to regulation 30ZE and to schedule 5 of the Workplace Relations Regulations, to the extent that they preclude conditions contained in sections 22(5), (6) and (7) and 23, 24, 25, 27, 28, 29, 33 and 65 of the act being displaced by a certified agreement. Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, perhaps the minister might indicate to me whether, on behalf of the government, he is willing to give the committee some sort of undertaking in those terms.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be wise to defer this amendment. No doubt we will be continuing with the committee stage debate tomorrow. The government would like to take some little time to have a look at this amendment. The opposition is putting forward a serious proposition, and it is taken in that vein. Certainly, I cannot give you an undertaking one way or another at this stage. I would seek that the amendment be deferred. We could perhaps come back to it with those other matters that we have left to be considered at a later hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move opposition amendments Nos 5 to 9:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 10, page 7 (lines 14 and 15), omit "recognises the diverse backgrounds of APS employees", substitute "that reflects the diverse nature of the community it serves".
(6) Clause 10, page 7 (line 24), at the end of paragraph (g), add "using procedures which are transparent".
(7) Clause 10, page 7 (lines 26 and 27), omit paragraph (i), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) the APS establishes co‐operative and participative workplace relations based on consultation, communication and negotiation;

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Clause 10, page 7 (lines 28 and 29), omit "a fair, flexible, safe and rewarding workplace", substitute:

TAB.TAB: its employees with:
(i) a fair, flexible, safe, healthy and rewarding workplace free from harassment; and
(ii) remuneration rates and conditions of employment commensurate with their responsibilities; and
(iii) fair and consistent treatment, free of arbitrary or capricious administrative acts or decisions; and
(iv) the right to be represented by unions; and
(v) opportunities for appropriate training and development; and
(vi) opportunities for appropriate participation in the decision‐making processes of the Agency in which they are employed.

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 10, page 7 (line 31), at the end of the clause, add:

TAB.TAB: ; (l) the APS promotes equity in employment;
(m) the APS provides a reasonable opportunity to all eligible members of the community to apply for APS employment;
(n) the APS is a career‐based service to enhance the effectiveness and cohesion of Australia's democratic system of government;
(o) the APS provides a fair system of review of decisions taken in respect of APS employees.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend to the committee these amendments on APS values to clause 10 of the bill. Opposition amendment No. 5 is important from an EEO perspective. It is clearly less important, from an EEO perspective, to have the APS recognising `the diverse backgrounds of APS employees' than to ensure that the APS employs people from diverse backgrounds.

Opposition amendment No. 6 is self-explanatory. I might say there is no other mention in the bill of the need for transparency of APS procedures, which is an important element of APS accountability to the parliament and to the public. Opposition amendment No. 7 is also very important, in our view. This bill removes all of the current act's provisions on industrial democracy. We think the legislation should at least recognise that APS management's responsibilities go beyond consultation and communication with the work force to include negotiation.

In relation to opposition amendment No. 8, we say that legislation which expands the powers of agency heads and puts such emphasis on the responsibilities and obligations of APS employees should at least contain a brief statement of their rights and entitlements. This is, in fact, a condensed version of the statement of rights and entitlements that was recommended by Mr McLeod in his report.

We believe that all the values in opposition amendment No.9 are of sufficient importance to be included in clause 10: subclause (l) is taken from the heading of clause 18; paragraph (m) is based on the language of section 33(1)(a) in the current act; paragraph (n) is designed to help preserve the APS as a career service, which is essential if it is to remain an effective repository of knowledge about government administration and service delivery; and paragraph (o) reflects the importance of having an independent appeal mechanism. These are all important values. I commend amendments Nos 5 to 9 to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) would like to indicate that, on these and the other ALP amendments, we will be voting with the opposition.

—I just indicate that the Democrats will also support amendments Nos 5 to 9. We believe it is important to have these matters included in the APS values. What we have here is a highly simplified and streamlined bill. In those circumstances, we think it is particularly important for the APS values to be set out as comprehensively as possible. We do not think it is good enough for the government to seek to minimise the list of APS values just for the sake of simplification. After all, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) has just said that the values are binding; so I think we have some responsibility to get them right.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could put it this way: whilst the bill contains aspects such as a code of conduct and APS values, it seeks to be as non-prescriptive as possible. It is the government's view that these amendments would result in over‐prescription and that, in particular, there could well be some overlapping with the Workplace Relations Act. You could even have some tension between the two pieces of legislation because, when you look at them as a whole, you could have different interpretations on what is applicable. The government's view is that the opposition is attempting to visit some sort of change on the Workplace Relations Act. The reason the government would oppose these amendments is to avoid having duplication and over‐prescription.

—I can understand the proposition that you want to reduce the legislative prescription in so far as it relates to the Public Service, but it seems to me that you are not doing that. The government is, in effect, moving away from prescription by way of primary legislation to prescription by way of subordinate legislation. I do not want to go through it all, but this bill requires regulations to be made and directions to be given in writing. I won der how accurate it is to say that this new regime moves away from prescription.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill moves away from prescription, but it is true that through its subordinate legislation, which is subject to parliamentary scrutiny, there are directions. Of course, those directions allow some flexibility. For instance, one of the things that was touched on earlier was diversity in employment. That is contained in chapter 2 of the Public Service Commissioner's directions. The government has avoided having an unwieldy piece of legislation which lumbers along like some leviathan. It is better to do it through subordinate legislation which is more flexible but which still enjoys the scrutiny of the parliament.

—If we move away from primary legislation to subordinate legislation, is there not a high risk that you move away from accountability to control? So that the people making the regulations would be in a better position to control the Public Service rather than to hold it accountable. If it is set out in primary legislation, it is much easier to make the Public Service accountable rather than control it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —On that point, the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances are two very good committees of the Senate which look at legislation and subordinate legislation. They are very good avenues that this Senate uses to keep an eye on these sorts of things and, of course, there is a disallowance procedure. They do provide some accountability, and the government would think sufficiently so in this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This disallowance procedure, as all senators know, is sudden death. You have only an opportunity of disallowing some subordinate legislation. The impacts of such a course of action are often quite significant. Again, that is something which the Senate is very aware of. Of course, if such provisions are contained within the primary legislation itself, you do have an opportunity to change or amend such legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very blunt instrument which is being proposed by the minister, and I would be surprised if any minister would like to encourage an opposition to use it. The minister is not alone in propounding these arguments. This is something that was argued with some vigour by the one or two supporters of the new public service bills through the extensive committee stage debate and public debate that has ensued around this legislation. For the very obvious reasons I have outlined, and which Senator Cooney has addressed, it is an approach of which the weaknesses are well known to this chamber and to all senators who sit in it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition amendment No. 5 is much of a muchness. We are talking about the workplace there, and I cannot see that I should support the amendment. I think that what is in the APS values, as proposed by the government, is adequate; that is, that the APS values and recognises the diverse backgrounds of APS employees. It is much of a muchness, and I would oppose amendment No. 5.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to opposition amendment No. 6, I could see situations, possibly, where using procedures which are transparent might indeed adversely affect somebody or place two clients at odds with each other at a particular stage. I am not inclined to support amendment No. 6.

I am in two minds in regard to amendment No. 7. It is indicated at lines 26 and 27 on page 7 of the legislation that the APS establishes cooperative workplace relations based on consultation and communication. The only extension of that is negotiation. I suppose that is neither here nor there. If the government sees a problem in that regard, it may also see a problem when it comes to negotiating certain situations which may impinge upon the work of the department. Any competent manager would be undertaking consultations and proper communications with his or her staff. I cannot see that amendment No. 7 is necessary.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition amendment No. 8, as Senator Faulkner said, is almost straight out of McLeod. I see merit in amendment No. 8. I hope the government might see merit in amendment No. 8 as well. That is enough said on that.

I guess the government would not object to opposition amendment No. 9. The government seems to be saying that it does not want to clutter up the legislation with all of these things. I suppose there is a need to maintain and retain some stability in the public sector reforms and ensure that they are not totally embracing private sector models.
