So, on balance, I would be inclined to support amendment No. 9. My current situation is to oppose opposition amendments Nos 5, 6 and 7 and support opposition amendments Nos 8 and 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly on opposition amendment No. 5, I hear what Senator Harradine says. Senator Harradine, the issue in relation to amendment No. 5 simply put is that the bill recognises the diverse backgrounds of APS employees. What I am saying is an important issue is that people from diverse backgrounds and from designated groups are employed in the Australian Public Service. So that is the point I would make in response to what you say.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say on this one we do differ quite considerably. I do see a significant difference between what is proposed in this amendment and what the government proposes in terms of just recognising diverse backgrounds of APS employees.
Amendment No. 5 not agreed to.
Amendment No. 6 not agreed to.
Amendment No. 7 not agreed to.
Amendment No. 8 agreed to.
Amendment No. 9 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 10, page 7 (after line 31), at the end of subclause (1), add:

PARA.TAB: (l) the APS ensures that services provided on behalf of the APS are delivered fairly, effectively, impartially, courteously and transparently;
(m) the APS ensures that the Commonwealth's best practice standards are used in selecting consultants and in public reporting on the engagement of consultants;
(n) the APS ensures that any contracting or tendering processes are open and competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment adds new values to the list of APS values in the bill. These additional values seek to impose on the APS a requirement to ensure that services provided on its behalf—that is, services which are contracted out—meet the same criteria as in-house services. It also ensures that any contracting or tendering processes are open and competitive and that best practice standards are used in selecting and engaging consultants.

This amendment reflects the Democrats' concern that the bill is silent on the quality and the accountability of contracted out services—services which, after all, involve the use of taxpayers' money. It reflects our wider concern that governments are avoiding accountability by contracting out public services and then in many cases refusing to take full responsibility for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I have not heard argument from the government in respect of this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is that Democrat amendment No. 2 is not appropriate for a piece of legislation that is dealing with the employment of public servants. What you have got here is delivery of service to the public. That is more for a charter of service, which the various departments are introducing from next year. I think most of them have them on their books.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of selecting private consultants again is not for this piece of legislation. That is something which deals with people outside the Public Service. For those reasons, the government believes it is not appropriate to include that amendment here. Accordingly, the government will oppose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do beg to differ with the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison). We believe that these are important issues to be dealt with in this bill, given that we have a government that is hell-bent on contracting out and outsourcing. As far as I am concerned, this amendment—the spirit of which is to apply appropriate values to services which are contracted out—is worthy of support by this committee.

SPEECH.PARA: We in the opposition have been concerned for some time—and we have made those concerns known—that the accountability relationship is distanced by contracting out. We think this is an absolutely crucial issue for the parliament and it is a crucial issue that is properly addressed within a new Public Service act. For those reasons, the opposition is minded to support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Allison on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand what Senator Faulkner said but, again, whether or not this should be in this legislation is another question. The whole point is, whether we like it or not, whichever government is in power, you are going to have certain functions that are contracted out. It is really up to us to ensure that, through various measures that are available to members of parliament, what is indicated here as best practice is observed.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether this should not be dealt with in some other fashion. I think it ought to be dealt with by oversight from the parliament. I am thinking of some agencies that do certain contracting out. I have had arguments in the estimates committees about some of this work, but short of saying that there should be no contracting out, I do not think there is effectively much that can be done other than the minister, aided and abetted by the parliament itself, overseeing what the agency does in this area. If what the agency does is inconsistent with whatever best practice means, then we surely should pursue that in the various areas that we have available to us in the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear Senator Harradine canvassing the issue of the appropriateness or otherwise of these amendments being moved to this legislation. What Senator Harradine needs to consider is the fact that the government proposes no other mechanism for appropriate and effective accountability measures—none whatsoever. If we heard the minister give some commitments to the committee on this issue, it might be appropriate for us to give further thought to what Senator Allison has proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: I do think that it is appropriate for these values to apply to services which are contracted out. I find it most unexceptionable, frankly, that the government might find difficulty in the APS ensuring that any contracting or tendering processes are open and competitive. In the absence of any other commitments about accountability, I think it is appropriate for this committee to support the amendments that Senator Allison has moved. I am not persuaded to undertake any other course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —We do believe that this is appropriate in this bill. Perhaps if the minister could enlighten the committee about what more appropriate legislation there is, we would appreciate that. Public servants will be managing the contracting out process—whether it is tendering, contracting, supervision or any one of the various stages in contracting out—and it is up to the Public Service to do just that.

SPEECH.PARA: We were, after all, told by the minister that this bill is not just about employment of public servants; we were told that it was also about improving the service quality. Surely that means that the Public Service has some responsibility to ensure that its values are reflected in contracted out services. This goes to the issue of quality as well as accountability. I think it is imperative that the bill actually reflects that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, recently in the Senate we passed the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1996. Clause 44, entitled `Promoting efficient, effective and ethical use of Commonwealth resources', requires that the affairs of the agency must be managed in a way which is proper. Proper use means efficient, effective and ethical use. That is squarely a burden which is cast upon the chief executive who manages the agency. I have already mentioned the charter of government service that various departments are bringing in in respect of how they deliver their services to the community. The government believes there are adequate safeguards in place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess that I am very impressed with what Senator Allison says. There has to be a mechanism whereby parliament can inquire into and make amendments to what the administration does. There are three great traditional functions of parliament. Firstly, parliament has always had to approve any money that is spent. The second great principle is that where you have two houses of parliament, both of them have to pass any legislation. The third one, traditionally, has been that parliament should oversee, as it were, the functions of the executive.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the point that the minister has made about the other legislation, but it seems to me that in a piece of legislation that sets out the structure within which the Public Service is to operate, it goes directly to the third function of parliament—parliament's ability to supervise what the Public Service does or what people carrying out government functions do, even though they might not be part of the Public Service. Those bodies ought to be subject to control or at least supervision by parliament within the terms of this legislation.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 11, page 8 (lines 14 to 18), omit subclause (1), substitute:

TAB.TAB: The Commissioner must issue directions in writing in relation to each of the APS Values for the purpose of:
(a) ensuring that the APS incorporates and upholds the APS Values; and
(b) determining where necessary the scope or application of the APS Values.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say in relation to this amendment that I think that it is a very important one in a range of key issues that we have to debate. The values are arguably the centrepiece of the legislation. We believe that their implementation should not be left entirely to the discretion of agency heads. If the commissioner has the responsibility, as the government is proposing, to ensure that the APS incorporates—and, of course, we are proposing to add the words, `and upholds'—the values, then it is logical that the commissioner be required to provide guidance to agency heads about how this is to be achieved.
We believe, therefore, there should be directions in respect of each of the values. Page 26 of the report of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts states:
The Committee would expect the Commissioner's Direction on the APS Values to clarify the meaning and intent of the Values, to the extent that the Values are unclear.

The purpose of the commissioner's directions should surely be not only to ensure that the APS incorporates the APS values, but also that it upholds them. This would be consistent with the terminology used in clause 12. Paragraphs (a) and (b) should be complementary, hence `and' instead of `or'; and the commissioner should only be circumscribing the application of the values where necessary.

Admittedly, this is perhaps a bit woolly, but at least it gives an indication of parliament's concern that the commissioner should only be limiting the application of values where it is absolutely essential—for example, a case of positive discrimination for EEO reasons. As I say, these values are arguably the centrepiece of this legislation. As far as the opposition is concerned, this is an important amendment and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support this amendment. I think it is very important to compel the Public Service Commissioner to issue directions for each of the APS values. I have had a look at the directions and I have to say that it does not actually fill us with much confidence. It simply says that agency heads and APS employees must consider and apply the APS values to ensure that the objects of the act are achieved. Then it goes on to make provision for only diversity in employment, merit in employment and public interest whistleblowing.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no attempt to issue directions about the value that, for instance, `the APS has the highest ethical standards', or that `the APS establishes cooperative workplace relations.' We would argue that there is not much point in having values if the commissioner can pick and choose the ones that they can be bothered issuing directions on. Perhaps the minister could indicate whether the government intends that the commissioner eventually issue directions on each of the APS values or whether what we have before us is the complete set as it were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested in the response to Senator Allison's comments of a moment ago. With regard to Senator Faulkner's amendment 11, I do not know whether this legislation does require it. The amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner must issue directions in writing in relation to each of the APS Values for the purpose of:
(a) ensuring that the APS incorporates and upholds the APS values;

I assume that, where it was necessary, the commissioner would, under the government's proposal, issue those directions. The fact of the matter is, is it not—and the minister might correct me if I am wrong—that the obligation is in fact on the agency heads. Without this direction they are required to observe and uphold the APS values. For example, in clause 12, it is simply stated:
Agency Heads must promote APS values.
Whether or not the commissioner directs them to, they must do that, full stop.

I am inclined to the view, as expressed by the government, that some of these arguments may be just putting things in there for no purpose. I think it is pretty clear in the bill that there is a requirement on agency heads. Clause 13 states:

BREAK.PARA: The APS Code of Conduct
(1) An APS employee must behave honestly and with integrity in the course of APS employment.

I know somewhere it says that they have to uphold APS values. I do not know what the minister might say about that, but I would be interested to hear his response to what Senator Allison said. At this stage I am inclined not to support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The agency head does have the onus of upholding these values. When one looks through the Public Service Commissioner's direction you can see that the onus is cast squarely on the agency head to uphold these.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the amendment at hand, we have here a drafting which I believe really takes us no further. Senator Faulkner referred to the question of upholding the APS values. In the current wording we have:
The Commissioner must issue directions . . . for the purpose of ensuring that the APS incorporates the APS Values;

Of course that goes hand in hand with upholding. The word `incorporate' means a lot more than just writing them down or issuing them: it means that they are actually brought within the body of the APS and that they are followed. The government believes that the wording of the amendment adds nothing to it.

In relation to the directions, the government believes that these directions should be available to be updated from time to time and to adapt to circumstances so that the directions you have here would not be the final directions for all time. The commissioner would be free to issue a direction on a particular value if the circumstance so permitted. This document of the Public Service Commissioner's direction is very much alive to the times and circumstances prevailing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that that is the case, that regulations can be updated, Minister, perhaps you can comment on the two examples I gave. Is there any chance that the directions will be changed to include those two examples? How flexible are these directions at this point in time?
—What were the two again?
—The two that I mentioned were that `the APS has the highest ethical standards' and that `the APS establishes cooperative workplace relations'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot give any undertaking on behalf of the government that those will be incorporated in this particular document. They are certainly matters that the government could look at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the amendments suggested by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate are still needed. If you look at part 3, clause 9 starts off talking about the constitution of the APS and then clause 10 sets out 10 APS values. None of those are very specific. They all turn on words like `apolitical', `free from discrimination', `highest ethical standards' and what have you. They clearly need defining. That seems to be the purpose of clause 11.

SPEECH.PARA: To make those values set out in clause 10 sensible to the people who have to carry them out, the commissioner then has to give directions. The way clause 11 is phrased makes it a bit difficult to understand what it is on about. It states:
(1) The Commissioner must issue directions in writing in relation to the APS Values:
(a) for the purpose of ensuring that the APS incorporates the APS Values; or
(b) determining the scope or application of the APS Values.

Paragraphs (a) and (b) are, as it were, disjunctive. You can do only one or the other. It would seem to me that you cannot do both. I do not know whether the commissioner could say that you do not have to carry out all the values from (a) to (k) or whether it means that the commissioner sets out the ways in which (a) to (k) should be carried out in order to meet the requirements of the act—I think it probably does mean that—or the scope or application, whatever that means, of the APS values.

BREAK.PARA: It seems to me that a lot depends on what the commissioner does as to the definition of how the values set out in clause 10 are to be carried out before clause 12 and 13 become sensible. It seems to me that not only is it very vague but also the mechanism itself is undefined and fairly tortuous. As we look at it now, whether we accept the amendment of Senator Faulkner or not—and it seems to me to clear up the issue—we are left with a very vague and difficult to understand regime set out in the legislation to make the APS values somehow sensible. Clause 11 is very difficult to understand and very difficult to give meaning to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the nub of Senator Harradine's argument that he has put to the committee to be: why do you effectively need the commissioner to undertake this activity when, effectively, the bill says that it is the agency heads' responsibility? We say, yes, Senator Harradine, you have it right in part. Agency heads are responsible for their agencies observing the values.

SPEECH.PARA: The government says it is appropriate that the commissioner should issue directions about some values, but we in the opposition say that it makes sense in fact for the commissioner to do them all, otherwise you will have the situation where agency heads will be continually reinventing the wheel. It is just absolutely unnecessary duplication. The case for this amendment is very strong on those grounds.

I understand the minister is saying to us that the words `and upholds' effectively are incorporated in the word `incorporates'. You have a different understanding, Minister, of the English language from me. If you are to ensure that the APS incorporates APS values, I suppose you could do that by mechanisms such as the annual report, a corporate plan or whatever, but there is no doubt that what the opposition is proposing goes significantly further.

Frankly, Minister, if you consider this is unnecessary from the point of view of, effectively, the words `and upholds' are already incorporated, I see very little downside in your embracing that part of the amendment for absolute clarity. I really do think that this particular amendment strongly commends itself to the Senate. I say again: this is really the cornerstone of the legislation, and we do not believe the implementation of these values should be left to the discretion of a plethora of agency heads. As I have outlined, the arguments in support of this amendment are strong and, again, I commend the amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, as Senator Faulkner has indicated, if you feel that clause 11 does mean `and upholds', does embrace, as it were, the words `and upholds', I suppose he has a point when he asks why the government does not embrace it as well. I did mention previously the next clause which requires the agency heads to uphold and promote the APS values. It requires them to do so. The point I was making was that I can see why the commissioner should be issuing directions under clause 11 for what is required to be done under the act under clause 12.

SPEECH.PARA: If you go over the page and have a look at clause 15, breaches of the code of conduct and so on, you then think to yourself, `Who will bring agency heads to boot if you have a minister who is not well over the situation?' Will that be the commissioner? If it is the commissioner, is it appropriate to have a situation where the commissioner can issue directions to a particular agency head to uphold the APS values? If that is the case, Senator Faulkner's amendment does have some merit.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 11, page 8 (line 18), at the end of subclause (1), add:

PARA.TAB: ; or (c) for the purpose of ensuring that APS values are incorporated and upheld in the provision of services or functions on behalf of the APS.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 41, page 20 (after line 15), after paragraph (1)(a), insert:

TAB.TAB: (aa) to ensure that APS Values are incorporated and upheld in the provision of services or functions on behalf of the APS.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that, on the basis of the past voting patterns on amendments, these are unlikely to get up but, nevertheless, I have moved them. Amendment No. 3 requires the Public Service Commissioner to issue directions for the purposes of ensuring that the APS values are incorporated and upheld in contracted services. The Democrats believe it is appropriate, even necessary, for the commissioner to ensure that APS values continue, if you like, beyond the door of the APS and into contracted services, and we think that taxpayers are entitled to expect that. Amendment No. 5 makes it a function of the Public Service Commissioner to ensure APS values are upheld in the provision of contracted out services.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the same reasons that I articulated at the time the opposition supported previous amendments, the opposition is willing to support Australian Democrat amendments Nos 3 and 5. I do not intend to delay the committee by repeating the same arguments in support of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to this matter, the government's arguments are those which were put forward in relation to Democrat amendment 2. This is a provision of services to the community as a whole and does not touch on the employment of public servants as such, and this is not the place for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move to the next amendment, I want to ask the minister a question so I am clear on the APS code of conduct in clause 13. In the House of Representatives, the government amended the bill to omit the existing subclause (3) and substitute it with the following:

SPEECH.PARA: An APS employee, when acting in the course of APS employment, must treat everyone with respect and courtesy, and without harassment.
All I would ask is that the minister very briefly explain the rationale for the change the government has made to the original text, which was:
An APS employee, when acting in the course of APS employment, must treat everyone with respect and courtesy, and without coercion or harassment of any kind.
Minister, if you could explain to us the basis for that change, I would appreciate it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —This change came from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. There was some query during the hearing as to the word `coercion' and the change was a result of that concern raised by the committee. I cannot point to the place in the report where it was dealt with, but I can say to Senator Faulkner that this was done as a result of the committee's comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would appreciate a reference on that point if you could, Minister, but I will not bog the committee down. If you could provide that, it would be helpful. I wish to move to opposition amendment No. 12.
—It's a good one.
—Senator Harradine has filled me with confidence. He said it was quite a good amendment. Given Senator Harradine has said that, one could only go backwards from this point, so I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 14, page 10 (line 9), at the end of the clause, add "and are subject to sanctions for breaches of the Code, to be determined by the Prime Minister on the recommendation of the Commissioner".

It is the view of the opposition that the bill should make clear that agency heads are subject to sanctions for breaches of the code of conduct in the same way as are APS employees. I agree with Senator Harradine: it is a good amendment and I commend it to the committee.
Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

BREAK.PARA: (13) Clause 15, page 10 (lines 15 and 16), omit "include the following", substitute "are".
(14) Clause 15, page 10 (line 21), at the end of subclause (2), add:

TAB.TAB: ;(f) admonishment.

BREAK.PARA: (15) Clause 15, page 10 (lines 24 and 25), omit "The procedures must have due regard to procedural fairness.", substitute "The procedures must be based on minimum standards, determined by the Commissioner, and must have due regard to procedural fairness.".
(17) Clause 17, page 11 (after line 14), after subclause (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) A breach of subsection (1) is to be treated as a breach of the Code of Conduct.

BREAK.PARA: With the change that amendment 13 would bring and the addition of `admonishment' from amendment 14, this is the complete range of current sanctions. Employees should know what the sanctions are. There is, in our view, no need for discretion to expand on them. Before I speak on amendment 15, I would like to ask the minister to clarify—and I think this is a crucial point—whether decisions on sanctions would be appellable actions as defined in clause 33.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Within the ambit of clause 33, that would be so. It would be subject to review.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that advice. In relation to opposition amendment 15, we believe that there should be a basic standard for procedure on breaches and this should be set by the commissioner; otherwise departments are going to waste time and effort duplicating procedures. I remind the committee that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, in its fourth recommendation, recommended that the commissioner have a role in monitoring agencies' procedures to make sure they are fair and reasonable. In relation to opposition amendment 17, this particular provision—which the government claims to be a significant innovation—we believe is meaningless in the absence of sanctions for breaches. I commend these amendments to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Matters such as breaches of the code are important. I think that if Senator Cooney was saying this he would say it much more eloquently and with a greater deal of judiciousness than I can. In relation to breaches of the code of conduct, the bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: The sanctions that may be prescribed by the regulations include the following:

I agree with what Senator Faulkner said. What he is really saying is that we need to have certainty when we are dealing with these matters—certainty before the law. I think that is a matter that the government would probably agree to anyhow.

In regard to clause 15, yes, it is true: if the commissioner is required to do that which is proposed in clause 15, that will help ensure uniformity across agencies in respect of this very important matter. I agree with clause 15. Similarly, I agree with clause 17, subject of course to what the minister may say in opposition, but I would have thought the government might see its way clear to agree with those particular propositions. They are, I think, principled and probably deserve to be placed in the Public Service legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to clause 17, the government sees it as perhaps superfluous that a breach of the APS values is a breach of the code as such.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to amendments to clauses 13 to 15, the government is of the view, firstly, that the amendment to clause 13 is too limiting in its approach; it is too prescriptive. I take the point that Senator Harradine made when he said:
The sanctions that may be prescribed by the regulations include the following:

I also take the other points Senator Harradine made—that you must have certainty and that there could be other things which are included. Of course, in the way the bill is framed there it is wider in application, and it is meant to be that way. It says sanctions include termination of employment, reduction in classification, re‐assignment of duties, reduction in salary and deduction from salary by way of fine. Those are sanctions which you may have. There may be something else which is more appropriate for the circumstances, but if you cut it off and limit it you do not give yourself that flexibility, and it is flexibility that we are looking at in relation to that.

They are penalties which are not akin to putting an employee in prison or something as draconian as that. They are more to suit the workplace and how an employee is dealt with: what might be said if there is a situation with an employee which really does not warrant termination of employment because the situation is nowhere near that bad; reduction of salary might be a bit harsh and so there is another means by which a sanction can be imposed. It gives that flexibility.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 16, page 11 (after line 7), after paragraph (a), insert:

TAB.TAB: (aa) the Merit Protection Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by the Merit Protection Commissioner; or

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment adds the Merit Protection Commissioner to clause 16. It obviously reflects the government's decision to create this office and effectively gives whistleblowers another avenue of appeal beyond the commissioner, agency head or a person appointed by either of those office holders.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not now be proceeding with Democrat amendment No. 1 to oppose the clause, the reason being that we have just approved the opposition's amendment to that clause. Really, to oppose this was a tidying up exercise. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 11 (after line 23), after clause 19, insert:

TAB.TAB: The object of this Part is to establish a framework to facilitate the disclosure by APS employees, in the public interest, of maladministration, serious or substantial waste, or corrupt or illegal conduct in the APS:
(a) by providing means by which such disclosures may be made; and
(b) by providing for the protection of APS employees who make such disclosures; and
(c) by providing for those disclosures to be properly investigated and dealt with.
This Part applies to public interest disclosures made, and detrimental action suffered, after the commencement of this Act.
In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears:

SPEECH.PARA: Commissioner means the Commissioner of the Public Interest Disclosure Agency appointed under section 19K
detrimental action has the meaning given by section 19X
PIDA means the Public Interest Disclosure Agency established under section 19G
Protection Commissioner means the Commissioner of the Whistleblowers' Protection Agency appointed under section 19ZC
public interest disclosure has the meaning given by section 19F
WPA means the Whistleblowers' Protection Agency established under section 19Z

PARA.TAB: (1) An APS employee who makes a public interest disclosure is not subject to any civil, criminal or administrative action if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the APS employee:
(i) believes on reasonable grounds that the information is true; or

(ii) is not in a position to form a belief on reasonable grounds about the truth of the information but believes on reasonable grounds that the information may be true and is of sufficient significance to justify its disclosure so that its truth may be investigated; and
(b) the disclosure is made to:
(i) the PIDA; or
(ii) the WPA; or
(iii) an Agency Head or a person authorised for the purposes of this Part by an Agency Head; or
(iv) the Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this Part by the Commissioner; or
(v) the Merit Protection Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this Part by the Merit Protection Commissioner; and
(c) the disclosure is made in good faith.

PARA.TAB: (2) An APS employee who makes a public interest disclosure that complies with subsection (1) or section 19E:

TAB.TAB: (a) in any proceeding for defamation—has a defence of absolute privilege for publishing the information in accordance with subsection (1) or section 19E;
(b) if the disclosure would otherwise contravene an Act, oath, rule of law or practice:
(i) does not contravene that Act, oath, rule of law or practice; and
(ii) is not liable for any disciplinary or other action for making the disclosure.

PARA.TAB: (3) If a disclosure is made to a person other than an officer of the PIDA, that person must pass the information to the PIDA as soon as practicable.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19E Disclosures to other persons permitted in certain circumstances

TAB.TAB: A public interest disclosure by an APS employee to a member of Parliament or to a journalist is protected by this Part if:
(a) the APS employee has made substantially the same disclosure to a person mentioned in paragraph 19D(1)(b); and
(b) the PIDA has decided not to investigate the matter; or
(c) the PIDA has decided to investigate the matter but has not completed the investigation within 6 months of the disclosure being made; or
(d) the PIDA has investigated the matter but has not recommended that any action be taken in respect of the matter; or
(e) the PIDA has failed to notify the APS employee who made the disclosure, within 6 months of the disclosure being made, of whether or not the matter is to be investigated; and
(f) the APS employee has reasonable grounds for believing that the disclosure is substantially true; and
(g) the disclosure is substantially true.
In this Part, a public interest disclosure includes an allegation that:
(a) an APS employee has committed, or been involved in the commission by another person of:
(i) an infringement of the law; or
(ii) a serious and substantial waste of public money; or
(iii) an act constituting an abuse of the authority vested in the APS employee or another person, as the case may be; or
(iv) an act constituting or resulting in substantial danger to public health or safety; or
(v) serious and substantial mismanagement of public money or property; or
(vi) the suppression of an expert opinion, finding or document prepared by another person; or
(b) an APS employee has failed, or been involved in the failure of another person, to act in accordance with the law;

SPEECH.PARA: in relation to the person's duties as an APS employee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Subdivision 1—Establishment, functions and powers of Agency

TAB.TAB: The Public Interest Disclosure Agency is established.
The PIDA has the following functions:
(a) to receive public interest disclosures from any APS employee or other person mentioned in paragraph 19D(1)(b); and
(b) to assess disclosures made under paragraph (a) and:
(i) where an allegation may amount to a criminal offence—to refer the matter to the Australian Federal Police or other relevant agency for investigation; or

(ii) where an allegation may amount to a breach of the Code of Conduct—to refer the matter to the appropriate Agency for investigation unless the APS employee requests that the PIDA undertake the investigation and the Commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that the investi gation would more appropriately be undertaken by the PIDA; and
(c) in cases to which paragraph (b) does not apply—to investigate public interest disclosures and to take, or recommend to the appropriate Agency, ameliorative action; and
(d) to promote the ethic of openness and public accountability; and
(e) to improve community perception of whistleblowers, in recognition of the fact that they are responsible citizens; and
(f) any other matter arising under this Part.
The PIDA consists of a single commissioner, to be known as the Public Interest Disclosure Commissioner.
The Commissioner is to be appointed by the Governor‐General for a period of up to 5 years specified in the instrument of appointment.
The remuneration and other conditions of appointment of the Commissioner are as determined in writing by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Governor‐General may remove the Commissioner from office if each House of the Parliament, in the same session of the Parliament, presents an address to the Governor‐General praying for the removal of the Commissioner on the ground of misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.
(2) The Governor‐General must remove the Commissioner from office if the Commissioner does any of the following:

TAB.TAB: (a) becomes bankrupt;
(b) applies to take the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors;
(c) compounds with his or her creditors;
(d) assigns his or her remuneration for the benefit of his or her creditors.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Prime Minister may appoint a person to act as Commissioner:

TAB.TAB: (a) if there is a vacancy in the office of Commissioner, whether or not an appointment has previously been made to the office; or
(b) during any period, or during all periods, when the Commissioner is absent from duty or from Australia or is, for any reason, unable to perform the duties of the office.

PARA.TAB: (2) Anything done by or in relation to a person purporting to act under this section is not invalid merely because:

TAB.TAB: (a) the occasion for the appointment had not arisen; or
(b) there was a defect or irregularity in connection with the appointment; or
(c) the appointment had ceased to have effect; or
(d) the occasion to act had not arisen or had ceased.

PARA.TAB: (1) The staff necessary to assist the Commissioner must be persons engaged under this Act.
(2) For the purposes of this Act:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Commissioner and the APS employees assisting the Commissioner together constitute a Statutory Agency; and
(b) the Commissioner is the Head of that Statutory Agency.

PARA.TAB: (1) After the end of each financial year, the Commissioner must give a report to the Prime Minister, for presentation to the Parliament, on the activities of the PIDA during the year.
(2) The report must include a report on the incidence of and response to whistleblowing in the APS.
(3) An Agency Head must give the Commissioner whatever information the Commissioner requires for the purpose of preparing the report referred to in subsection (2).
(1) A disclosure under this Part may be made to the PIDA orally or in writing.

(2) Where a disclosure is made to the PIDA, the PIDA must, within a reasonable time after receipt of the disclosure, notify the complainant of the action (if any) it proposes to take as a result of its investigation of the disclosure.
(3) The PIDA may decide not to investigate a disclosure made to it or, if it has commenced to investigate a disclosure made to it, decide not to investigate it further if, in the opinion of the PIDA:

TAB.TAB: (a) the disclosure is frivolous or vexatious and there are no special reasons justifying the investigation or further investigation of the disclosure; or
(b) investigation or further investigation of the disclosure is unnecessary having regard to all the circumstances of the case.

PARA.TAB: (1) The PIDA may, for the purposes of this Part, obtain information from such persons, and make such inquiries, as it thinks fit.
(2) An investigation under this Part is to be conducted in private and, except as otherwise provided by this Part, in such manner as the PIDA thinks fit.

(3) Subject to subsection (5), it is not necessary for the complainant or any other person to be afforded an opportunity to appear before the PIDA or any other person in connection with an investigation by the PIDA under this Part.

(4) The PIDA must keep the identity of the complainant and the nature of the complaint confidential unless and until it is necessary to reveal them to another person in order to enable that person to make a proper reply to the allegations in the complaint.
(5) The PIDA must not make a report in respect of an investigation under this Part in which it:

TAB.TAB: (a) sets out opinions that are, either expressly or impliedly, critical of an Agency or a person; or
(b) recommends the taking of action by an Agency against a person;
unless, before completing the investigation, the Agency has:

(c) in the case of opinions or recommendations relating to an Agency, afforded the Agency Head and the officer principally concerned in the action to which the investigation relates opportunities to appear before the Commissioner, or an authorised person, and to make such submissions, either orally or in writing, in relation to the action as they think fit; and

(d) in the case of opinions or recommendations relating to a person, afforded the person an opportunity to appear before the Commissioner, or an authorised person, and to make such submissions, either orally or in writing, in relation to the action to which the investigation relates as he or she thinks fit.

PARA.TAB: (6) Where the PIDA affords the principal officer of an Agency an opportunity to appear before the Commissioner or an authorised person, under subsection (5), the Agency Head may appear in person or a person authorised by the Agency Head may appear on behalf of the Agency Head.

(7) Where the PIDA affords a person other than the Agency Head an opportunity to appear before the Commissioner, or an authorised person, under subsection (5), the person may, with the approval of the Commissioner or authorised person, as the case may be, be represented by another person.
(8) In carrying out an investigation under this Part, the PIDA is not bound by the rules of evidence but may inform itself on a matter in any manner it deems appropriate.

(9) In deciding whether it is satisfied concerning a matter under investigation, the PIDA is not required to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt but must reach its decision or opinion on the balance of probabilities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19S Power to require persons to answer questions and produce documents

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commissioner may, by notice in writing, require a person believed to be capable of giving information relevant to an investigation under this Part to furnish, in writing, within a reasonable period specified in the notice, such information, and to produce such documents and other records, being information, documents or records relevant to the investigation, as are specified in the notice.

(2) For the purposes of an investigation under this Part, the Commissioner may, by notice in writing, require the complainant, or any other person reasonably believed by the Commissioner to be able to give information relevant to an investigation, to attend before the Commissioner or an authorised person at a time and place specified in the notice and then to answer questions and produce documents or records relevant to the investigation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19T Persons not to refuse to furnish information, etc.

PARA.TAB: (1) Notwithstanding the provisions of any enactment, a person is not excused from furnishing any information, producing a document or other record or answering a question when required to do so under this Part on the ground that furnishing the information, producing the document or record, or answering the question:

TAB.TAB: (a) would contravene the provisions of any other Act, would be contrary to the public interest or might tend to incriminate the person or make him or her liable to a penalty; or
(b) would disclose legal advice, the disclosure of which would otherwise be privileged;
but the answer to the question is not admissible in evidence against the person in proceedings other than proceedings for an offence against section 19ZV.

PARA.TAB: (2) A person is not liable to a penalty under the provisions of any other enactment by reason of furnishing information, producing a document or record or answering a question when required to do so under this Part.

TAB.TAB: The Commissioner or an authorised person may administer an oath or affirmation to a person required to attend before the Commissioner or the authorised person, as the case may be, under subsection 19S(2), and may examine the person on oath or affirmation.

PARA.TAB: (1) For the purposes of an investigation under this Part, the Commissioner or an authorised person may, at any reasonable time of the day, enter any place occupied by an Agency, and may carry on the investigation at that place.

(2) Where, upon application being made to a Judge of the Federal Court by the Commissioner or an authorised person for the issue of a warrant under this section authorising the entry into, and search of, premises, the Judge is satisfied, by information on oath, that there are reasonable grounds for believing that there are, at the premises, documents, records or other evidence relevant to an investigation under this Act, the Judge may, by warrant, authorise a member of the staff of the Agency, subject to any conditions or restrictions the Judge sees fit to specify in the warrant, to enter and search the premises specified in the warrant and search any person found on the premises and to take possession of and remove any books, documents and other things found on the premises and reasonably believed to be relevant to the investigation.

(3) A warrant under subsection (2) must state whether entry is authorised to be made at any time of the day or night or only during specified hours and may, if the Judge issuing the warrant thinks fit, provide that entry may be made without permission being first sought or demand first being made and authorise measures that the Judge is satisfied are necessary for that purpose.
(4) A warrant under subsection (2) must specify the period for which it is to remain in force, being a period not exceeding one month.
(5) Subsection (4) does not prevent the issue of a further warrant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19W Person to be informed of outcome of disclosure

TAB.TAB: The PIDA must notify the complainant of the outcome of any investigation into the matters to which the disclosure relates.

PARA.TAB: (1) A person who intentionally takes detrimental action against an APS employee because of, or in the belief that, the APS employee has made or may make a public interest disclosure is guilty of an offence.
Penalty: 50 penalty units
(2) In this Division, detrimental action includes:

TAB.TAB: (a) action leading to injury, damage or loss;
(b) action that prejudices a person's safety;
(c) intimidation or harassment;
(d) discrimination, disadvantage or adverse treatment in relation to employment;
(e) dismissal from, or prejudice in, employment;
(f) disciplinary proceedings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19Y Detrimental action may be treated as a breach of the Code of Conduct

TAB.TAB: Detrimental action by an APS employee against another APS employee in respect of a public interest disclosure may be treated as a breach of the Code of Conduct.
The Whistleblowers' Protection Agency is established.
The WPA has the following functions:
(a) to receive allegations of detrimental action against APS employees; and
(b) to assess allegations received under paragraph (a) and:
(i) where an allegation may amount to a criminal offence—to refer the matter to the Australian Federal Police or other relevant agency for investigation; or

(ii) where an allegation may amount to a breach of the Code of Conduct—to refer the matter to the appropriate Agency for investigation unless the complainant requests that the WPA undertake the investigation and the Protection Commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that the investigation would more appropriately be undertaken by the WPA; and

(c) in cases to which paragraph (b) does not apply—to investigate allegations of detrimental action against APS employees and, where appropriate, recommend action to be taken in respect of substantiated allegations; and
(d) to provide advice on the process for making public interest disclosures, in confidence if requested; and
(e) to provide support for APS employees who have been subject to detrimental action; and
(f) to improve community perception of whistleblowers, in recognition of the fact that they are responsible citizens.
The WPA consists of a single commissioner, to be known as the Protection Commissioner.
The Commissioner is to be appointed by the Governor‐General for a period of up to 5 years specified in the instrument of appointment.
The remuneration and other conditions of appointment of the Commissioner are as determined in writing by the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Governor‐General may remove the Protection Commissioner from office if each House of the Parliament, in the same session of the Parliament, presents an address to the Governor‐General praying for the removal of the Protection Com missioner on the ground of misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.
(2) The Governor‐General must remove the Protection Commissioner from office if the Protection Commissioner does any of the following:

TAB.TAB: (a) becomes bankrupt;
(b) applies to take the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors;
(c) compounds with his or her creditors;
(d) assigns his or her remuneration for the benefit of his or her creditors.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Prime Minister may appoint a person to act as Protection Commissioner:

TAB.TAB: (a) if there is a vacancy in the office of Protection Commissioner, whether or not an appointment has previously been made to the office; or
(b) during any period, or during all periods, when the Protection Commissioner is absent from duty or from Australia or is, for any reason, unable to perform the duties of the office.

PARA.TAB: (2) Anything done by or in relation to a person purporting to act under this section is not invalid merely because:

TAB.TAB: (a) the occasion for the appointment had not arisen; or
(b) there was a defect or irregularity in connection with the appointment; or
(c) the appointment had ceased to have effect; or
(d) the occasion to act had not arisen or had ceased.

PARA.TAB: (1) The staff necessary to assist the Protection Commissioner must be persons engaged under this Act.
(2) For the purposes of this Act:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Protection Commissioner and the APS employees assisting the Protection Commissioner together constitute a Statutory Agency; and
(b) the Protection Commissioner is the Head of that Statutory Agency.

PARA.TAB: (1) After the end of each financial year, the Protection Commissioner must give a report to the Prime Minister, for presentation to the Parliament, on the activities of the WPA during the year.
(2) The report must include reports on:

TAB.TAB: (a) public interest disclosures made to the WPA which have been referred to other agencies for investigation; and
(b) allegations of detrimental action against APS employees who have made public interest disclosures; and
(c) the investigation of allegations referred to in paragraph (b).

PARA.TAB: (1) A complaint under this Part may be made to the WPA orally or in writing.

(2) Where a complaint is made to the WPA, the WPA must, within a reasonable time after receipt of the complaint, notify the complainant of the action (if any) it proposes to take as a result of its investigation of the complaint.
(3) The WPA may decide not to investigate a complaint made to it or, if it has commenced to investigate a complaint made to it, decide not to investigate it further if, in the opinion of the WPA:

TAB.TAB: (a) the complaint is frivolous or vexatious and there are no special reasons justifying the investigation or further investigation of the complaint; or
(b) investigation or further investigation of the complaint is unnecessary having regard to all the circumstances of the case.

PARA.TAB: (1) The WPA may, for the purposes of this Part, obtain information from such persons, and make such inquiries, as it thinks fit.
(2) An investigation under this Part is to conducted in private and, except as otherwise provided by this Part, in such manner as the WPA thinks fit.

(3) Subject to subsection (5), it is not necessary for the complainant or any other person to be afforded an opportunity to appear before the WPA or any other person in connection with an investigation by the WPA under this Part.

(4) The WPA must keep the identity of the complainant and the nature of the complaint confidential unless and until it is necessary to reveal them to another person in order to enable that person to make a proper reply to the allegations in the complaint.
(5) The WPA must not make a report in respect of an investigation under this Part in which it:

TAB.TAB: (a) sets out opinions that are, either expressly or impliedly, critical of an Agency or a person; or
(b) recommends the taking of action by an Agency against a person;
unless, before completing the investigation, the Agency has:

(c) in the case of opinions or recommendations relating to an Agency, afforded the Agency Head and the officer principally concerned in the action to which the investigation relates opportunities to appear before the Commissioner, or an authorised person, and to make such submissions, either orally or in writing, in relation to the action as they think fit; and

(d) in the case of opinions or recommendations relating to a person, afforded the person an opportunity to appear before the Commissioner, or an authorised person, and to make such submissions, either orally or in writing, in relation to the action to which the investigation relates as he or she thinks fit.

PARA.TAB: (6) Where the WPA affords the principal officer of an Agency an opportunity to appear before the Commissioner or an authorised person, under subsection (5), the Agency Head may so appear in person or a person authorised by the Agency Head may so appear on behalf of the Agency Head.

(7) Where the WPA affords a person other than the Agency Head an opportunity to appear before the Commissioner, or an authorised person, under subsection (5), the person may, with the approval of the Commissioner or authorised person, as the case may be, be represented by another person.
(8) In carrying out an investigation under this Part, the WPA is not bound by the rules of evidence but may inform itself on a matter in any manner it deems appropriate.

(9) In deciding whether it is satisfied concerning a matter under investigation, the WPA is not required to be satisfied beyond reasonable doubt but must reach its decision or opinion on the balance of probabilities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19ZL Power to require persons to answer questions and produce documents

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commissioner may, by notice in writing, require a person believed to be capable of giving information relevant to an investigation under this Part to furnish, in writing, within a reasonable period specified in the notice, such information, and to produce such documents and other records, being information, documents or records relevant to the investigation, as are specified in the notice.

(2) For the purposes of an investigation under this Part, the Commissioner may, by notice in writing, require the complainant, or any other person reasonably believed by the Commissioner to be able to give information relevant to an investigation, to attend before the Commissioner or an authorised person at a time and place specified in the notice and then to answer questions and produce documents or records relevant to the investigation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19ZM Persons not to refuse to furnish information, etc.

PARA.TAB: (1) Notwithstanding the provisions of any enactment, a person is not excused from furnishing any information, producing a document or other record or answering a question when required to do so under this Part on the ground that furnishing the information, producing the document or record, or answering the question:

TAB.TAB: (a) would contravene the provisions of any other Act, would be contrary to the public interest or might tend to incriminate the person or make him or her liable to a penalty; or
(b) would disclose legal advice, the disclosure of which would otherwise be privileged;
but the answer to the question is not admissible in evidence against the person in proceedings other than proceedings for an offence against section 19ZV.

PARA.TAB: (2) A person is not liable to a penalty under the provisions of any other enactment by reason of furnishing information, producing a document or record or answering a question when required to do so under this Part.

TAB.TAB: The Commissioner or an authorised person may administer an oath or affirmation to a person required to attend before the Commissioner or the authorised person, as the case may be, under subsection 19ZL(2), and may examine the person on oath or affirmation.

PARA.TAB: (1) For the purposes of an investigation under this Part, the Commissioner or an authorised person may, at any reasonable time of the day, enter any place occupied by an Agency, and may carry on the investigation at that place.

(2) Where, upon application being made to a Judge of the Federal Court by the Commissioner or an authorised person for the issue of a warrant under this section authorising the entry into, and search of, premises, the Judge is satisfied, by information on oath, that there are reasonable grounds for believing that there are, at the premises, documents, records or other evidence relevant to an investigation under this Act, the Judge may, by warrant, authorise a member of the staff of the Agency, subject to any conditions or restrictions the Judge sees fit to specify in the warrant, to enter and search the premises specified in the warrant and search any person found on the premises and to take possession of and remove any books, documents and other things found on the premises and reasonably believed to be relevant to the investigation.

(3) A warrant under subsection (2) must state whether entry is authorised to be made at any time of the day or night or only during specified hours and may, if the Judge issuing the warrant thinks fit, provide that entry may be made without permission being first sought or demand first being made and authorise measures that the Judge is satisfied are necessary for that purpose.
(4) A warrant under subsection (2) must specify the period for which it is to remain in force, being a period not exceeding one month.
(5) Subsection (4) does not prevent the issue of a further warrant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19ZP Person to be informed of outcome of complaint

TAB.TAB: The WPA must notify the complainant of the outcome of any investigation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 19ZQ Assistance to persons prejudiced by prohibited personnel practices or subjected to harassment

PARA.TAB: (1) Subject to this Part, where the WPA is satisfied, either before or after completing an investigation under this Part, that a person has been subjected to detrimental action the Agency must provide the person with such assistance, of a kind specified in subsection (2), as it deems to be appropriate in all the circumstances.
(2) The following kinds of assistance to a person are specified for the purposes of subsection (1):

TAB.TAB: (a) assistance to secure the reinstatement of the person in an office or position from which the person had been moved in consequence of the prohibited personnel practice or harassment;
(b) assistance to secure the reallocation of the person to another office or position;
(c) assistance to secure the re‐engagement of the person in employment from which the person was dismissed in consequence of the prohibited personnel practice or harassment;

(d) assistance to secure the taking of such other action with respect to the person as the Agency deems proper to put the person in the position he or she would have been in if the prohibited personnel practice or harassment had never occurred;
(e) the payment to the person of a sum by way of compensation for the prejudice or harassment;
(f) the seeking of an injunction under section 31.

PARA.TAB: (3) The WPA must not seek to provide assistance of a kind specified in paragraph (2)(a), (b), (c) or (d) to a person unless it has obtained the consent of the person to provide assistance of that kind to the person.

(4) Where the WPA decides to provide assistance to a person of a kind specified in paragraphs (2)(a), (b), (c) or (d), the WPA must discuss such action with the body, authority or person responsible for the person's employment or for the employment the person was seeking, as the case may be, and seek to reach agreement with that body, authority or person with respect to the action that it would be practicable and appropriate to take to assist the person concerned, having regard to all the circumstances.

(5) If agreement is reached under subsection (4) but the action agreed to be taken is not taken within a reasonable time after the agreement is reached, the WPA may give to the body, authority or person concerned a notice in writing directing that the action be taken within a reasonable time specified in the notice.
(1) Where the WPA is satisfied that it is proper to do so, the WPA may assess a sum to be paid to a person under paragraph 19ZQ(2)(e).

(2) In deciding whether to make an assessment under subsection (1), and in assess ing the amount of assistance, the WPA must have regard to the assistance (if any) of a kind referred to in paragraph 19ZQ(2)(a), (b), (c) or (d) that has been provided, or is to be provided, for the person concerned.

(3) Where a person cannot be reinstated, reallocated, or re‐engaged in accordance with subsection 19ZQ(2), in assessing the amount of a sum to be paid to a person in accordance with subsection (1), the WPA is to take into account:

TAB.TAB: (a) the salary and related entitlements to which the person would have been entitled had he or she remained in his or her employment; and
(b) the time period for which the person could reasonably have been expected to remain in that employment; and

(c) prevailing severance payments, appropriate to the field of employment in which the person was engaged, payable to a person whose term or period of employment has been terminated without the consent of the person.

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Court may, on the application of the WPA, grant an injunction restraining a person from engaging in conduct that constitutes or would constitute detrimental action.

(2) Where the WPA has given a notice under subsection 19ZQ(6), the Federal Court may, on the application of the WPA, make an order directing the person required to take the action under that notice to take that action, or such other action as the Court deems proper, within a time specified by the Court.
(3) Where, in the opinion of the Federal Court, it is desirable to do so, the Court may grant an interim injunction pending determination of an application under subsection (1).
(4) The Federal Court may vary or rescind an injunction granted under subsection (1), (2) or (3).

(5) Where an application is made to the Federal Court for the grant of an injunction restraining a person from engaging in conduct of a particular kind, being conduct referred to in subsection (1), the Court may:

TAB.TAB: (a) if it is satisfied that the person has engaged in conduct of that kind—grant an injunction under subsection (1) restraining the person from engaging in conduct of that kind; or
(b) if, in the opinion of the Court, it is desirable to do so—grant an interim injunction under subsection (3) restraining the person from engaging in conduct of that kind;
whether or not it appears to the Court that the person intends to engage again, or to continue to engage, in conduct of that kind.

PARA.TAB: (6) Where an application is made to the Federal Court for the grant of an injunction restraining a person from engaging in conduct of a particular kind, being conduct referred to in subsection (1), the Court may:

TAB.TAB: (a) if it appears to the Court that, in the event that an injunction is not granted, it is likely that the person will engage in conduct of that kind—grant an injunction under subsection (1) restraining the person from engaging in conduct of that kind; or
(b) if, in the opinion of the Court, it is desirable to do so—grant an interim injunction under subsection (3) restraining the person from engaging in conduct of that kind;

whether or not the person has previously engaged in conduct of that kind and whether or not there is an imminent danger of substantial damage to any person if the first‐mentioned person engages in conduct of that kind.

PARA.TAB: (7) Where the WPA makes an application to the Federal Court for the grant of an injunction under this section, the Court shall not require the WPA or any other person, as a condition of granting an interim injunction, to give any undertaking as to damages.
(8) Where:

TAB.TAB: (a) in a case to which subsection (7) does not apply, the Federal Court would, but for this subsection, require a person to give an undertaking as to damages or costs; and
(b) the Minister gives the undertaking;
the Court must accept the undertaking by the Minister and must not require a further undertaking from any other person.

PARA.TAB: (1) Where the WPA is of the opinion that it is desirable to do so, the WPA may cause appropriate counselling to be provided to a person:

TAB.TAB: (a) who has made to the WPA an allegation of detrimental action; or
(b) who has been concerned in, or party to, any matters investigated by the WPA under this Part.

PARA.TAB: (2) Counselling in accordance with subsection (1) is to occur only with the consent of the person to be counselled.

TAB.TAB: If it appears to the WPA that, because a person:
(a) has made to the WPA an allegation of detrimental action; or
(b) has made to the PIDA a public interest disclosure; or
(c) has appeared, is appearing or is to appear before the Commissioner or the Protection Commissioner or an authorised person to give information or produce documents or records; or
(d) has furnished, has been required to furnish, or proposes to furnish, in writing, information, documents or records to the WPA or PIDA; or
(e) has assisted, is assisting or is to assist the Agency in some other manner in relation to an investigation under this Part;

the safety of the person or some other person may be prejudiced, or the person or some other person may be subjected to intimidation or harassment, the WPA may make such arrangements as are necessary to avoid prejudice to the safety of the person or to protect the person from intimidation or harassment.

PARA.TAB: (1) A person must not without lawful excuse refuse or fail:

TAB.TAB: (a) to attend before the Commissioner or the Protection Commissioner or an authorised person; or
(b) to be sworn or take a declaration; or
(c) to answer a question or produce a document or record; or
(d) to furnish information;
when so required in pursuance of this Part.
Penalty: 50 penalty units

PARA.TAB: (2) A person must not:

TAB.TAB: (a) wilfully obstruct, hinder or resist the WPA, the PIDA or any other person on the exercise of functions or powers under this Part without lawful excuse; or
(b) furnish information in a disclosure or complaint under this Part that is, to the knowledge of the person, false or misleading in a material particular; or

(c) furnish information to, answer a question put by, or furnish a document or record to the Commissioner, the Protection Commissioner or an authorised person for the purposes of this Part knowing that it is false or misleading in a material particular.
Penalty: 50 penalty units

The Commissioner and Protection Commissioner, respectively, may delegate to a member of the staff of the PIDA or the WPA, as the case may be, all or any of the powers conferred on the Commissioner and Protection Commissioner by this Part other than this power of delegation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will need to take a little of the committee's time, if I may, because this is a fairly extensive amendment. It is one which is very important in accountability terms and very important to the Senate.

These sorts of amendments are colloquially known as whistleblower amendments, and they are well known in those terms. But probably the better and more dispassionate term is `public disclosures', because that is what it is about. The problem with whistleblower talk is that it tends to have a lot of baggage that comes with it, and people think of informers and of people getting victimised, et cetera. But some legislations in fact do use the term in their actual descriptions, as indeed does this bill. I think the government is to be commended for its clause 16 because, to my knowledge, it is one of the first times that the Commonwealth has in fact advanced the cause of whistleblowers, in however minor a sense.

Whistleblower legislation and amendments are not exceptional; they are not unusual. They are well established throughout the civilised world. In our own country in 1993 and 1994, whistleblower laws were passed in South Australia, New South Wales, Queensland and the ACT, and a limited form of whistleblower protection is now in place in Western Australia. But I must tell you—as you would expect—that no government has come willingly to this particular legislative table, because whistleblower legislation increases accountability and decreases the ability of those who would wish to exercise undue influence, patronage and, sometimes, corruption.

I want to draw your attention to a really first‐rate report produced by the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing in August 1994 titled In the public interest. There were five members: Senator Jocelyn Newman was the Chair; Senator Shayne Murphy was the Deputy Chair; Senator Paul Calvert was a member; then Senator Christabel Chamarette was a member; and Senator Kay Denman was a member. That was five very experienced and capable people in this area.
I will draw your attention, if I may, to the part of the report headed `Summary of conclusions and recommendations' on page (xiii). The report said:

The Committee acknowledges that whistleblowing is a legitimate form of action within a democracy and that there have been, there are, and there will continue to be occasions on which whistleblowing is the only available avenue for the concerned ethical citizen to expose wrongdoing in the public or private sector.

The Committee believes that a fundamental shift in Australian values and ethics is necessary to overcome the stigma and trauma associated with whistleblowing. Notwithstanding the recommendations in this report, the Committee encourages organisations and institutions in both the public and private sectors, to reassess the value of reporting wrong‐doing and welcomes any initiatives, programs or strategies aimed at addressing this culture-change. The Committee appreciates that, notwithstanding the implementation of any legislative initiatives recommended in this report, in order to effect a shift in traditional workplace values and ethics, legislation must be accompanied by national leadership and education programs specifically targeted at workplace ethics.
I quote that to you to indicate that we are well aware that what we propose here in amendment No. 2 needs to be accompanied by other measures. But then the report goes on in (xiv):
The committee recommends that the practice of whistleblowing should be the subject of Commonwealth legislation—

I think that is very important to emphasise. That committee, headed by Senator Newman, and with Senators Murphy, Calvert, Chamarette and Denman, unanimously pro posed that whistleblowing should be the subject of Commonwealth legislation. The quote goes on:
to facilitate the making of disclosures in the public interest and to ensure protection for those who choose to do so.

I said to you that that approach is not an orphan—to use a Shakespearean phrase as used earlier by Senator Cooney, since he gets us into literary mode. I refer you to the Commission on Government Report No. 5 August 1996 , Western Australia.

That commission on government was a consequence of the royal commission into WA Inc. in 1992 and was appointed by Premier Richard Court. So this is hardly a radical body of people. They listened to all the submissions that came forward. In recommendations 73 and 74, they proposed the following:
The Public Interest Disclosures Act . . . should provide for a whistleblowing scheme to encourage—
note the word `encourage'—
public interest disclosures . . .

The Public Interest Disclosures Act . . . should provide that it is unlawful for a person to cause or attempt to or conspire to take reprisal action by causing detriment to another person because, or in the belief that, that person has made or may make a public interest disclosure . . . Detriment should be defined as including:
(a) personal injury or prejudice to safety;
(b) property damage or loss;
(c) intimidation or harassment;
(d) adverse discrimination, disadvantage or adverse treatment about career, profession, employment, trade or business;
(e) threats of detriment; and
(f) financial loss from detriment.
Recommendation 73 said:
Legislation, to be called the Public Interest Disclosures Act, should be introduced in Western Australia for the protection of a person who makes a public interest disclosure.

Those of you who understand politics well will know that Premier Richard Court has not yet enacted such legislation because it does not suit an executive to pursue that stuff. But it does suit the parliament and the people, because it advances the issues of accountabili ty. Why I am at pains to quote from those two reports is to indicate the importance of this kind of proposal to accountability and to the people.

I am aware that the minister has said that this matter has been referred to the Attorney‐General. My attitude to that is as follows. The whistleblower amendment we have put before you is drawn from the acts and the recommendations which I have described. It is not exceptional; it is tried and tested. It has not resulted in the collapse of good government in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia or the ACT; in fact, it has contributed to that good government.

Whistleblowers often have a reputation as being obsessive. The reason they become obsessive is that the way in which they are victimised and pursued to arrive at their disclosure forces them to become absolutely single minded. This sort of legislation takes that kind of pressure off and allows the proper disclosure of improper behaviour to occur in a controlled environment. Senators such as Senator Calvert, who was involved with that report, will recognise in this amendment some of the language you yourselves used and which we have expressed in consequence.

In the remaining minutes, I will take you briefly through the amendments I have to part 2 on sheet 758. The object of the part in 19A clearly states the intention to provide for disclosures by Australian government service employees in the public interest. The object sets out the three principal elements of the whistleblowers legislative framework which are the means by which disclosures may be made, the protection for whistleblowers and investigation of the disclosures.

We think these amendments could save Australian taxpayers millions of dollars in public funds, money which, in the past, has been lost because APS employees felt they could not speak out about corruption or fraud that they may have witnessed or been suspicious of because either they were subject to secrecy provisions, they were not afforded protection or they felt that their jobs, or at least their promotion, could be at risk.

Our 19B refers to application of the part. We should note that these amendments are not retrospective. They only apply to disclosures made or reprisal action taken against whistleblowers after the commencement of the act and we think that is consistent with natural justice and principles of fairness which demand that such acts cannot retrospectively be made illegal. The `Interpretation' establishes the important definitions and bodies set up by the Democrats amendments.
