In 19D, immunity for public interest disclosures, this section removes liability of an APS employee who makes a public interest disclosure in good faith to a list of disclosure agencies including: the public interest disclosure agency, which Senator Calvert would recognise, which is the one which pursues the matter of investigations; the whistleblowers protection agency—that is the agency which protects the whistleblower, and they have to be separate; you cannot have the investigative authority and the protective authority as one and the same—an agency head or appropriately authorised person; the commissioner; or the Merit Protection Commissioner.

The APS employee who complies with the section has a defence of absolute privilege for publishing the information and is deemed not to have contravened any act, oath, rule of law or practice and is not liable for any disciplinary action. Those of you who have any military background might remember that you cannot be required to obey an unlawful order. That is the equivalent in legislation.

In 19E, disclosures to other persons permitted in certain circumstances: once a public interest disclosure has been made to the appropriate agency or body listed, the APS employee may make substantially the same disclosure to a member of parliament or to a journalist in limited circumstances. That may surprise you, but the second most important agency of democracy that we have is the media. After parliament, they are the people who push out the information. There is a delay of six months between the disclosure to the PIDA—the public interest disclosure agency—and a permitted disclosure to a member of parliament or a journalist. This should mean that the PIDA could answer questions about the reported allegations and determine whether or not it is being treated seriously and pursued. That is a fail‐safe situation. If something is suppressed, then the media or parliament will get access to it.

In 19F, public interest disclosures, it sets out what constitutes a public interest disclosure. Under the government bill, an APS employee could make allegations of breaches of the code of conduct established under the bill. The Democrats' amendments dramatically broaden the scope of the possible disclosures that may be made by whistleblowers to include—now, who would oppose these?—serious or substantial waste of public money—no‐one; an abuse of authority by an APS employee—maybe some of you might; an act constituting or resulting in substantial danger to public health or safety—I would not think anyone opposes that; or the suppression of an expert opinion, finding or document prepared by another person—one or two of you might worry about that one.

These provisions will enable APS employees to report allegations or make disclosures which may save Australian taxpayers millions of dollars and they are consistent with the warnings of royal commissions and inquiries which have recommended that whistleblowers be protected and structures be put in place to ensure whistleblowing is possible in the public interest.

I have given you a fairly lengthy introduction because I think it is necessary to do so. I have further points to make, but I will take inquiries if you wish to ask me further questions about the amendments before you. Therefore, I commend the amendments to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a very brief preliminary contribution on Senator Murray's amendments and explain to the committee what the approach of the opposition will be on this matter. I want to say to Senator Murray that the sorts of issues that he canvassed at the deliberations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts were perhaps in many ways the most difficult that we had to grapple with; difficult because the issue was: how do you effectively deal with these matters in the Public Service Bill 1997 ? That, I think, is the fundamental issue.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day, the committee decided—and this was a matter on which there was unanimity between government and opposition senators—that it was more appropriate to address these particular matters through separate legislation. That is not to say that the issues that Senator Murray canvasses in his speech and the issues that Senator Murray's amendment deals with are not important ones for this parliament to give appropriate consideration to. The view of the opposition, having looked at this exhaustively through the Joint Committee of Public Accounts process, was that the most appropriate vehicle for us to deal with these matters was separate whistleblowers legislation.

I have not been convinced by Senator Murray's contribution that that is still not the case. The issue for Senator Murray to give consideration to is the appropriateness or otherwise of using the Public Service Bill 1997 as a vehicle for this sort of protection for these quite significant amendments to the legislation. I have no doubt that in your considerations, Senator Murray, you have thought long and hard about that issue. I appreciate that that would be the case.

I put it to you in the strongest possible terms that perhaps it might be more appropriate to be trying to obtain from Senator Ellison some commitments about what the government might be willing to do in terms of whistleblower legislation, whether the government will bring such legislation before the parliament, and whether the government contemplates this as a priority for government in this particular parliament.

As far as the opposition is concerned, the substantive matters that you have dealt with in your contributions are ones that we also believe are very important in terms of their receiving an adequate level of parliamentary scrutiny. I suspect that a number of the propositions you put forward might be embraced by the parliament. With others, perhaps that is not the case.

Fundamentally, through you Madam Temporary Chair, I say to Senator Murray that the problem the opposition has with what you are proposing is using this particular bill as a vehicle to achieve those outcomes. I do not think it is appropriate. I think it would be better for separate legislation to come before this parliament and for it to be given the focus and the attention that the issues you raise deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The points Senator Faulkner made are good ones which we have taken into consideration. It is true that separate legislation might well sit better, but our fear is that the coalition government will not introduce whistleblower legislation and, therefore, we have thought it appropriate to bring it forward—and that is why I emphasised the unexceptional nature of the clauses we have put forward—in this bill. If, in due course, the coalition introduces its own bill, it can repeal this and bring on its own legislation in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point concerns the nature of the Public Service Bill 1997 itself. By and large, in my opinion, that bill is a bill about the terms and conditions of employment for public service employees. I believe that terms and conditions of employment include the proper protection which should be accorded to employees in the carrying out of their duties. Plainly, you can take that too far. You cannot put in every health and safety regulation that exists, or every possible outcome that could be dealt with under the common law.

The fact is, this is a government which is materially changing the nature of public service employment and opening it up to a far less traditional, a far less governed environment in which public servants are more at the discretion of their particular employer, from the minister down to heads of departments. In that environment it is going to be more difficult, not easier, for them to blow the whistle, to make disclosures, because their jobs are more at risk.

Yet many public servants—probably most of the public servants, and certainly the people I have met—would have a very ethical view and would like to be able to carry out their jobs on an ethical basis. They may feel constrained from blowing the whistle. When we are dealing, as we do in this parliament and as the government does in its duties, with billions of dollars of taxpayers' money, I think it is appropriate that when we are changing the very nature of the legislation which governs the Public Service they are given appropriate legislative protection. That legislative protection is not provided by clause 16, as you would readily admit.

If that is so, my attitude is, by all means let the government improve my unexceptional amendments, which are based on tried and tested law elsewhere in this country; by all means let them introduce their own stand‐alone legislation and repeal this; but for as long as this does not exist, there is a gaping hole in the protection accorded to our public service employees and in the area of accountability which was not there under the old act.

Public servants are in a more vulnerable situation. We are in a more vulnerable situation under this bill because these protections do not exist. It is for that reason that I have added them in here. The arguments you put are very good ones, and I acknowledge them, but if the coalition does not introduce whistleblower legislation, and there is no means to go back to this issue, what are we to do? We are going to be left without it. They are going to be left vulnerable, and the parliament is going to be left vulnerable. It is for those reasons that I have put this case to you and have put these amendments in the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray is a person who has done much for civil liberties and for the ordinary person not only in this country but also in other countries, but I must say that the amendments he is suggesting here are—unintentionally on his part—oppressive. For example, his proposed clause 19T headed `Persons not to refuse to furnish information' goes on to say how a person must give over information, even though that information can be used in a criminal prosecution. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: A person is not liable to a penalty under the provisions of any other enactment by reason of furnishing that information . . .

It is a provision which takes away the right to silence. I have become a great admirer of the right to silence, largely may I say because of the arguments I have heard from the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) over the years in this place. He is a person who has, in my view, a great sense of what the appropriate balance is between the need to see wrongs suppressed and the need to ensure that people are entitled to live in an appropriate way. I would like to acknowledge that.

Perhaps what I am talking about is best summarised in some words expressed by Mr John Coldrey QC, who was Director of Public Prosecutions in Victoria at the time he gave this paper in July 1990 and who has since gone on to become a Supreme Court justice. He said this in a paper entitled `The right to silence reassessed':

The right to silence has formed an integral part of the English criminal justice system, and those systems based upon it, for the last 300 years. The concept has survived despite periodic criticism of it. Consequently it is not unreasonable to cast upon those who seek its abolition or modification the onus of justifying the necessity for change.

The present balance in the criminal justice system is, it appears to me, designed to prevent what most persons would regard as the ultimate injustice. This is not that guilty people are acquitted, but that innocent people are convicted. Assuming that the proponents of abolition or modification subscribe to the same value system, it would seem imperative that any evidentiary procedures they might postulate in substitution for the status quo do not increase the possibilities of injustice.

There is, and always will be, an uneasy tension in the administration of the criminal law between the competing public interests of convicting the guilty and protecting individual citizens from unfair, illegal or arbitrary treatment. There is ample scope for persons of goodwill to differ as to where the balance between these competing interests should be struck. Commenting on the question of balance Mr. Justice Vincent of the Victorian Supreme Court has remarked:

TAB.EMPHASIS: "The task is to recognise that the problem which exists in the community in relation to criminal behaviour is, in a sense, part of the price which is paid for freedom. It is important to understand that there is a balance to be struck between these respective interests; . . . that we are aware of the importance of that balance and do not, in any enthusiastic endeavour to prevent particular forms of anti‐social behaviour, create a situation which threatens individual liberties that every man, woman and child in this community are entitled to."

SPEECH.PARA: Is the price paid for the right to silence too great?

These amendments proposed by Senator Murray take away the right to silence. I must make a distinction here between the right to silence and the right not to incriminate oneself—they are two different rights. There is a right that people have that they should not incriminate themselves and there is a right that people have to silence. In my view, these amendments interfere with both those rights.

In the enthusiasm to wash misbehaviour and bad conduct out of the Public Service, which is a noble purpose, these amendments propose to introduce into the Public Service the sort of investigative techniques and oppressive conducts that will not apply to the rest of the community. There are all sorts of problems with these particular amendments. First, it will introduce a culture of informing, and that would be a very bad thing. If I can read another quote that I have used before in the Senate and that I quoted earlier today, which is from a statement made in 1846—a long time ago—but which has been used by the courts from time to time since then. The Vice-Chancellor Sir Knight Bruce made this statement in Pearse v. Pearse:

The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them.

In my view, the sorts of oppressive proceedings that these amendments introduce fall into that category of things that the Vice-Chancellor would not go along with. For example, proposed clause 19V states:
. . . the Commissioner or an authorised person may, at any reasonable time of the day, enter any place occupied by an Agency, and may carry on the investigation at that place.

These are police powers given to people who are not police. There has been growth over the 1980s and 1990s of powers that are given to people who are not even members of the police force. They are powers that go beyond what the police themselves have. There has been an increase in the investigative procedures that have come about in the community and a proliferation—I use that word advisedly—of bodies that investigate people.

What are we doing to the community? What are we trying to do? Where are we going to stop? When are people's rights and liberties going to be given the respect that they are entitled to? When is the climate of informing, of investigating, of putting people on the spot going to stop? When are the rights of individuals to go about living their lives in a reasonable fashion going to come about?

This sort of legislation makes it very easy for people to put other people into embarrassing situations and to inform on them in a way that makes it very difficult to counter. It is the sort of thing that I think we should go into only after the most exhaustive consideration and after the most protracted debate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: University of New South Wales : Closure of St George Campus

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight in this adjournment debate to call on the New South Wales Labor government to use its legal powers to stop the intended closure of the St George campus of the University of New South Wales. A major row has erupted over this decision taken by the council of the University of New South Wales and its Vice‐Chancellor, Professor John Niland.

SPEECH.PARA: If the closure of the St George campus is allowed to proceed, the New South Wales Labor government will create a very disastrous impact on higher education in southern Sydney. A premier school of teacher education—one with an incredibly high reputation and one of the best teacher education schools in New South Wales—will be lost forever.

It is an institution which has a very long record of excellence. One thousand places will be lost and 300 third‐year students who were promised the chance to finish their degree at the University of New South Wales will be disadvantaged. These losses to teacher education will occur at a time when the Preston report has shown growing shortages in teacher education in New South Wales and elsewhere.

BREAK.PARA: The proposed closure of the only higher education facility in southern Sydney, an area of 700,000 people, will mean that those people will be left without any tertiary education provision. Citizens of the municipalities of Hurstville, Kogarah, Rockdale and Sutherland will be adversely affected by the closure of the St George campus.

The story of this campus dates back to 1980. The buildings were constructed in the 1970s with funds supplied by the Commonwealth. These building were to replace the former Alexander Mackie Teachers College as the St George Institute of Higher Education, which was part of the Sydney College of Advanced Education. The land was purchased by the New South Wales government and over a period of 20 years the Commonwealth government invested $150 million of recurrent and capital expenditure in this site.

During the Dawkins amalgamations, this institution was transferred to the University of New South Wales by the then state government at a peppercorn rent of $1. The University of New South Wales now finds that campus surplus to its requirements and it is determined to sell or to lease it. To lease the 15,000 square metres of floor space at $300 per square metre could deliver to the University of New South Wales a $4.5 million annual return. All the people who invested in the Telstra float would be drooling at that sort of investment—$4.5 million a year for a $1 initial investment. This handsome dividend is on current tracking going to be allowed by the New South Wales Labor government.

What about the community interest in the provision of higher education in this region? Today the campus is equipped with fine functioning, purpose‐built, teacher education facilities and sports science facilities. It is the only campus in the geographical region of southern Sydney. It is a full 75‐minute journey by public transport from this campus at Oatley to Kensington—the trek that many will have to make; otherwise they will have to go to the University of Western Sydney or the University of Wollongong, which are at greater distances.

We are advised by Colliers Jardine, who are responsible under the aegis of the University of New South Wales for leasing the property, that expressions of interest close on 28 November this year. The expression of interest is to use the site for `educational purposes'. This is vague and not specific. If a party decides to take up the lease, the whole deal could be stitched up by mid-December this year when the University of New South Wales Council meets. Depending on the terms of the lease, which could be something like a 20-year lease, then the control of government or the possible control of government over the use of that site will be gone forever under such a situation.

Faced with this, what is the reaction of the New South Wales Minister for Education and Training? On 2UE a year ago he said he was quite happy for this campus to be transferred to the University of Wollongong; he really did not have a problem with that concept all. But everything that he has done—or to be more correct, has not done—in the last year indicates that he has no interest in that course of action occurring and, therefore, no interest in the provision of higher education staying in the southern Sydney area.

All he has to do—and the power is with the state minister—is to change the University of New South Wales Act. That would then give him control over what the University of New South Wales is doing. As the act currently stands, the minister has the power to stop the sale, but he does not have any power to stop leasing—that is under the aegis of the University of New South Wales. All the legal obligations rest with the New South Wales parliament.

I have condemned on many occasions the New South Wales minister for his inaction on this matter. He has even attempted the very slippery tactic of creating a smokescreen by saying that he was going to lead a delegation to the federal minister. The federal minister has no power in this matter. Minister Aquilina, the state minister, can change it by amending the act. He could also pursue another suggested solution to the problem by legislating the transfer of the St George site to the University of Wollongong.

The University of New South Wales, with the inaction of the New South Wales Labor government, remains able to thumb its nose at the local community represented by a number of groups and individuals who demand that St George stay open as a higher education facility. These include Associate Professor Alan Watson of the St George 2000 Committee; the mayors of four municipality councils—Hurstville, Kogarah, Sutherland and Rockdale; and federal and New South Wales members of parliament, both Liberal and Labor, all of whom have met on a number of occasions. I do not think in my time in politics I have seen such a united show of action at all levels of government by all parties against this decision.

What does Minister Aquilina do? Sit on his hands, do nothing, just let the whole thing slide away and let the University of New South Wales get its way on this matter. There is a very strong case for retaining the St George campus as a specialist teacher education facility. The Mayor of Kogarah, Councillor James Jordan, has taken action by writing to Colliers Jardine, who have control over the lease on behalf of the University of New South Wales, reflecting the anger and determination of the local community. The mayor wrote:
You are presumably aware that any development proposal will require an application to be submitted to the Council for community notification and determination.
You must also be aware of the very widespread community opposition that has been expressed about the lease or sale of the property. We are committed to ensuring the site remains as a university.
The University of New South Wales and potential lessees should beware as a result of that statement by the local mayor.

Finally, I want to congratulate the initiative shown by the Liberal shadow minister for education and training in New South Wales, Stephen O'Doherty. He has tabled a private member's bill to do exactly what the Labor minister is failing to do. I hope, along with the St George community, that John Aquilina will act in this crisis to save the St George campus. His actions to date have been spineless. He needs to develop backbone quickly to save St George for the people of southern Sydney and from this act of piracy on public assets by the University of New South Wales. Time is running out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Today was a most appropriate day for former Nixon henchman Chuck Colson to have visited this parliament. If he had been at question time in the House of Representatives, he would have seen a very Nixonian thing. He would have seen the Prime Minister of this country refuse to answer a specific four part question about the Prime Minister's own standards and behaviour. He would have seen, instead, a Prime Minister going into an hysterical rant, attacking Mr Beazley and Mr Evans, knowing that the evidence is to the contrary.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell you when this tale started. On 8 April 1997 the Prime Minister presumably told Mr Jull and Mr Williams to have their departments search their records of the previous government of 1983 in matters pertaining to Senator Colston. These requests occurred simultaneously for Mr Williams and Mr Jull to their departments. Both departments refused the request. Their refusal was backed up by advice from the deputy secretary of PM&C who also said that these ministers were not entitled to those records. The next step by the government was to have Mr Howard write to Mr Beazley seeking Mr Beazley's permission for the current government to have the files of the previous government dating back to 1983.

Mr Beazley generously concedes and grants that permission and puts a request in that any such documents available to the government be made available to him. Immediately, both departments are informed. Whilst not shown Mr Beazley's letter and the conditionality of his letter, both departments are informed that they can now produce the documents, and both did. In the case of Attorney-General's, they found the files. They passed them on to the Attorney-General (Mr Williams), showing him the original that he had to sight and sign for. He then gave copies of that file to a member of his staff to walk around to the Prime Minister's office. DAS behaved similarly. They passed on the file to Mr Jull who also passed it on to the Prime Minister's office.

Then on 11 April the Prime Minister writes to Mr Beazley and says the departments—plural—have searched their records and he is passing on the documents to Mr Beazley. Guess what? Of all the documents that were around, the two critical documents were not passed on from Attorney-General's. They were deleted somewhere. I will come back to that.

On 11 April, just to make sure, the Prime Minister's office asked an officer from Prime Minister and Cabinet to come over and check the documents to assess the suitability of whether these documents go on to Mr Beazley. That officer, by his own minute, is only shown the DAS file, deliberately, in the Prime Minister's office. The A‐G's file was not shown to Mr Lang, who ticked off the DAS documents to go to Mr Beazley.

It is bad enough a government deleting these documents, but they did not even have the expert from PM&C check whether they were suitable documents to go on. He was not even shown them. But guess what? Quotes from those two documents deleted started to leak out to the press. They were read to the press, not shown to them, by the media officer in the Prime Minister's office. And they start appearing in newspapers in very selective quotes, not the whole document.

What we see here are these documents that Mr Beazley approved, which they otherwise would not have had access to, not being given to Mr Beazley or Mr Evans and then, in total breach of the Archives Act, being selectively leaked bit by bit to the media but leaving out the crucial paragraphs. So we have in Mr Alan Ramsey's column bits and pieces of it quoted.

This was bad enough, but on 29 September, 30 September and 1 October we had Mr Howard and Mr Costello walking into the House of Representatives under pressure on travel matters and resignations of ministers and launching a vicious attack on Mr Beazley and Mr Evans. The nature of that attack was that they conspired to ignore the advice of the head of the Attorney-General's Department and the Chief General Counsel. They were alleged to be perverters of the course of justice. Yet what do the two documents hidden, deleted, somewhere in the Prime Minister's office show? Document No. 1, if you like, dated 14 September signed by Mr Brazil points out that the one piece of evidentiary evidence that the Prime Minister relies on is in fact wrong—the so-called Holdich note of 23 August. Mr Brazil on 14 September says in fact it is a distortion of the Attorney's view.

Then on 18 September both Mr Brazil and Mr Tom Sherman sign off an aide memoire in which they concur with the Attorney's actions. They even give their specific reasons why the Attorney acted appropriately. These two documents that would have been valuable in the debate somehow disappeared out of the system. The Labor Party is deprived of them whilst the Prime Minister's media spinners go out there to try to reinforce the Prime Minister and other people's accusations in regard to this.

We have asked some questions on this. We have asked who walked around the documents from the A‐G's office and who did they give them to in the Prime Minister's office. We do not have any answers to those questions. We do not have answers to questions as to how they happened to disappear. There are two theories here. One is that some sneaky, unprincipled staff member just pocketed them and thought, `These will be really handy. We'll be able to make hay while the sun shines.' I must say, I hope that happened. I hope it was not the Prime Minister who authorised this act. Until today, I did not think it was. I did not think the Prime Minister could sink to such low depths as to delete documents such as this and then misuse the generosity of the Leader of the Opposition who said, `Sure, you can go back into the files.'

Just so people understand, it is a convention in this place, in this parliament, that a new government does not have access to the files of the previous government, except for one condition—for purposes of continuity, and none of us begrudge that. I should say that, when that is invoked, generally those files are not shown to the new government but a position summary is done by a departmental officer and is passed on to the government. There are obvious reasons why the new government does need to know about some of the decisions and issues that the previous government considered—so that they know what the trade-offs were so they can govern appropriately.

Going back 13 years was nothing to do with continuity; going back 13 years was just for political purposes. But those political purposes are ill‐served when, having got the documents only on the permission of Mr Beazley—they could not get them otherwise—they do not pass those documents on.

This actually fits a pattern that is starting emerge in this country, that the Prime Minister's office, through a whole series of sneaky manoeuvres, is becoming absolutely Nixonian. We went through the episode of how Labor ministers were targeted for legitimate repayments to be asterisked. But for those Liberal ministers who made repayments, of course, Mr Morris and Mr Sutherland and others conspired to make sure they were not highlighted in any way. This is a total misuse of office and it is not the first time that the Prime Minister's media office has been engaged in this sort of manipulation.

I say again, I really do hope the Prime Minister had nothing to do with this sordid affair, but it makes you wonder. On 29 October, the Prime Minister was finally given a letter to send to Mr Evans, including the documents and some sort of explanation as to what happened. Up until this morning no correspondence arrived and, when it did, it was quite obvious that the new letter was just prepared yesterday or today under pressure. In fact it was completely different from the one on the 29th.

What we have here is a government that will stoop to any Nixonian level for political manipulation. They are going to get exposed on this and other similar issues if they continue to behave this way. I cannot think of one occasion in the 13 years of Labor government when we went back to the files of the previous government. Not on one occasion did we do so. Yet here we have a government that is totally unprincipled and a Prime Minister's office that is totally out of control. If he wants to retain some reputation for integrity he should take action—have an investigation, find out who is responsible, give them the Grahame Morris treatment and put them out the door.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to take a few moments of the Senate's time to discuss some ethical franchising tactics. The prompt response of the Liberal government to the report, Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia , produced by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, is indeed to be applauded. A very extensive and thorough investigation into unfair conduct by big business towards small business was carried out and the speed with which the government has acted on its report will be warmly welcomed by many in the small business community. Tonight I wish to stress that it is not only big business that can act unscrupulously towards small business; some small businesses can in relation to other small businesses.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Labor Party's 13 years in office, 17 fair trading reports, reviews or draft proposals, were unfortunately shelved, ignored or deferred. In stark contrast, within just 18 weeks of the report being tabled, the coalition Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, the Hon. Peter Reith, made public the government's commitment to end the Trade Practices Act so that small business would be protected in its commercial dealings with big business. Enabling legislation, the Trade Practices Amendment (Fair Trading) Bill 1997 will be introduced shortly I think into the House of Representatives.

The government accepted all the recommendations of the report, either fully or in part, taking into account the powers of the Commonwealth as well as ensuring that the greatest benefits and the least obstacles were achieved for small business. In the area of franchising, for example, the committee recommended that the franchising code of practice and the other relevant codes should provide for full disclosure of information related to rental, outgoings, promotion ex penses, tenancy mix and redevelopment proposals to franchisees who sub‐let their premises from the franchisor.

It also recommended that the Commonwealth enact specific franchising legislation providing for compulsory registration of franchisors and compliance with codes of practice. The legislation provides for adequate disclosure documentation, the establishment of appropriate independent code administration bodies and dispute resolution procedures funded through compulsory registration fees. These measures taken by the government with regard to franchises should go a long way to preventing catastrophes similar to the one in which a couple of my constituents found themselves.

I wish to take this opportunity to draw the attention of honourable senators to the unscrupulous methods used by the Copperart franchising system. Over a period of five years, constituents of mine who have been involved in franchising for approximately 18 years and who owned two Copperart franchises in Tasmania, lost approximately $300,000 through being associated with this particular company. Since August last year the number of Copperart franchises has dropped from 78 to less than 10. Many like my constituents have lost almost everything through what appears to be a deliberate ploy by Copperart to rid the system of franchises.

Copperart, it would seem, is forcing businesses out by financially undermining the profitability and viability of the stores and forcing franchisees to breach their franchise agreements. This is done by inhibiting cash flow through stock supply and price manipulation, and forcing them into debt with Copperart—through rent, for example. The Managing Director of Copperart, Mr Aart van Roest, a former bankrupt, has a track record of misleading and deceptive conduct. He is on record in the Federal Court in the case, Finch v. Copperart, in which Aart van Roest misled the former franchisee.

One of my constituents said that as a director on the Franchising Code Council for four years he had never experienced such a ruthless approach as that undertaken by Copperart in crucifying the majority of its franchisees. From his position on the council he noted that when there were signs that the council would be winding up and the voluntary code of practice would not be enforceable—that was in August 1996—Mr & Mrs van Roest's attitude towards their franchises changed notably. While the council was in existence there was quite a respect for its powers and role. Copperart was looking for credibility and willingly provided documents for existing and incoming franchisees such as regarding disclosure. When the council folded they disregarded all such obligations.

The main component of my constituents' $300,000 loss was for goodwill paid to Copperart for the purchase of the franchise over their two stores. They did anticipate selling their stores to incoming franchisees looking for a suitable business. Unfortunately, prospective buyers would decide against buying once they learnt the truth about the decline in the franchisee numbers and the reasons for this decline. Any goodwill was lost under these circumstances.

The new government has now legislated to strengthen the franchising code by making it mandatory. The Trade Practices Act will be used to underpin vital elements of the code such as pre‐contractual disclosure. Under the legislation a Franchising Policy Council will be set up consisting of three members representing franchisees, three representing franchisors, two service provider representatives and an independent chair.

Their first assignment will be to advise and report to the government on the recommended terms of the mandatory code, including the definition of the `franchise system' for the purposes of the code and whether any sector of the franchising industry should or should not be exempt from the recommended provisions of the mandatory code. A continuing role for the council will be to advise the government on policy issues associated with the code, many of which were raised by the report.

A Codes of Conduct Enforcement Unit will be established under the legislation within the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to monitor and enforce this mandatory franchising code. The government is also keen to see alternative dispute resolution mechanisms set up to reduce litigation and legal costs. The government will appoint a dispute resolution adviser to assist parties to avoid disputes and to reduce the time required to solve a dispute.

There are many former franchisees with similar stories to my constituents. My constituents have lost a lifetime of savings through these unscrupulous entrepreneurs because of the tardiness of the previous government in implementing effective measures to counter underhand trading practices within the franchise industry. Once the government's legislation is passed, other innocent people will be able to have confidence that the law will give them protection against unethical tactics of franchisors such as those experienced by my constituents. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to address the events surrounding the release of the Colston documents from the 1983‐84 period of the Labor government to yet again expose what an underhand, sneaky, sleazy bunch of political operators we have inhabiting the highest political office in the land.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, in good faith, fully understanding there might even be some perceived collateral damage through the release of these documents, said to the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, in April, `Yes. You can have access to documents from that period from the archives as long as I receive copies of all documents.' Of course the Prime Minister wrote back and agreed to that process. But did the Prime Minister keep his word on this? The answer to that is absolutely not. The Prime Minister took advantage of Mr Beazley's sense of fair play, Mr Beazley's sense of decency and, in true John Howard fashion, he dudded him. What else would you expect from a person who single‐handedly invents the dubious political concept of the non-core promise!

Of course this very sleazy conspiracy gets better. The Prime Minister had a pile of documents from the archives of the Department of Administrative Services scrutinised by a documents expert from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Alex Lang, and gave the tick to the release of the Beazley file. Mr Lang was not allowed to go anywhere near the 1983 file from the Attorney‐General's Department. When Mr Lang came over to the Prime Minister's office, strangely enough, the Attorney-General's file was locked away in a cupboard somewhere, stuffed behind the prime ministerial pot plant. We do not really know what happened to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was in Mr O'Leary's office.

—Perhaps it was in Mr O'Leary's office, but Mr Lang never saw them. Why not? You have to ask yourself why not? Because part of that particular file was two documents that showed clearly and categorically that Mr Howard and Mr Costello misled the parliament earlier this year.

SPEECH.PARA: After Mr Lang's visit to the Prime Minister's office, Mr Howard got his staff to fillet the file from the Attorney-General. They extracted the two documents that cleared Mr Evans and Mr Beazley. They sent the remainder of the documents or at least some of the documents over to Mr Beazley, stuffed the aides‐memoire that cleared Mr Evans down the back of the couch and sat on them for eight months. That is what happened to them in the Prime Minister's office. That is what happened in Honest John's office.

I ask you, Madam President: is this honourable behaviour? Is this an honest way to do business? Is this what you expect from the Prime Minister of this country, the highest political office holder in Australia? I do not think you could name another Prime Minister who would be responsible for such underhand and sneaky behaviour. You could not name another Prime Minister who would do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not even Billy Hughes.

—Not even Billy Hughes. This is the same Prime Minister who is concentrating his activities and his attention on these sorts of political games. This is the same Prime Minister who has spent a lot of his time trying to get a building named after Sir William McMahon, the only Prime Minister in the living memory of Australians who might compare somewhat favourably with the current Prime Minister. This is the same Prime Minister who spends his time having his department head trying to remove the walls and the back of a bus shelter outside the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. There is no concentration on the issues that Australians care about. Go to the tangential non-issue, the sleaze, the trick and John Howard is always in it. Frankly, not only is John Howard devious and Nixonian in his approach; he is inept.
—Madam President, on a point of order: it is quite unparliamentary to say that the Prime Minister or any other member is devious.

—I withdraw. But the dirty tricks merchants in the Prime Minister's office on this occasion went one step too far. You have the chief dirty tricks merchant over there, Mr Tony O'Leary—he has inherited the mantle, given that Mr Morris has got the boot. He decided to make political capital out of Kim Beazley's generous gesture to approve release of the documents. It is the same Tony O'Leary, by the way, who conducted the whisper campaign in the press gallery about Sir Ronald Wilson and his fitness to conduct the stolen children generation inquiry, and we do not forget Mr O'Leary for that. He is the same Tony O'Leary—we do not forget him for this—who wrote the questions that a couple of dopes from the Liberal Party, a couple of backbench senators, asked at a Senate estimates committee about Mr Kerry O'Brien.
—They failed to ask them. They drew the line; they would not ask them.

—Maybe they drew the line, but you have to admit it was pretty dopey having the whole thing come out publicly. That is fair enough. This is a Nixonian style administration that we have in this country. It is exactly what we have come to expect from the Prime Minister's way of doing business—that is, selectively leaking parts of documents to journalists without providing those self‐same documents to Mr Beazley. It was not good enough for the Leader of the Opposition, the man who gave permission for these documents, for these files, to be investigated, on the condition they be provided to him, to receive all the documents. When he got the documents, they had been filleted in the Prime Minister's office and selectively leaked to journalists. You might ask: is this allowed under the Archives Act? Answer: absolutely not. In fact, people in Mr Howard's office might be in very serious breach of the Archives Act by leaking this material to the press, and that is going to require further investigation on the part of the opposition. I guarantee we will look into that, and perhaps that will involve the Australian Federal Police.

SPEECH.PARA: Do not forget that it is the same Mr Howard who called the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) perverters of the course of justice. It is the same Mr Howard who uttered those words. Since the Prime Minister called the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition perverters of the course of justice, it has come to light that Mr Howard himself is at best a perverter of the truth, a perverter of the truth into slimy, sleazy, sneaky little cover-ups in his own office. When Mr Evans realised that this was occurring, he wrote a letter.

Eventually as the time has moved on Mr Howard has been caught in his own rat trap. That is what has happened. He has been exposed for what he is—that is, not only a grubby opportunist but an inept and incompetent opportunist as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Faulkner has been given a lot of latitude from this side of the chamber, but to say that any honourable member of the House is grubby in the fashion in which Senator Faulkner has done it, I believe, is also unparliamentary and he should be asked to withdrew.

—On that point of order, Madam President, we had a situation in the other place where the Prime Minister was able to get away, now we find, without any justice, with nominating two people as per verters of the course of justice. Let us have a bit of justice in this chamber and set some standards. If it is going to be ruled out here, I hope you will take it up with your colleague in the other place who weakly and ineptly refused to rule it out of order.
—I do believe that the phrase used is unparliamentary, and I would ask you to withdraw.

—Given that Mr Howard has accused the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition of being perverters of the course of justice—that is what the House of Representatives Hansard says—who is the perverter of the course of justice? I will tell you who it is. The answer to that question is Mr Howard. That is who it is. Mr Howard is the perverter of the course of justice.
—Senator Faulkner, I did ask you to withdraw that earlier phrase.

—Madam President, on a point of order: if it is competent in the House of Representatives and is parliamentary for the Prime Minister in question time to accuse the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition of being perverters of the course of justice, why is it unparliamentary in the Senate chamber for me, having had Mr Howard and his office exposed in their sleazy little deal, to use precisely the same terminology? That is my point of order.

—We have absolutely no control over what is said or what is ruled on in the House of Representatives. It is a matter for this chamber, and I believe the expression you have used is unparliamentary and I would ask you to withdraw it.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I thought the issue at hand—and this is a new point of order that has not been raised that you have just ruled on—was the previous comments made by Senator Faulkner that you asked him to withdraw.
—They are the comments I am asking him to withdraw.
—I think he will. I think he sort of nodded, but he did not actual ly articulate the withdrawal. He then went on to make other comments, to which no objection has yet been taken.
—If that is the view of the opposition, I object to the more recent comments made by Senator Faulkner.
—Why don't you go and talk to Halverson. What a disgrace! What an absolute disgrace!
—Order! There are two phrases which I believe should be withdrawn, Senator Faulkner.
—If I have uttered any unparliamentary words, of course, as always, I would withdraw them.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. In the course of raising a point of order, Senator Ray used some fairly unflattering and, I believe, unparliamentary comments about the Speaker. In particular, he made a reflection upon a ruling made by the Speaker, which I do not believe is according dignity to either the House or the Senate. I would suggest that, for the good functioning of the Senate, that comment be withdrawn as well.

—A ruling of the Speaker in the context in which it may have been made is nothing to do with this chamber. I heard Senator Ray's voice but not what he said at the same time as I was listening to Senator Faulkner. I cannot comment on what I did not hear. Senator Faulkner has withdrawn the two statements that he was asked to withdraw and has 15 seconds to conclude his remarks.
—What we have is a conspiracy and a cover-up in the Prime Minister's office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 92 (Senate Hansard, 18 September 1996, p.3576):

(3) Is it the case that the Federal Office of Road Safety requested legal opinion and engineering opinion on the legality of bull‐bars, following a statement by a Melbourne coroner regarding Australian Design Rule 42.9.1.1; if so, was this advice concurrent with the opinion of the coroner.

(2) In relation to parts (1) and (2) of the answer to question on notice no. 92: (a) how much power do the States and Territories have to exempt themselves from the Australian design rules; and (b) have all States and Territories specifically exempted themselves from the Australian design rules relating to bull‐bars in the same way as, or a similar way to, the example given from the Victorian Road Safety Act.

(3) Is the Minister aware whether accident report forms used in the various States and Territories have any area on them which prompts police to report the presence of a bull‐bar in any vehicle accident.

(4) In relation to the working group referred to in part (4) of the answer to question on notice no. 92:(a) can a list be provided of the specific members of or groups which comprise the working group; (b) has the group produced any report(s) and/or is there a date for the provision of any report(s); and (c) as well as developing a standard for the design of bull‐bars, is this group considering the appropriateness of bull‐bars being used at all, particularly in metropolitan areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Development has provided the following supplementary answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) (a) The working group referred to is no longer active. When active, participation in the group's deliberations varied over time. Participation has comprised representatives of the Federal Office of Road Safety, National Road Transport Commission, State and Territory authorities, vehicle manufactures and importers, suppliers of bullbars, researchers in the fields of computer simulation and energy absorbing barrier design, Australian Automobile Association and its constituent bodies. I am advised that the Australian Consumers Association nominated a representative but he did not participate in deliberations as it was not possible for the Federal Office of Road Safety to provide funding for his attendance at meetings outside Melbourne. (b) The working group has not produced any reports. The current situation is that Standards Australia, at the request of the Australian Automotive Aftermarket Association, is considering the development of an Australian Standard for performance requirements for frontal protection bars for use with motor vehicles. (c) No.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) Did the Coalition parties promise at the 1996 federal election that the Defence Housing Authority (DHA) would give special attention to housing in isolated areas and the standard of accommodation for on-base single personnel; and (b) is that still the Government's intention.
(2) What forms of special attention to housing in isolated areas has the DHA been asked by the Government to give.
(3) How much accommodation for on-base single personnel has the DHA been asked to provide to date.
(4) Is the DHA to be subject to the full range of competitive neutrality measures such as taxes and providing a business rate of return on its assets.
(5) Is a study proceeding into the option of disposing of Government ownership of the DHA.
(6) Is there to be a study into the legislation governing the DHA; if so, for what purpose has the study been ordered.
(7) Does the Government have any policies on how Defence families are to be assisted with housing if the DHA is dismantled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with advice to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel the following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. The Coalition policy on Defence stated "The Defence Housing Authority will give special attention to housing in isolated areas and the standard of accommodation for on-base single personnel." The standard of accommodation for on-base personnel has been rigorously reviewed and in 1996 a comprehensive survey of living in accommodation was undertaken across Australia. Recent development proposals for Townsville and Darwin have been based on the outcomes of these reviews and include providing soldier accommodation of a single room with individual ensuite.
(b) Yes.

(2) The function of DHA is to provide housing to meet the operational needs of the Australian Defence Force and the requirements of the Department of Defence. To cater for fluctuations in of houses required, DHA provides around 85% of the total requirement wit,h the remaining houses being rented by individuals on the private market. In isolated areas where there is little or no private market, DHA provides 100% of the housing requirement.
(3) None. DHA do not provide accommodation for on-base single personnel.

(4) DHA will need to comply with the Commonwealth's Competitive Neutrality Policy Statement. The degree to which DHA will comply with, and the timing for application of, these principles is presently a matter for discussion between the relevant shareholder Ministers.

(5) Reviews are being undertaken of the need for continued Commonwealth ownership of Commonwealth GBEs. The previous government categorised the Defence Housing Authority as a GBE and the review process thus includes the Authority.
(6) A review of the Defence Housing Authority Act 1987 is required under the Commonwealth's Legislation Review Schedule for 1997-98.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that a distinct stock of `pygmy snapper' is now being confirmed to occupy the area of lower Useless Inlet, which includes the Shark Bay World Heritage Area and the Useless Loop salt pond currently being constructed.
(2) Is the Minister aware that this stock is likely to become extinct on completion of the pond.

(3) (a) Will the Federal Government provide the $30 000 needed to determine the taxonomic status of the stock by DNA fingerprinting; and (b) if the stock proves to be an endangered species, would the Minister take action to protect it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)—(2) I am aware that genetic studies comparing the Useless Inlet snapper with snapper from other areas of Shark Bay have begun, but these studies have not yet concluded.
(3) (a) The Federal Government has noted that the Western Australian Government is already undertaking genetic testing.

(b) If the genetic testing demonstrates that the stock is a separate species, its status would be considered in accordance with the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992. In the light of this assessment, appropriate action would be considered in co-operation with the Western Australian Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 20 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What was the level of illegal fishing for the Patagonian toothfish around Heard Island in the 1996 and 1997 calendar years; (b) what action has the government taken to protect the Heard Island marine environment from illegal fishing; and (c) how much has been budgeted and how much has been spent.

(2) (a) What research and monitoring programs have been undertaken or planned to assess the impact of the toothfish fishery on wildlife on Heard and Macquarie Islands; and (b) why was the fishery allowed to go ahead with no monitoring in place to assess its ecological impact.

(3) (a) Why is the Tasmanian Parks and wildlife Service not represented on the Fisheries Advisory Group which advises the Australian Fisheries Management Authority Board on sub-Antarctic fisheries; and (b) why has an ecological adviser on sub-Antarctic fisheries not been appointed, as previously promised by AFMA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Fishing for Patagonian toothfish by Australian authorised fishing vessels commenced in the Australian fishing zone (AFZ) at Heard Island and MacDonald Islands (HIMI) in April 1997. There is no information available concerning illegal foreign fishing vessel activity at HIMI prior to this time. From April 1997 until the end of October 1997 a total of 15 incidents involving 14 foreign fishing vessels have been reported to the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) by Australian authorised fishing vessels operating in the area.

(1) (b) & (1) (c) Surveillance and enforcement action in the AFZ around HIMI is still ongoing and it would be inappropriate to provide operational details on this activity, its budget or current expenditure levels at this time. However, I can report that in a recent action at HIMI two foreign fishing vessels were apprehended in Australian waters for alleged breaches of fisheries legislation. The vessels have been escorted to port in Fremantle and investigations are continuing.
(2) (a) A number of measures have been set in place to assess the impacts of the fishery for Patagonian toothfish on the wildlife at HIMI and Macquarie Islands, which include:
• the mandatory requirement to carry two scientific observers on each fishing vessel to:
• monitor the fishing vessel's activities;
• gather biological data on fish species; and
• monitor any interaction with marine mammals and sea birds;
• the funding of a $2.9 million three-year research project, to be conducted jointly by the Australian Antarctic Division (AAD) and CSIRO; and
• the convening of a workshop on predator-prey interactions for sub-Antarctic fisheries.

(2) (b) The Macquarie Island Developmental Fishery and the HIMI Exploratory Fishery Management Policies were approved by the Minister for the Environment, Senator the Hon Robert Hill. In accordance with the Administrative Procedures under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the Minister for the Environment determined that neither an environmental impact statement nor a public environment report was required and that AFMA's assessment process had identified the relevant environmental issues and measures needed for the monitoring of environmental impacts and the protection of the environment of both fisheries.

(3) (a) AFMA is currently in the process of forming the Sub-Antarctic Management Advisory Committee of which no members have been appointed to date. It is AFMA's intention that one representative from the Tasmanian State Government will be invited to participate as a member.

AFMA will be writing to the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industries and Fisheries and the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Management (of which Tasmanian Parks and Wildlife is a part) to request them to nominate a single representative of the Tasmanian State Government to be a member of the Management Advisory Committee.

(3) (b) AFMA has made available $50,000 to fund the position of an ecological coordinator for Sub-Antarctic fisheries, however the process for defining the duties of the position and recruiting for it have yet to be completed.
